Endpoint Denial of Service: Application or System Exploitation is techniques
Description: Adversaries may exploit software vulnerabilities that can cause an application or system to crash and deny availability to users. 
 Some systems may automatically restart critical applications and services when crashes occur, but they can likely be re-exploited to cause a persistent denial of service (DoS) condition.
Adversaries may exploit known or zero-day vulnerabilities to crash applications and/or systems, which may also lead to dependent applications and/or systems to be in a DoS condition. Crashed or restarted applications or systems may also have other effects such as 
, 
, 
 etc. which may further cause a DoS condition and deny availability to critical information, applications and/or systems.

Endpoint Denial of Service: OS Exhaustion Flood is techniques
Description: Adversaries may launch a denial of service (DoS) attack targeting an endpoint's operating system (OS). A system's OS is responsible for managing the finite resources as well as preventing the entire system from being overwhelmed by excessive demands on its capacity. These attacks do not need to exhaust the actual resources on a system; the attacks may simply exhaust the limits and available resources that an OS self-imposes.
Different ways to achieve this exist, including TCP state-exhaustion attacks such as SYN floods and ACK floods.
 With SYN floods, excessive amounts of SYN packets are sent, but the 3-way TCP handshake is never completed. Because each OS has a maximum number of concurrent TCP connections that it will allow, this can quickly exhaust the ability of the system to receive new requests for TCP connections, thus preventing access to any TCP service provided by the server.
ACK floods leverage the stateful nature of the TCP protocol. A flood of ACK packets are sent to the target. This forces the OS to search its state table for a related TCP connection that has already been established. Because the ACK packets are for connections that do not exist, the OS will have to search the entire state table to confirm that no match exists. When it is necessary to do this for a large flood of packets, the computational requirements can cause the server to become sluggish and/or unresponsive, due to the work it must do to eliminate the rogue ACK packets. This greatly reduces the resources available for providing the targeted service.

Endpoint Denial of Service: Service Exhaustion Flood is techniques
Description: Adversaries may target the different network services provided by systems to conduct a denial of service (DoS). Adversaries often target the availability of DNS and web services, however others have been targeted as well.
 Web server software can be attacked through a variety of means, some of which apply generally while others are specific to the software being used to provide the service.
One example of this type of attack is known as a simple HTTP flood, where an adversary sends a large number of HTTP requests to a web server to overwhelm it and/or an application that runs on top of it. This flood relies on raw volume to accomplish the objective, exhausting any of the various resources required by the victim software to provide the service.
Another variation, known as a SSL renegotiation attack, takes advantage of a protocol feature in SSL/TLS. The SSL/TLS protocol suite includes mechanisms for the client and server to agree on an encryption algorithm to use for subsequent secure connections. If SSL renegotiation is enabled, a request can be made for renegotiation of the crypto algorithm. In a renegotiation attack, the adversary establishes a SSL/TLS connection and then proceeds to make a series of renegotiation requests. Because the cryptographic renegotiation has a meaningful cost in computation cycles, this can cause an impact to the availability of the service when done in volume.

Endpoint Denial of Service: Application Exhaustion Flood is techniques
Description: Adversaries may target resource intensive features of applications to cause a denial of service (DoS), denying availability to those applications. For example, specific features in web applications may be highly resource intensive. Repeated requests to those features may be able to exhaust system resources and deny access to the application or the server itself.

Network Denial of Service: Reflection Amplification is techniques
Description: Adversaries may attempt to cause a denial of service (DoS) by reflecting a high-volume of network traffic to a target. This type of Network DoS takes advantage of a third-party server intermediary that hosts and will respond to a given spoofed source IP address. This third-party server is commonly termed a reflector. An adversary accomplishes a reflection attack by sending packets to reflectors with the spoofed address of the victim. Similar to Direct Network Floods, more than one system may be used to conduct the attack, or a botnet may be used. Likewise, one or more reflectors may be used to focus traffic on the target.
 This Network DoS attack may also reduce the availability and functionality of the targeted system(s) and network.
Reflection attacks often take advantage of protocols with larger responses than requests in order to amplify their traffic, commonly known as a Reflection Amplification attack. Adversaries may be able to generate an increase in volume of attack traffic that is several orders of magnitude greater than the requests sent to the amplifiers. The extent of this increase will depending upon many variables, such as the protocol in question, the technique used, and the amplifying servers that actually produce the amplification in attack volume. Two prominent protocols that have enabled Reflection Amplification Floods are DNS
 and NTP
, though the use of several others in the wild have been documented.
  In particular, the memcache protocol showed itself to be a powerful protocol, with amplification sizes up to 51,200 times the requesting packet.

Network Denial of Service: Direct Network Flood is techniques
Description: Adversaries may attempt to cause a denial of service (DoS) by directly sending a high-volume of network traffic to a target. This DoS attack may also reduce the availability and functionality of the targeted system(s) and network. 
s are when one or more systems are used to send a high-volume of network packets towards the targeted service's network. Almost any network protocol may be used for flooding. Stateless protocols such as UDP or ICMP are commonly used but stateful protocols such as TCP can be used as well.
Botnets are commonly used to conduct network flooding attacks against networks and services. Large botnets can generate a significant amount of traffic from systems spread across the global Internet. Adversaries may have the resources to build out and control their own botnet infrastructure or may rent time on an existing botnet to conduct an attack. In some of the worst cases for distributed DoS (DDoS), so many systems are used to generate the flood that each one only needs to send out a small amount of traffic to produce enough volume to saturate the target network. In such circumstances, distinguishing DDoS traffic from legitimate clients becomes exceedingly difficult. Botnets have been used in some of the most high-profile DDoS flooding attacks, such as the 2012 series of incidents that targeted major US banks.

Resource Hijacking: Cloud Service Hijacking is techniques
Description: Adversaries may leverage compromised software-as-a-service (SaaS) applications to complete resource-intensive tasks, which may impact hosted service availability. 
For example, adversaries may leverage email and messaging services, such as AWS Simple Email Service (SES), AWS Simple Notification Service (SNS), SendGrid, and Twilio, in order to send large quantities of spam / 
 emails and SMS messages.
 Alternatively, they may engage in LLMJacking by leveraging reverse proxies to hijack the power of cloud-hosted AI models.
In some cases, adversaries may leverage services that the victim is already using. In others, particularly when the service is part of a larger cloud platform, they may first enable the service.
 Leveraging SaaS applications may cause the victim to incur significant financial costs, use up service quotas, and otherwise impact availability.

Resource Hijacking: Compute Hijacking is techniques
Description: Adversaries may leverage the compute resources of co-opted systems to complete resource-intensive tasks, which may impact system and/or hosted service availability. 
One common purpose for 
 is to validate transactions of cryptocurrency networks and earn virtual currency. Adversaries may consume enough system resources to negatively impact and/or cause affected machines to become unresponsive.
 Servers and cloud-based systems are common targets because of the high potential for available resources, but user endpoint systems may also be compromised and used for 
 and cryptocurrency mining.
 Containerized environments may also be targeted due to the ease of deployment via exposed APIs and the potential for scaling mining activities by deploying or compromising multiple containers within an environment or cluster.
Additionally, some cryptocurrency mining malware identify then kill off processes for competing malware to ensure it’s not competing for resources.

Resource Hijacking: Bandwidth Hijacking is techniques
Description: Adversaries may leverage the network bandwidth resources of co-opted systems to complete resource-intensive tasks, which may impact system and/or hosted service availability. 
Adversaries may also use malware that leverages a system's network bandwidth as part of a botnet in order to facilitate 
 campaigns and/or to seed malicious torrents.
 Alternatively, they may engage in proxyjacking by selling use of the victims' network bandwidth and IP address to proxyware services.
 Finally, they may engage in internet-wide scanning in order to identify additional targets for compromise.
In addition to incurring potential financial costs or availability disruptions, this technique may cause reputational damage if a victim’s bandwidth is used for illegal activities.

Resource Hijacking: SMS Pumping is techniques
Description: Adversaries may leverage messaging services for SMS pumping, which may impact system and/or hosted service availability.
 SMS pumping is a type of telecommunications fraud whereby a threat actor first obtains a set of phone numbers from a telecommunications provider, then leverages a victim’s messaging infrastructure to send large amounts of SMS messages to numbers in that set. By generating SMS traffic to their phone number set, a threat actor may earn payments from the telecommunications provider.
Threat actors often use publicly available web forms, such as one-time password (OTP) or account verification fields, in order to generate SMS traffic. These fields may leverage services such as Twilio, AWS SNS, and Amazon Cognito in the background.
 In response to the large quantity of requests, SMS costs may increase and communication channels may become overwhelmed.

Supply Chain Compromise: Compromise Software Dependencies and Development Tools is techniques
Description: Adversaries may manipulate products or product delivery mechanisms prior to receipt by a final consumer for the purpose of data or system compromise. Applications often depend on external software to function properly. Popular open source projects that are used as dependencies in many applications may be targeted as a means to add malicious code to users of the dependency.

Supply Chain Compromise: Compromise Software Supply Chain is techniques
Description: Adversaries may manipulate application software prior to receipt by a final consumer for the purpose of data or system compromise. Supply chain compromise of software can take place in a number of ways, including manipulation of the application source code, manipulation of the update/distribution mechanism for that software, or replacing compiled releases with a modified version.

Supply Chain Compromise: Compromise Hardware Supply Chain is techniques
Description: Adversaries may manipulate hardware components in products prior to receipt by a final consumer for the purpose of data or system compromise. By modifying hardware or firmware in the supply chain, adversaries can insert a backdoor into consumer networks that may be difficult to detect and give the adversary a high degree of control over the system.

Command and Scripting Interpreter: Unix Shell is techniques
Description: Adversaries may abuse Unix shell commands and scripts for execution. Unix shells are the underlying command prompts on Android and iOS devices. Unix shells can control every aspect of a system, with certain commands requiring elevated privileges that are only accessible if the device has been rooted or jailbroken. 
Unix shells also support scripts that enable sequential execution of commands as well as other typical programming operations such as conditionals and loops. Common uses of shell scripts include long or repetitive tasks, or the need to run the same set of commands on multiple systems. 
Adversaries may abuse Unix shells to execute various commands or payloads. Interactive shells may be accessed through command and control channels or during lateral movement such as with SSH. Adversaries may also leverage shell scripts to deliver and execute multiple commands on victims or as part of payloads used for persistence. 
If the device has been rooted or jailbroken, adversaries may locate and invoke a superuser binary to elevate their privileges and interact with the system as the root user. This dangerous level of permissions allows the adversary to run special commands and modify protected system files.

Event Triggered Execution: Broadcast Receivers is techniques
Description: Adversaries may establish persistence using system mechanisms that trigger execution based on specific events. Mobile operating systems have means to subscribe to events such as receiving an SMS message, device boot completion, or other device activities. 
An intent is a message passed between Android applications or system components. Applications can register to receive broadcast intents at runtime, which are system-wide intents delivered to each app when certain events happen on the device, such as network changes or the user unlocking the screen. Malicious applications can then trigger certain actions within the app based on which broadcast intent was received. 
In addition to Android system intents, malicious applications can register for intents broadcasted by other applications. This allows the malware to respond based on actions in other applications. This behavior typically indicates a more intimate knowledge, or potentially the targeting of specific devices, users, or applications. 
In Android 8 (API level 26), broadcast intent behavior was changed, limiting the implicit intents that applications can register for in the manifest. In most cases, applications that register through the manifest will no longer receive the broadcasts. Now, applications must register context-specific broadcast receivers while the user is actively using the app.

Hijack Execution Flow: System Runtime API Hijacking is techniques
Description: Adversaries may execute their own malicious payloads by hijacking the way an operating system runs applications. Hijacking execution flow can be for the purposes of persistence since this hijacked execution may reoccur at later points in time. 
On Android, adversaries may overwrite the standard OS API library with a malicious alternative to hook into core functions to achieve persistence. By doing this, the adversary’s code will be executed every time the overwritten API function is called by an app on the infected device.

Abuse Elevation Control Mechanism: Device Administrator Permissions is techniques
Description: Adversaries may abuse Android’s device administration API to obtain a higher degree of control over the device. By abusing the API, adversaries can perform several nefarious actions, such as resetting the device’s password for 
, factory resetting the device for 
 and to delete any traces of the malware, disabling all the device’s cameras, or to make it more difficult to uninstall the app.
Device administrators must be approved by the user at runtime, with a system popup showing which actions have been requested by the app. In conjunction with other techniques, such as 
, an app can programmatically grant itself administrator permissions without any user input.

Process Injection: Ptrace System Calls is techniques
Description: Adversaries may inject malicious code into processes via ptrace (process trace) system calls in order to evade process-based defenses as well as possibly elevate privileges. Ptrace system call injection is a method of executing arbitrary code in the address space of a separate live process.  
Ptrace system call injection involves attaching to and modifying a running process. The ptrace system call enables a debugging process to observe and control another process (and each individual thread), including changing memory and register values.
 Ptrace system call injection is commonly performed by writing arbitrary code into a running process (e.g., by using 
) then invoking that memory with 
 to set the register containing the next instruction to execute. Ptrace system call injection can also be done with 
/
, which copy data to a specific address in the target process's memory (e.g., the current address of the next instruction).
  
Ptrace system call injection may not be possible when targeting processes with high-privileges, and on some systems those that are non-child processes.
  
Running code in the context of another process may allow access to the process's memory, system/network resources, and possibly elevated privileges. Execution via ptrace system call injection may also evade detection from security products since the execution is masked under a legitimate process.

Hide Artifacts: Conceal Multimedia Files is techniques
Description: Adversaries may attempt to hide multimedia files from the user. By doing so, adversaries may conceal captured files, such as pictures, videos and/or screenshots, then later exfiltrate those files.  
Specific to Android devices, if the 
 file is present in a folder, multimedia files in that folder will not be visible to the user in the Gallery application. Additionally, other applications are asked not to scan the folder with the 
 file, effectively making the folder appear invisible to the user.  
This technique is often used by stalkerware and spyware applications.

Hide Artifacts: User Evasion is techniques
Description: Adversaries may attempt to avoid detection by hiding malicious behavior from the user. By doing this, an adversary’s modifications would most likely remain installed on the device for longer, allowing the adversary to continue to operate on that device. 
While there are many ways this can be accomplished, one method is by using the device’s sensors. By utilizing the various motion sensors on a device, such as accelerometer or gyroscope, an application could detect that the device is being interacted with. That way, the application could continue to run while the device is not in use but cease operating while the user is using the device, hiding anything that would indicate malicious activity was ongoing. Accessing the sensors in this way does not require any permissions from the user, so it would be completely transparent.

Hide Artifacts: Suppress Application Icon is techniques
Description: A malicious application could suppress its icon from being displayed to the user in the application launcher. This hides the fact that it is installed, and can make it more difficult for the user to uninstall the application. Hiding the application's icon programmatically does not require any special permissions. 
This behavior has been seen in the BankBot/Spy Banker family of malware.
 
Beginning in Android 10, changes were introduced to inhibit malicious applications’ ability to hide their icon. If an app is a system app, requests no permissions, or does not have a launcher activity, the application’s icon will be fully hidden. Further, if the device is fully managed or the application is in a work profile, the icon will be fully hidden. Otherwise, a synthesized activity is shown, which is a launcher icon that represents the app’s details page in the system settings. If the user clicks the synthesized activity in the launcher, they are taken to the application’s details page in the system settings.

Impair Defenses: Device Lockout is techniques
Description: An adversary may seek to inhibit user interaction by locking the legitimate user out of the device. This is typically accomplished by requesting device administrator permissions and then locking the screen using 
. Other novel techniques for locking the user out of the device have been observed, such as showing a persistent overlay, using carefully crafted "call" notification screens, and locking HTML pages in the foreground. These techniques can be very difficult to get around, and typically require booting the device into safe mode to uninstall the malware.
Prior to Android 7, device administrators were able to reset the device lock passcode to prevent the user from unlocking the device. The release of Android 7 introduced updates that only allow device or profile owners (e.g. MDMs) to reset the device’s passcode.

Impair Defenses: Disable or Modify Tools is techniques
Description: Adversaries may disable security tools to avoid potential detection of their tools and activities. This can take the form of disabling security software, modifying SELinux configuration, or other methods to interfere with security tools scanning or reporting information. This is typically done by abusing device administrator permissions or using system exploits to gain root access to the device to modify protected system files.

Impair Defenses: Prevent Application Removal is techniques
Description: Adversaries may abuse the Android device administration API to prevent the user from uninstalling a target application. In earlier versions of Android, device administrator applications needed their administration capabilities explicitly deactivated by the user before the application could be uninstalled. This was later updated so the user could deactivate and uninstall the administrator application in one step.
Adversaries may also abuse the device accessibility APIs to prevent removal. This set of APIs allows the application to perform certain actions on behalf of the user and programmatically determine what is being shown on the screen. The malicious application could monitor the device screen for certain modals (e.g., the confirmation modal to uninstall an application) and inject screen input or a back button tap to close the modal. For example, Android's

Description: Adversaries may perform software packing to conceal their code. Software packing is a method of compressing or encrypting an executable. Utilities used to perform software packing are called packers. An example packer is FTT. A more comprehensive list of known packers is available, but adversaries may create their own packing techniques that do not leave the same artifacts as well-known packers to evade defenses.

Description: Adversaries may modify code signing policies to enable execution of applications signed with unofficial or unknown keys. Code signing provides a level of authenticity on an app from a developer, guaranteeing that the program has not been tampered with and comes from an official source. Security controls can include enforcement mechanisms to ensure that only valid, signed code can be run on a device. 
Mobile devices generally enable these security controls by default, such as preventing the installation of unknown applications on Android. Adversaries may modify these policies in a number of ways, including 
 or malicious configuration profiles.

This may include changing behavior after checking for the presence of artifacts indicative of a virtual environment or sandbox. If the adversary detects a virtual environment, they may alter their malware’s behavior to disengage from the victim or conceal the core functions of the implant. They may also search for virtualization artifacts before dropping secondary or additional payloads. 
Checks could include generic system properties such as host/domain name and samples of network traffic. Adversaries may also check the network adapters addresses, CPU core count, and available memory/drive size. 
Hardware checks, such as the presence of motion sensors, could also be used to gather evidence that can be indicative a virtual environment. Adversaries may also query for specific readings from these devices.

Keychains are the built-in way for iOS to keep track of users' passwords and credentials for many services and features such as Wi-Fi passwords, websites, secure notes, certificates, private keys, and VPN credentials. 
On the device, the keychain database is stored outside of application sandboxes to prevent unauthorized access to the raw data. Standard iOS APIs allow applications access to their own keychain contained within the database. By utilizing a privilege escalation exploit or existing root access, adversaries can access the entire encrypted database.

Input Capture: GUI Input Capture is techniques
Description: Adversaries may mimic common operating system GUI components to prompt users for sensitive information with a seemingly legitimate prompt. The operating system and installed applications often have legitimate needs to prompt the user for sensitive information such as account credentials, bank account information, or Personally Identifiable Information (PII). There are several approaches adversaries may use to mimic this functionality. Adversaries may impersonate the identity of a legitimate application (e.g. use the same application name and/or icon) and, when installed on the device, may prompt the user for sensitive information.
 Adversaries may also send fake device notifications to the user that may trigger the display of an input prompt when clicked.
 
Additionally, adversaries may display a prompt on top of a running, legitimate application to trick users into entering sensitive information into a malicious application rather than the legitimate application. Typically, adversaries need to know when the targeted application and the individual activity within the targeted application is running in the foreground to display the prompt at the proper time. Adversaries can abuse Android’s accessibility features to determine which application is currently in the foreground.

Applications regularly register URIs with the operating system to act as a response handler for various actions, such as logging into an app using an external account via single sign-on. This allows redirections to that specific URI to be intercepted by the application. If an adversary were to register for a URI that was already in use by a genuine application, the adversary may be able to intercept data intended for the genuine application or perform a phishing attack against the genuine application. Intercepted data may include OAuth authorization codes or tokens that could be used by the adversary to gain access to protected resources.

Encrypted Channel: SSL Pinning is techniques
Description: Adversaries may use 
  to protect the C2 traffic from being intercepted and analyzed.
  is a technique commonly utilized by legitimate websites to ensure that encrypted communications are only allowed with a pre-defined certificate. If another certificate is presented, it could indicate device compromise, traffic interception, or another upstream issue. While benign usages are common, it is also possible for adversaries to abuse this technology to protect malicious C2 traffic.
In normal, not pinned SSL validation, when a client connects to a server using HTTPS, it typically checks whether the server’s SSL/TLS certificate is signed by a trusted Certificate Authority (CA) in the device’s trust store. If the certificate is valid and signed by a trusted CA, the connection is established. However, with 
 , the client is configured to trust a specific SSL/TLS certificate or public key, rather than relying on the device’s trust store. This means that even if the server’s certificate is signed by a trusted CA, the client will only establish the connection of the certificate or key is pinned.

Encrypted Channel: Asymmetric Cryptography is techniques
Description: Adversaries may employ a known asymmetric encryption algorithm to conceal command and control traffic, rather than relying on any inherent protections provided by a communication protocol. Asymmetric cryptography, also known as public key cryptography, uses a keypair per party: one public that can be freely distributed, and one private that should not be distributed. Due to how asymmetric algorithms work, the sender encrypts data with the receiver’s public key and the receiver decrypts the data with their private key. This ensures that only the intended recipient can read the encrypted data. Common public key encryption algorithms include RSA, ElGamal, and ECDSA.
For efficiency, many protocols (including SSL/TLS) use symmetric cryptography once a connection is established, but use asymmetric cryptography to establish or transmit a key. As such, these protocols are classified as 
.

Encrypted Channel: Symmetric Cryptography is techniques
Description: Adversaries may employ a known symmetric encryption algorithm to conceal command and control traffic, rather than relying on any inherent protections provided by a communication protocol. Symmetric encryption algorithms use the same key for plaintext encryption and ciphertext decryption. Common symmetric encryption algorithms include AES, Blowfish, and RC4.

Web Service: One-Way Communication is techniques
Description: Adversaries may use an existing, legitimate external Web service channel as a means for sending commands to a compromised system without receiving return output. Compromised systems may leverage popular websites and social media to host command and control (C2) instructions. Those infected systems may opt to send the output from those commands back over a different C2 channel, including to another distinct Web service. Alternatively, compromised systems may return no output at all in cases where adversaries want to send instructions to systems and do not want a response. 
Popular websites and social media, acting as a mechanism for C2, may give a significant amount of cover. This is due to the likelihood that hosts within a network are already communicating with them prior to a compromise. Using common services, such as those offered by Google or Twitter, makes it easier for adversaries to hide in expected noise. Web service providers commonly use SSL/TLS encryption, giving adversaries an added level of protection.

Web Service: Dead Drop Resolver is techniques
Description: Adversaries may use an existing, legitimate external Web service to host information that points to additional command and control (C2) infrastructure. Adversaries may post content, known as a dead drop resolver, on Web services with embedded (and often obfuscated/encoded) domains or IP addresses. Once infected, victims will reach out to and be redirected by these resolvers. 
Popular websites and social media, acting as a mechanism for C2, may give a significant amount of cover. This is due to the likelihood that hosts within a network are already communicating with them prior to a compromise. Using common services, such as those offered by Google or Twitter, makes it easier for adversaries to hide in expected noise. Web service providers commonly use SSL/TLS encryption, giving adversaries an added level of protection. 
Use of a dead drop resolver may also protect back-end C2 infrastructure from discovery through malware binary analysis, or enable operational resiliency (since this infrastructure may be dynamically changed).

Web Service: Bidirectional Communication is techniques
Description: Adversaries may use an existing, legitimate external Web service channel as a means for sending commands to and receiving output from a compromised system. Compromised systems may leverage popular websites and social media to host command and control (C2) instructions. Those infected systems can then send the output from those commands back over that Web service channel. The return traffic may occur in a variety of ways, depending on the Web service being utilized. For example, the return traffic may take the form of the compromised system posting a comment on a forum, issuing a pull request to development project, updating a document hosted on a Web service, or by sending a Tweet. 
Popular websites and social media, acting as a mechanism for C2, may give a significant amount of cover. This is due to the likelihood that hosts within a network are already communicating with them prior to a compromise. Using common services, such as those offered by Google or Twitter, makes it easier for adversaries to hide in expected noise. Web service providers commonly use SSL/TLS encryption, giving adversaries an added level of protection.

Command and Scripting Interpreter: PowerShell is techniques
Description: Adversaries may abuse PowerShell commands and scripts for execution. PowerShell is a powerful interactive command-line interface and scripting environment included in the Windows operating system.
 Adversaries can use PowerShell to perform a number of actions, including discovery of information and execution of code. Examples include the 
 cmdlet which can be used to run an executable and the 
 cmdlet which runs a command locally or on a remote computer (though administrator permissions are required to use PowerShell to connect to remote systems).
PowerShell may also be used to download and run executables from the Internet, which can be executed from disk or in memory without touching disk.
A number of PowerShell-based offensive testing tools are available, including 
,  
, 
, and PSAttack.
PowerShell commands/scripts can also be executed without directly invoking the 
 binary through interfaces to PowerShell's underlying 
 assembly DLL exposed through the .NET framework and Windows Common Language Interface (CLI).

Out-of-Band Communications Channel is mitigations
Description: Establish secure out-of-band communication channels to ensure the continuity of critical communications during security incidents, data integrity attacks, or in-network communication failures. Out-of-band communication refers to using an alternative, separate communication path that is not dependent on the potentially compromised primary network infrastructure. This method can include secure messaging apps, encrypted phone lines, satellite communications, or dedicated emergency communication systems. Leveraging these alternative channels reduces the risk of adversaries intercepting, disrupting, or tampering with sensitive communications and helps coordinate an effective incident response.

Encrypt Network Traffic is mitigations
Description: Application developers should encrypt all of their application network traffic using the Transport Layer Security (TLS) protocol to ensure protection of sensitive data and deter network-based attacks. If desired, application developers could perform message-based encryption of data before passing it for TLS encryption.
iOS's App Transport Security feature can be used to help ensure that all application network traffic is appropriately protected. Apple intends to mandate use of App Transport Security  
 for all apps in the Apple App Store unless appropriate justification is given.
Android's Network Security Configuration feature similarly can be used by app developers to help ensure that all of their application network traffic is appropriately protected  
.
Use of Virtual Private Network (VPN) tunnels, e.g. using the IPsec protocol, can help mitigate some types of network attacks as well.

WP3.XYZ malware attacks over 5,000 WordPress websites, creating fake administrator accounts.

Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 22/67 (IT) on Thursday, January 16, 2025, discovered a new malware campaign targeting more than 5,000 WordPress websites by creating fake administrator accounts, installing malicious plugins, and stealing sensitive data.  Researchers from the security firm c/side found that the malware uses the domain wp3[.]xyz to send data to the attacker's server. After successfully compromising a system, the malicious script creates an account named "wpx_admin" with a password specified in the code. It then installs a plugin named plugin.php, which collects data such as administrator accounts and logs, and sends the data disguised as image requests to evade security detection.  C/side states that the malware also includes steps to verify the success of the attack, such as checking whether the account and plugin have been created and activated, to systematically track the status of the attack. For prevention, c/side recommends blocking the wp3[.]xyz domain using firewalls and security tools, checking administrator accounts and installed plugins for unusual activity, and adding CSRF (Cross-Site Request Forgery) protection using short-lived server-side tokens.  Furthermore, enabling multi-factor authentication (MFA) will enhance security.

CISA adds BeyondTrust and Qlik Sense vulnerabilities to its Known Exploited Vulnerabilities (KEV) list.  Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 20/67 (IT) Wednesday, January 15, 2025. The US Cybersecurity and Infrastructure Security Agency (CISA) has added new vulnerabilities to the Known Exploited Vulnerabilities (KEV) list, including CVE-2024-12686, an OS Command Injection vulnerability with a CVSS score of 6.6, found in BeyondTrust Privileged Remote Access (PRA) and Remote Support (RS).  Hackers with administrator privileges can exploit this vulnerability to upload malicious files and execute operating system commands. Another added vulnerability is CVE-2023-48365, an HTTP Tunneling vulnerability in Qlik Sense with a CVSS score of 9.6.  This vulnerability allows attackers to escalate privileges and send unauthorized HTTP requests to the backend server, a significant risk that could lead to access to sensitive data within the system. To mitigate and reduce the risk from these vulnerabilities, agencies under the Federal Civilian Executive Branch (FCEB) must patch them within a specified timeframe. CISA requires all vulnerabilities to be patched by February 3, 2025, to prevent exploitation and address related vulnerabilities as quickly as possible.

Telefónica confirms internal ticketing system breach after data leak.  Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 16/67 (IT) Monday, January 13, 2025.  Spanish telecommunications company Telefónica has confirmed that its internal ticketing system was hacked after stolen data was published on a hacking forum. The company revealed that it has blocked access and thoroughly investigated the incident. Telefónica is Spain's largest multinational telecommunications company, with over 104,000 employees and operates in 12 countries. The incident stemmed from attackers using stolen employee account information to access the system. The attackers claim to have extracted approximately 2.3 GB of internal documents and tickets, some of which may be related to customers, but most are tickets opened with @telefonica.com emails for internal problem reporting.  The attackers claiming responsibility for the incident are identified as DNA, Grep, Pryx, and Rey. Pryx told BleepingComputer that they did not demand a ransom or negotiate with Telefónica before publishing the data. The attack occurred yesterday, and the company immediately reset the passwords of the compromised accounts.  Additionally, members of the groups Grep, Pryx, and Rey are also associated with the "Hellcat Ransomware" group, which previously attacked Schneider Electric and stole over 40 GB of data from the company's Jira servers.

SonicWall warns of exploitable vulnerability in SonicOS.

Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 14/67 (IT) Friday, January 10, 2025. SonicWall has issued a warning urging customers to immediately upgrade their firewall's SonicOS firmware to protect against an authentication bypass vulnerability, CVE-2024-53704, with a CVSS score of 8.2.  This vulnerability exists in the SSL VPN and SSH management features. SonicWall states that users with these features enabled are at risk of attack.  To address and mitigate this vulnerability, SonicWall recommends upgrading to the following firmware versions: – Gen 6 / 6.5 hardware firewalls: SonicOS 6.5.5.1-6n or later – Gen 6 / 6.5 NSv firewalls: SonicOS 6.5.4.v-21s-RC2457 or later – Gen 7 firewalls: SonicOS 7.0.1-5165 or later, 7.1.3-7015 and above – TZ80: SonicOS 8.0.0-8037 or later.  In addition to the firmware upgrade, SonicWall also recommends the following mitigation steps: – Restrict SSL VPN access to trusted sources only, or disable access from the internet. – For SSH management, restrict access to trusted sources only, or disable SSH management from the internet.  SonicWall emphasizes that customers should take immediate action to mitigate the risk and prevent exploitation of this vulnerability.  Instructions on disabling SSL VPN access can be found at https://www.sonicwall.com/support/knowledge-base/how-can-i-setup-ssl-vpn/170505609285133.

Nessus Scanner Agents offline due to a failed plugin update.  Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 10/67 (IT) Wednesday, January 8, 2025. Tenable, the developer of the vulnerability scanning tool "Nessus", announced the deactivation of Nessus Scanner Agent versions 10.8.0 and 10.8.1 after discovering that the "differential" plugin update caused the agent to go offline on some systems. This resulted in the company temporarily halting plugin updates to prevent the issue. The company stated that they are urgently investigating and resolving the issue. Tenable announced a remediation plan, stating: – Nessus Agent systems for Tenable Vulnerability Management (TVM), Tenable Security Center (TSC), and Nessus were downgraded from 10.8.0/10.8.1 back to 10.7. – Plugin feed updates were disabled specifically for Nessus Agent versions below 10.8 and all versions of Nessus Scanner linked to TVM. Tenable has released Nessus Agent version 10.8.2 to address this issue and recommends that users running versions 10.8.0 and 10.8.1 upgrade to version 10.8.2 or downgrade to version 10.7.3.  It is also recommended to reset the plugins if using profiles for agent upgrades or downgrades to bring the agents back online.

Nuclei vulnerability risks signature bypass and malicious code execution

Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 08/67 (IT) Tuesday, January 7, 2025.  A high-severity vulnerability (CVE-2024-43405) with a CVSS score of 7.4 has been identified in Nuclei, an open-source vulnerability scanner.  This vulnerability allows attackers to bypass signature verification and inject malicious code into templates.  The Wiz team reported that the vulnerability stems from differing newline character handling between signature verification and YAML parser data conversion, enabling attackers to insert malicious content while maintaining valid signatures in the normal section.

Nuclei supports various protocols, including HTTP, TCP, DNS, and Code, which can execute code on the operating system.  Using unsafe templates could lead to system compromise.  Wiz's report demonstrates that the "Code" protocol can be used to extract sensitive information from target systems if weaponized with malicious code.

This vulnerability affects Nuclei versions 3.0.0 and later and has been patched in version v3.3.2.  Users should verify templates before use to prevent malicious code injection.  Caution should be exercised when allowing users to modify or upload templates in shared systems to avoid the risk of attacks that could lead to unauthorized command execution, data theft, or system control.

Lumen blocked the hacker group Salt Typhoon from its network after discovering they were targeting attacks in the US and globally.  Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 04/67 (IT) on Friday, January 3, 2025, reported that Lumen successfully blocked the hacker group Salt Typhoon, linked to China, from its network.  They confirmed that no customer data was accessed or leaked.  Salt Typhoon, also known as FamousSparrow and GhostEmperor, has been active since 2019, targeting government agencies and telecommunications companies worldwide.  Recently, they infiltrated nine US telecommunications companies as part of a cyber espionage campaign.  Anne Neuberger, the White House cybersecurity advisor, revealed that the attacks focused on Americans' metadata, including communications of key figures in government and politics.  In early December 2024, it was reported that Salt Typhoon had penetrated telecommunications companies in dozens of countries. The Wall Street Journal further reported that at least eight US telecommunications companies were previously affected.  In addition to Lumen, major providers such as AT&T and Verizon confirmed they successfully strengthened network security and prevented attacks.  Meanwhile, T-Mobile stated that the hackers attempted to penetrate their systems but were unable to access sensitive data or company systems. This incident highlights the importance of cybersecurity measures in the telecommunications sector, which plays a crucial role in national security.

Iran and Russia have been sanctioned after interfering in the U.S. elections with AI and cyberattacks.  The U.S. Department of the Treasury, under the Office of Foreign Assets Control (OFAC), has sanctioned organizations in Iran and Russia that attempted to interfere in the 2024 U.S. presidential election. The Iranian organization is the "Cognitive Design and Production Center" (CDPC) under the Islamic Revolutionary Guard Corps (IRGC), which aims to incite social tensions. The Russian organization is the "Center for Geostrategic Expertise" (CGE), which works with the GRU intelligence unit and uses AI to create fake content to spread disinformation.  Investigations in 2024 indicated that Iran and Russia were involved in cyberattacks, disinformation, and deception to create divisions in American society. Meta shut down WhatsApp accounts of attackers linked to Iran, while U.S. authorities have filed criminal charges against IRGC individuals who attempted to steal information from government officials.  Russia also supported the creation of a network of websites and used fake identities to conceal its connection with the state.  The U.S. Treasury Department pointed out that these attempts reflect Russia's strategy to undermine the security of the U.S. and its allies by using cyber tools and fake news sources to cause political and social damage internationally.  The U.S. continues to implement strict measures to counter such threats.

CISA adds Acclaim Systems' USAHERDS vulnerability to the Known Exploited Vulnerabilities (KEV) catalog.  The Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) reported on Wednesday, December 25, 2024, that the U.S. Cybersecurity and Infrastructure Security Agency (CISA) has added a vulnerability in Acclaim Systems' USAHERDS system, designated CVE-2021-44207 and with a CVSS severity score of 8.1, to the KEV catalog.  This vulnerability involves the use of credentials embedded in the code, allowing attackers to execute malicious code on the system.  This vulnerability has been previously exploited by the Chinese APT41 group to attack several U.S. government networks. Affected systems are USAHERDS version 7.4.0.1 and earlier. USAHERDS is a web application developed by Acclaim Systems to assist U.S. government agencies in tracking and managing animal health, including disease outbreak control. It is part of the AgraGuard suite of products that supports agricultural operations and food safety, such as USALIMS, USAPlants, USAFoodSafety, and USAMeals.  To prevent and mitigate risks from these vulnerabilities, agencies under the U.S. Federal Civilian Executive Branch (FCEB) are required to remediate the vulnerability within a specified timeframe. CISA has mandated remediation by January 13, 2025, to prevent exploitation and address related vulnerabilities as soon as possible.

CISA adds BeyondTrust software vulnerabilities to the Known Exploited Vulnerabilities (KEV) catalog.  The Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) reported on Monday, December 23, 2024, that the U.S. Cybersecurity and Infrastructure Security Agency (CISA) has added a Command Injection vulnerability in BeyondTrust Privileged Remote Access (PRA) and Remote Support (RS) software, designated CVE-2024-12356 with a CVSS severity score of 9.8, to the KEV catalog. This vulnerability allows unauthenticated attackers to inject malicious commands and execute them as a site user.  It affects all versions of BeyondTrust PRA and RS products. However, BeyondTrust has released patches to address the vulnerability in RS and PRA versions 22.1.x and later. To mitigate and prevent risks from these vulnerabilities, agencies under the U.S. Federal Civilian Executive Branch (FCEB) are required to remediate the vulnerability within a specified timeframe. CISA has mandated completion of remediation by December 27, 2024, to prevent exploitation and address related vulnerabilities as soon as possible.

Attackers are attempting to exploit a vulnerability in Apache Struts, tracked as CVE-2024-53677.  Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 451/67 (IT) Friday, December 20, 2024. Researchers warn of an Apache Struts vulnerability where attackers are attempting to exploit CVE-2024-53677, which has a CVSS score of 9.5.  This vulnerability arises from attackers being able to modify file upload parameters to perform a Path Traversal attack, potentially leading to the upload of malicious files used for Remote Code Execution.  This vulnerability affects the following software versions: – Struts 2.0.0 to Struts 2.3.37 (EOL) – Struts 2.5.0 to Struts 2.5.33 (EOL) – Struts 6.0.0 to Struts 6.3.0.2.  Dr. Johannes Ullrich, Dean of Research at SANS Technology Institute, states that this vulnerability stems from an incomplete fix for the previous vulnerability, CVE-2023-50164. The new vulnerability is similar to the old one.  Furthermore, Proof-of-Concept (PoC) code has been published, and attackers have begun using it in real-world attacks. To mitigate the risk, users should update their software to Struts 6.4.0 or later and utilize the Action File Upload Interceptor to prevent future attacks.

CISA adds Microsoft Windows Kernel-Mode Driver and Adobe ColdFusion vulnerabilities to the (KEV) catalog.  Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 449/67 (IT) Thursday, December 19, 2024. The U.S. Cybersecurity and Infrastructure Security Agency (CISA) has added the Microsoft Windows Kernel-Mode Driver Untrusted Pointer Dereference vulnerability (CVE-2024-35250) and the Adobe ColdFusion Improper Access Control vulnerability (CVE-2024-20767) to the Known Exploited Vulnerabilities (KEV) catalog.  Details of the vulnerabilities are as follows: – CVE-2024-35250 has a CVSS score of 7.8 and is an Elevation of Privilege vulnerability in the Windows Kernel-Mode Driver.  It allows attackers who are already on the system to elevate their privileges to SYSTEM.  The attack is low complexity. – CVE-2024-20767 has a CVSS score of 7.4 and is an Improper Access Control vulnerability in Adobe ColdFusion versions 2023.6, 2021.12 and earlier. Attackers can exploit this vulnerability to read files without authorization. The attack occurs when an externally accessible Admin Panel is enabled. To mitigate and reduce the risk from these vulnerabilities, agencies under the U.S. Federal Civilian Executive Branch (FCEB) must remediate the vulnerabilities within a specified timeframe.  CISA has set a deadline of January 6, 2025, to complete remediation to prevent exploitation of these vulnerabilities.

ConnectOnCall reveals data breach affecting over 900,000 users.
Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 447/67 (IT) Wednesday, December 18, 2024. ConnectOnCall, a telehealth platform and after-hours emergency call service, has disclosed a data breach affecting the personal and medical information of over 900,000 users. The company discovered the security breach on May 12, 2024, and immediately launched an investigation, which found that an unauthorized party had accessed data in ConnectOnCall's systems between February 16 and May 12, 2024. This included communications between providers and patients. Potentially affected information includes names, phone numbers, dates of birth, social security numbers, medical record numbers, and health information such as medical conditions, treatments, and prescriptions.  ConnectOnCall has hired cybersecurity experts, taken the system offline, and begun restoring the system, while also notifying law enforcement. Although there are no reports of misuse of the data or harm to patients, the company recommends that those potentially affected exercise caution and report any suspicious activity related to identity theft to their health insurance company or financial institution. ConnectOnCall notified potentially affected users on December 11, 2024, and is offering free credit monitoring and identity theft protection services through Kroll for those whose social security numbers were affected.

CISA adds Microsoft Windows CLFS Driver vulnerability to its catalog (KEV).  Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 441/67 (IT) Thursday, December 12, 2024. The U.S. Cybersecurity and Infrastructure Security Agency (CISA) has added a vulnerability in the Microsoft Windows Common Log File System (CLFS), designated CVE-2024-49138 with a CVSS score of 7.8, to its Known Exploited Vulnerabilities (KEV) catalog. This vulnerability was addressed in Microsoft's December 2024 Patch Tuesday security updates, which covered a total of 71 vulnerabilities and included the actively exploited CVE-2024-49138. Although Microsoft has not disclosed details about attacks exploiting this vulnerability, experts warn that attackers could use it to elevate privileges to SYSTEM. To mitigate and reduce the risk from these vulnerabilities, agencies under the U.S. Federal Civilian Executive Branch (FCEB) are required to patch vulnerabilities within specified timeframes. CISA mandates that government agencies patch this vulnerability by December 31, 2024, to prevent its exploitation.

Romania faces over 85,000 cyberattacks against election systems.
Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 437/67 (IT) Monday, December 9, 2024.  Romania's Intelligence Service revealed that the country's election systems were subjected to over 85,000 cyberattacks. Attackers gained access to election-related website data and disseminated it on Russian cybercrime forums before the presidential election. Intelligence agencies suggest these attacks may be linked to user account breaches or exploitation of training server vulnerabilities.  Heavy attacks occurred on election day and the night after, December 6, 2024.  Romania's Constitutional Court annulled the entire election process due to a lack of transparency and interference, ordering the government to set a new election date and develop an action plan to restart the electoral process from scratch.  Meanwhile, the pro-Russian candidate, Calin Georgescu, was heavily promoted on TikTok via coordinated accounts and paid advertising, leading to his questionable victory.  Romania's Foreign Intelligence Service (SIE) believes Russia employed tactics to interfere in Eastern European elections, viewing Romania as an "enemy" due to its support for NATO and Ukraine. This interference includes disinformation campaigns, propaganda, and backing anti-EU agendas.  Intelligence agencies warn that Romania's electoral systems remain vulnerable and at risk of future attacks.

Cisco warns of CVE-2014-2120 vulnerability in ASA being exploited.

Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 435/67 (IT) Friday, December 6, 2024. Cisco is warning customers about a vulnerability in Cisco Adaptive Security Appliance (ASA) software discovered ten years ago, CVE-2014-2120, which is currently being widely exploited.  The vulnerability resides in the WebVPN login page of the ASA software, allowing unauthenticated attackers to perform Cross-Site Scripting (XSS) attacks against WebVPN users on Cisco ASA devices. This vulnerability is due to insufficient input validation, allowing attackers to exploit it by tricking users into accessing malicious links.  In November 2024, the Cisco PSIRT (Product Security Incident Response Team) discovered new attempts to exploit this vulnerability in Cisco systems and recommends users update their software to a patched version as soon as possible to mitigate the risk of attack.  In addition, CISA in the United States has added this vulnerability to the Known Exploited Vulnerabilities (KEV) Catalog.  Cisco emphasizes that customers should review the updated security advisories and take corrective action as soon as possible to prevent attacks from this vulnerability, which continues to be actively exploited by hackers.

Two UK hospitals hit by cyberattacks. Alder Hey Children's Hospital in the UK has revealed that its systems were attacked, with patient data and other sensitive information stolen and published online.  The ransomware group Inc Ransom claimed to have obtained data between 2018 and 2024. The hospital confirmed it is increasing security measures and that the incident has not affected current services. Meanwhile, Wirral University Teaching Hospital had to shut down its IT systems and revert to paper records after suspicious activity was detected. The incident caused some services, such as appointments and surgeries, to be postponed. While emergency services remain available, patients may experience longer wait times in the emergency department.  Although there is no confirmation that the Wirral incident is ransomware-related, system shutdowns are a common response to such events. Both hospitals are working with relevant authorities to resolve the issues and assess the impact on potentially compromised data.

Hackers stole millions of dollars from Uganda's central bank.
Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 429/67 (IT) Monday, December 2, 2024. The Ugandan government confirmed on Thursday that the country's central bank was hit by a cyberattack by financially motivated threat actors, resulting in a significant loss of funds. The attack is under investigation by the Criminal Investigations Directorate (CID) of the police and the Office of the Auditor General (OAG).  Henry Musasizi, the junior finance minister, revealed in parliament that some central bank accounts were hacked. However, the losses might not be as severe as reported in some media outlets. He added that the bank has undertaken a thorough account reconciliation and investigation into the incident. The Bank of Uganda indicated that the attack involved a threat actor group called “Waste,” believed to be operating from Southeast Asia. The group moved 62 billion Ugandan shillings (approximately $16.8 million) to foreign accounts in early November. According to local media reports, some of the money was transferred to accounts in Japan and the United Kingdom. Authorities in the UK were able to seize more than $7 million, although some had already been withdrawn. In Japan, the attackers reportedly received about $6 million. The central bank has managed to recover some of the funds. The investigation is ongoing to identify those involved and to implement preventive measures for the future.

Critical Vulnerability in WordPress Anti-Spam Plugin Allows Remote Attacks

Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 425/67 (IT) Thursday, November 28, 2024: Two critical vulnerabilities affecting WordPress's Spam protection, Anti-Spam, and FireWall could allow unauthenticated attackers to install and activate malicious plugins on vulnerable websites and achieve remote code execution. The vulnerabilities, CVE-2024-10542 and CVE-2024-10781, have a CVSS severity score of 9.8. Both vulnerabilities have been patched in versions 6.44 and 6.45, released this month.  The CleanTalk plugin is installed on over 200,000 WordPress websites and blocks spam from comments and forms. However, if attackers can install plugins, it could lead to remote attacks, especially if those plugins have unpatched vulnerabilities. Updating plugins and the WordPress system is crucial for mitigating this risk.  Additionally, Sucuri has warned of multiple attack campaigns using compromised WordPress websites to redirect users to phishing sites, steal data, install malware, or run PHP code on the server, further increasing system risk. Administrators should reinforce security and regularly monitor their systems to minimize the chances of being attacked.

CISA adds Array Networks AG and vxAG ArrayOS vulnerability to the Known Exploited Vulnerabilities (KEV) catalog.  The Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) reported on Wednesday, November 27, 2024, that the U.S. Cybersecurity and Infrastructure Security Agency (CISA) has added vulnerability CVE-2023-28461, with a CVSS score of 9.8, affecting Array Networks AG Series and vxAG ArrayOS (version 9.4.0.481 and earlier) to the KEV catalog.  This vulnerability allows attackers to exploit the SSL VPN Gateway via unauthenticated file system access by sending an HTTP request containing a flags attribute in the header and using a vulnerable URL. Attackers can achieve remote code execution and gain control of the system.  To mitigate and reduce the risk from these vulnerabilities, agencies under the Federal Civilian Executive Branch (FCEB) are required to remediate the vulnerability within a specified timeframe. CISA requires government agencies to fix this vulnerability by December 16, 2024, to prevent exploitation.

The US has seized the PopeyeTools credit card marketplace and charged its administrators.  Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 421/67 (IT) Tuesday, November 26, 2024.  The US Department of Justice (DoJ) has seized the PopeyeTools website, a dark web marketplace for selling stolen credit card information, and charged three administrators: Abdul Ghaffar, Abdul Sami, and Javed Mirza.  They are charged with access device fraud and trafficking in information related to cybercrimes such as financial data theft and ransomware attacks. PopeyeTools has been operating on the dark web since 2016, specializing in the sale of credit card, debit card, and personally identifiable information (PII) for use in fraudulent activities and other cybercrimes.  Data for at least 227,000 individuals was offered for sale, generating over $1.7 million in revenue.  Authorities also seized $283,000 in cryptocurrency from accounts linked to Sami, as well as seizing the website domain names www.PopeyeTools[.]co.uk and www.PopeyeTools[.]to, which were used to access the platform. This action is part of the US Department of Justice’s strategy to combat cybercrime by seizing websites and assets derived from illegal activities. If convicted, the defendants face a maximum penalty of 10 years in prison per count.

IGT, a global gambling technology company, faces a cyberattack, impacting some IT systems.

Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 419/67 (IT) Monday, November 25, 2024. International Game Technology PLC (IGT), a global gambling technology company, faced a cyberattack on November 17, 2024, that caused some of the company's IT systems to shut down. IGT immediately responded to the incident, and according to a document filed with the U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC), the company detected that unauthorized outsiders had accessed the organization's IT systems, causing some internal systems and applications to be disrupted. To prevent further damage, IGT shut down the affected systems and launched an investigation into the incident with the assistance of an external consulting team. Although the company has not yet disclosed the details of the attack, based on the nature of the response, it is expected that this incident may be a ransomware attack. Currently, the investigation and system restoration are ongoing to assess the damage and enhance system security.

Oracle warns of vulnerability in Agile PLM Framework being actively exploited.

Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 416/67 (IT) Friday, November 22, 2024 Oracle issued a warning to users about a serious security vulnerability found in Agile Product Lifecycle Management (PLM) Framework, number CVE-2024-21287 and a severity score (CVSS 7.5). This vulnerability can be exploited remotely without authentication, allowing malicious actors to access sensitive information.  This vulnerability allows unauthenticated attackers to access the target system without requiring a username or password. Oracle explains in the advisory that "Successful exploitation of this vulnerability could allow an attacker to download files accessible under the PLM application’s privileges from the target system." Such an attack could lead to the exfiltration of files containing sensitive information without the target system being aware of the intrusion.  Security researchers from CrowdStrike, Joel Snape and Lutz Wolf, discovered and reported the vulnerability.  Oracle has made efforts to address this issue promptly.  However, it is currently unclear what the target of such attacks is or how widespread they are.  Administrators are advised to check the software version they are using and immediately install patches or update the system as soon as possible. Doing so will reduce the risk of being attacked and protect important data in the system from malicious actors.

Helldown ransomware attacks Linux systems and VMware servers, causing significant damage. Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 414/67 (IT) Thursday, November 21, 2024. The Helldown ransomware group is a new threat in the cyber world, targeting Linux systems and VMware ESXi used in organizations across multiple sectors.  Recent attacks reveal that the group exploits vulnerabilities in Zyxel firewall devices to gain access to victim systems. Sekoia reports that Helldown ransomware may be exploiting an undisclosed vulnerability in Zyxel firewalls. Although Zyxel has released patches, there is no clear information about the vulnerability used by the attackers. Helldown exhibits sophisticated attack behavior and focuses on stealing large amounts of data from victims, such as important documents and personal information, which are used as leverage for ransom demands. Since August, Helldown ransomware has attacked 31 victims, mostly in the United States and organizations in various sectors. Helldown also attempts to cover its tracks, such as deleting tools used and overwriting data on hard drives, to hinder the victim's data recovery process. Experts recommend that system administrators regularly update security patches, monitor unusual behavior, and treat virtual systems with the same caution as regular systems, as Helldown is a new threat that is having a severe impact across multiple sectors.

Botnet Exploits Zero-day Vulnerability in EoL GeoVision Devices

Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 411/67 (IT) Tuesday, November 19, 2024.  Researchers from the Shadowserver Foundation have discovered a botnet exploiting a zero-day vulnerability in end-of-life (EoL) GeoVision devices to attack and control devices that are still in use.  The vulnerability, tracked as CVE-2024-11120, has a CVSS score of 9.8 and is a pre-auth command injection vulnerability. It was discovered by the Shadowserver Foundation and confirmed with the assistance of TWCERT (Taiwan Computer Emergency Response Team). The vulnerability affects the following GeoVision products:

- GV-VS12
- GV-VS11
- GV-DSP_LPR_V3
- GVLX 4 V2
- GVLX 4 V3

According to Shadowserver Foundation data, approximately 17,000 GeoVision devices are connected to the internet and vulnerable to attacks exploiting CVE-2024-11120. The most vulnerable devices are located in the United States (9,179), followed by Germany (1,652), Taiwan (792), and Canada (784), indicating a significant risk for users of these devices.

Researchers recommend that users of EoL GeoVision devices should check and consider replacing them with newer models to prevent attacks.  Additionally, external access for devices still in use should be disabled to mitigate the risk of being hacked.

Amazon disclosed an employee data breach following the MOVEit attacks in May 2023.  Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 403/67 (IT) on Wednesday, November 13, 2024, reported that Amazon revealed the data breach which exposed employee information.  The data was stolen from a third-party service provider partnered with the company. Amazon did not specify the number of affected employees.  The threat actor group "Nam3L3ss" published over 2.8 million records on BreachForums.  The exposed data included names, phone numbers, work emails, and building locations.  Social security numbers or financial information were not exposed.  An Amazon spokesperson confirmed that Amazon and AWS systems remained secure, with no direct attacks on company systems.  The stolen data was limited to employee contact information.  Amazon has addressed the vulnerability that led to the attack to prevent future incidents.  Hudson Rock's analysis found that Nam3L3ss claimed to have data from 25 other large organizations. Although MOVEit was previously used in attacks by the CL0P Ransomware group, it is unconfirmed whether this breach is related to CL0P or another hacker group.

Researchers discovered a new ransomware called 'Ymir' that encrypts systems previously attacked by the RustyStealer malware.  Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 402/67 (IT) Wednesday, November 13, 2024. Kaspersky researchers discovered a new type of ransomware called Ymir being used in attacks alongside the RustyStealer malware, a data-stealing program that infiltrates victim systems before deploying the ransomware.  Ymir attacks networks containing sensitive information, with RustyStealer utilizing techniques to collect credentials and gain system access through privileged accounts. Once installed, Ymir encrypts system files and creates a ransom note in a PDF file to coerce payment.  It also modifies Windows settings to display warning messages on the login screen to further pressure victims into complying with the hackers' demands.  Ymir ransomware operates stealthily by running in memory and uses ChaCha20 encryption, an advanced encryption algorithm, to encrypt data, making decryption difficult.  The malware also scans the system for signs of PowerShell and deletes itself to avoid detection in its final stages. Currently, no data leak site associated with Ymir has been found, suggesting that the attackers may be in the early stages of victim data collection.  If this ransomware evolves to include data exfiltration capabilities, it could become an even more dangerous threat.

Palo Alto Networks Warns of Remote Code Execution (RCE) Vulnerability

Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 401/67 (IT) Tuesday, November 12, 2024. Palo Alto Networks issued a warning urging customers to immediately check the security settings of their PAN-OS management interface after the discovery of a Remote Code Execution (RCE) vulnerability that could be exploited. Although the source of this allegation is currently unclear, the company is closely monitoring the situation.  Currently, there is no evidence of actual zero-day attacks. The company states that even without clear information about the vulnerability or Indicators of Compromise (IoCs), securing the management interface from internet access will significantly reduce risk.  They recommend configuring access only from trusted internal IPs. The company's Prisma Access and cloud NGFW solutions are not affected by this issue. Recently, CISA added a vulnerability in the Palo Alto Networks Expedition tool, designated CVE-2024-5910, to the Known Exploited Vulnerabilities Catalog.  This vulnerability was patched in July, and although technical details were released in October, there is no indication of active exploitation at this time.

Newpark Resources, a Texas oil supplier, hit by Ransomware.  Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 399/67 (IT) Monday, November 11, 2024. On October 29, 2024, Newpark Resources, a major US oil industry supplier, was affected by a ransomware attack that resulted in temporary inaccessibility to some information systems and business applications. After detecting the incident, the company immediately implemented its cyber threat response plan and began investigating the incident with external experts to control the damage. According to the FORM 8-K filed with the US Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC), the company disclosed that the attackers were able to gain partial access to the company's internal systems, causing problems with the systems and applications that support operations and financial reporting.  However, production and operations continue as normal.  Currently, Newpark Resources is assessing the damage and costs from the attack, but expects that it will not significantly impact its financial position and operations. The company will disclose further information as the situation progresses, and so far no details have been released about the type of malware or the group claiming responsibility for this incident.

Canada orders TikTok to shut down operations in Canada due to security concerns.

Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 396/67 (IT) for Friday, November 8, 2024.  The Canadian government has ordered TikTok, owned by ByteDance in China, to cease operations in the country.  The decision is stated to be the result of a national security risk assessment.  The review was conducted by Canada’s security and intelligence community. The government emphasized that it will not restrict access to TikTok for the general Canadian public, but advised citizens to assess the potential risks of using the social media app.  François-Philippe Champagne, Canada’s Minister of Innovation, Science and Industry, stated that the government wants citizens to be aware of the risks of using social media platforms, particularly in terms of data management and security related to foreign countries. TikTok has been banned on government devices since February 2023.  TikTok responded that closing the office in Canada will result in hundreds of employees being laid off.  The company intends to challenge this order in court.  In a statement, ByteDance confirmed that no user data will be shared with the Chinese government. However, concerns remain that TikTok may be forced to hand over user data. This has resulted in the U.S. enacting a law requiring ByteDance to sell TikTok by January 2025 or face a ban in the country. Currently, TikTok is completely banned in several countries, including Afghanistan, India, Nepal, and Pakistan, and is prohibited on government-issued devices in many countries around the world.

CVE-2024-43093 vulnerability in Android is being actively exploited.

Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 395/67 (IT) Thursday, November 7, 2024. Google has warned about the CVE-2024-43093 vulnerability in the Android operating system that is being actively exploited by threat actors. This vulnerability is related to privilege escalation in the Android Framework component. If successfully exploited, it could lead to unauthorized access to critical system folders, such as "Android/data," "Android/obb," and "Android/sandbox."  Although Google has not yet disclosed the details of this exploit, the company further stated that there is another vulnerability, CVE-2024-43047, that is also being actively exploited.

The CVE-2024-43047 vulnerability resides in the Qualcomm component of the Android system. It is a Use-After-Free (UAF) vulnerability that could cause memory corruption due to the way the Digital Signal Processor (DSP) handles Direct Memory Access (DMA) File Descriptors in the Header Buffer.  Google reports that both vulnerabilities are being actively exploited in targeted attacks.

In September, Google also patched a high-severity vulnerability, CVE-2024-32896 (CVSS score: 7.8), which is a privilege escalation vulnerability in the Android Framework. This vulnerability could be exploited due to a logic error in the code, allowing attackers to escalate privileges without requiring permissions.

Vulnerability in Okta Verify Agent Windows Allows Attackers to Steal User Passwords

Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 393/67 (IT) Wednesday, November 6, 2024. Okta, a leading technology company in Identity and Access Management (IAM), has fixed a critical vulnerability in Okta Verify for Windows. This vulnerability could allow attackers to steal user passwords. The vulnerability was discovered during the company's regular penetration testing.  The vulnerability affects Okta Verify Agent for Windows versions 5.0.2 through 5.3.2 and is identified as CVE-2024-9191. It is related to the Okta Device Access feature. This vulnerability allows attackers with access to a compromised device to retrieve passwords associated with users' passwordless logins via the OktaDeviceAccessPipe. However, the vulnerability only affects users utilizing the passwordless Okta Device Access feature. Users using Okta Verify on other platforms or only the FastPass feature are not affected. Okta has addressed this vulnerability in version 5.3.3 of the Verify Agent for Windows and recommends that affected customers update to the latest version as soon as possible to mitigate the risk. The vulnerability was initially discovered on April 17, 2024, in version 5.0.2, and Okta released an Early Access version with a fix on September 20, 2024, before the general release on October 25, 2024.

LastPass warns of fake phone numbers trying to steal customer data.

Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 388/67 (IT) Monday, November 4, 2024. LastPass has warned users about an ongoing phishing campaign.  Attackers have been writing 5-star reviews for the LastPass Chrome extension, including a phone number claiming to be customer support. This number directs users experiencing issues to scammers who instruct them to visit the website ‘dghelp[.]top’ to download a remote control program.  Users who call the fake number are greeted by someone impersonating an "official" who asks about the issue. Then, they direct the user to the website to trick them into downloading remote access software. This software is installed via ScreenConnect and connects to a control server in Ukraine. LastPass emphasizes that users should never share their passwords with anyone.
