Researchers state that this fake number is being promoted as a support or customer service line for several other companies such as Amazon, Adobe, Facebook, Netflix, and Capital One. These numbers are being posted in Chrome extension reviews and on user-generated content sites such as company forums and Reddit. Although some posts have been removed, new ones continually appear. Therefore, LastPass users should be cautious and only use support numbers from the official website.

Interbank confirms data breach following failed extortion, customer data leaked online. Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 387/67 (IT) Friday, November 1, 2024. Interbank, one of Peru's leading banks, has confirmed a major data breach after hackers compromised its systems and published customer data online. The bank says data from over 2 million customers was affected and that it has increased security measures to protect customer data and transactions. Meanwhile, several customers reported that the bank's application and online platforms were unavailable both during the incident and two weeks prior.  However, Interbank confirms that most systems are now back online and emphasizes the security of customer deposits and financial transactions. According to Dark Web Informer, a hacker using the alias "kzoldyck" posted customer data for sale on a forum, claiming to have information on more than 3 million customers, including full names, account numbers, birthdays, addresses, emails, and credit card information, along with customer transaction data. Sensitive information such as usernames and passwords used to access banking systems was also partially disclosed. The hacker revealed that ransom negotiations with Interbank took place two weeks ago but failed because the bank refused to pay. As of now, Interbank has not provided further details about the breach.

QNAP has patched a critical zero-day vulnerability exploited in the Pwn2Own competition. Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 384/67 (IT) Thursday, October 31, 2024.  QNAP has released a patch for a critical security vulnerability, CVE-2024-50388, found in the company's TS-464 NAS devices. This zero-day vulnerability was exploited by hackers through the HBS 3 Hybrid Backup Sync feature, which operates within the backup system. The vulnerability allows for remote command execution if the software is not updated to the latest version. This vulnerability was revealed at Pwn2Own Ireland 2024 by the Viettel Cyber Security team from Vietnam. They successfully compromised the NAS system and gained administrator privileges, leading to the vulnerability being patched within five days of disclosure.  Users of TS-464 NAS devices should update HBS 3 Hybrid Backup Sync to version 25.1.1.673 or later.  This can be done through the QTS or QuTS hero system as an administrator.  QNAP has often been a target of ransomware groups because NAS devices store personal and important data that is vulnerable to attack. QNAP has previously warned users about ransomware attacks, such as eCh0raix and AgeLocker, which occurred in 2020 and 2021. Attackers exploited vulnerabilities in various apps like Photo Station and Multimedia Console. However, QNAP continues to release updates to address these vulnerabilities.

French telecom provider Free suffered a cyberattack impacting customer personal data.

Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 383/67 (IT) Wednesday, October 30, 2024. Free, the second-largest internet service provider (ISP) in France, confirmed it suffered a cyberattack and unauthorized access to customer personal data.  Free, a subsidiary of Iliad S.A., has over 22.9 million mobile and internet users in France. The incident occurred last week. Attackers were found attempting to sell the stolen data in cybercrime forums. Free stated that the attackers gained access to internal management tools but not passwords, bank card details, or communication data such as emails and voicemails. Free has notified French regulatory authorities CNIL and ANSSI of the incident for awareness and investigation.  The attackers offered two databases for sale containing information on 19.2 million customers and 5.11 million IBANs.  They released sample data and screenshots of the stolen information to prove its validity. Exposed information includes full names, phone numbers, addresses, and birth dates.  Customers of Free Mobile and Freebox may be affected since October 17, 2024. Free has implemented preventive measures and increased system security.  This incident follows a similar data breach at SFR.

Four members of the Revil Ransomware group have been sentenced to prison for hacking and money laundering.

Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 381/67 (IT) Tuesday, October 29, 2024. A Russian court sentenced four members of the REvil Ransomware group for hacking and money laundering. The Saint Petersburg Military Court announced the verdict on October 25, 2024, sentencing four REvil members: Artem Zaets, Alexei Malozemov, Daniil Puzyrevsky, and Ruslan Khansvyarov for illegal circulation of payments.  Puzyrevsky and Khansvyarov were also charged with the use and distribution of malicious programs.  The sentences are 4.5 years and 5 years for Zaets and Malozemov respectively, while Puzyrevsky and Khansvyarov were sentenced to 5.5 years and 6 years in a general regime penal colony.  This case is a rare instance of Russian authorities prosecuting domestic cybercriminals. The investigation stemmed from a US request linking the REvil group to cyberattacks against foreign technology companies. The investigation identified 14 suspects, with 8 prosecuted and 4 still under consideration. In addition, in May 2024, Ukrainian REvil member Yaroslav Vasinskyi was sentenced to more than 13 years in prison in the US for ransomware attacks on more than 2,500 victims and ordered to pay more than 16 million US dollars.

Chinese-linked hackers have attempted to compromise phones used by Donald Trump and JD Vance.  The Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 379/67 (IT) reported on Monday, October 28, 2024, citing the New York Times, that a group of hackers linked to China attempted to infiltrate the phones used by former President Donald Trump and Senator JD Vance, a potential vice-presidential candidate in the next US presidential election.  The attacks are part of a cyber espionage campaign aimed at gathering information about US leaders. US intelligence agencies are investigating what communications the hackers may have intercepted.  Unnamed sources indicated the hacking group's infiltration was sophisticated, successfully breaching telecommunications systems. The information obtained from Trump and Vance's phones is considered a valuable source of intelligence for foreign entities, particularly in the lead-up to the presidential election. Sources close to the matter informed CNN that the APT group "Salt Typhoon" also targeted individuals within the Harris-Walz campaign team and senior Biden administration officials.  The group also demonstrated advanced skills in penetrating communications systems and internet networks of major companies like AT&T, Verizon, and Lume. Once US security agencies identified the attacks, agencies like the FBI and CISA immediately alerted and provided technical assistance to the affected telecommunications companies, and shared information with other companies to prevent future attacks. The House and Senate Intelligence Committees have been briefed on the intrusions and are closely monitoring the situation.  The Chinese government continues to deny accusations of involvement in the cyberattacks.

CISA adds Microsoft SharePoint vulnerability to the Known Exploited Vulnerabilities (KEV) catalog.  The Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 377/67 (IT) for Friday, October 25, 2024, reports that the U.S. Cybersecurity and Infrastructure Security Agency (CISA) has added the Microsoft SharePoint Deserialization vulnerability, CVE-2024-38094, with a CVSS score of 7.2, to the KEV catalog. This vulnerability allows attackers with Site Owner privileges to inject and execute arbitrary code on a SharePoint Server. CVE-2024-38094 is caused by an input validation error in the search component of SharePoint Server, which allows unauthenticated users to exploit this vulnerability by sending crafted HTTP requests to a vulnerable SharePoint Server. This could allow attackers to execute arbitrary code on the server and gain access to the system.  To mitigate and reduce the risk from this vulnerability, agencies under the Federal Civilian Executive Branch (FCEB) must remediate the vulnerability within a specified timeframe. CISA requires government agencies to patch this vulnerability by November 12, 2024, to prevent exploitation.

Fortinet Zero-Day vulnerability "FortiJump" exploited since June 2024

Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 376/67 (IT) Friday, October 25, 2024.  A newly disclosed Zero-Day vulnerability in Fortinet products, known as "FortiJump" (CVE-2024-47575), has been exploited by malicious actors since June 2024, according to a report from Google Cloud's Mandiant. This vulnerability affects FortiManager, a product used for centrally managing Fortinet devices such as FortiGate firewalls. Fortinet recently began notifying customers about this vulnerability and released a patch to address the issue. However, Mandiant reports that more than 50 organizations worldwide have been targeted through this vulnerability, and attacks are ongoing, particularly through Managed Service Providers (MSPs).  Researcher Kevin Beaumont, who named the vulnerability "FortiJump," believes these attacks may originate from a state-sponsored group with cyber espionage objectives. The vulnerability allows threat actors to steal sensitive information and use it to further penetrate FortiManager systems. Although Fortinet has not yet found evidence of malware installation or database modification in the compromised FortiManager systems, such Zero-Day attacks remain a widespread concern. Both Fortinet and Mandiant have published Indicators of Compromise (IoCs) so that organizations can defend against potential attacks.

CISA adds ScienceLogic SL1 vulnerability to its Known Exploited Vulnerabilities (KEV) catalog.  The Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) reported on Thursday, October 24, 2024, that the U.S. Cybersecurity and Infrastructure Security Agency (CISA) has added a vulnerability in the ScienceLogic SL1 system, identified as CVE-2024-9537 with a CVSS score of 9.3, to the KEV catalog. This vulnerability stems from a third-party component within ScienceLogic SL1 and has been addressed in versions 12.1.3+, 12.2.3+, and 12.3+.  Patches have also been released for older versions dating back to 10.1.x.  On September 24, 2024, cloud hosting provider Rackspace reported issues with the ScienceLogic EM7 tool, an older version of SL1. Attackers exploited a zero-day vulnerability in third-party software bundled with the ScienceLogic application.  This breach exposed sensitive information, including usernames, account details, and encrypted credentials.  Patches have been issued to address this issue, and the company has notified affected customers. To mitigate risk, Federal Civilian Executive Branch (FCEB) agencies are required to remediate this vulnerability by a specified deadline. CISA mandates that government agencies patch this vulnerability by November 11, 2024, to prevent exploitation.

Internet Archive Suffers Repeated Attack During System Recovery

Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 373/67 (IT) Tuesday, October 22, 2024: The Internet Archive, a non-profit digital library, has been hit by another cyberattack during its recovery from a previous attack. This resulted in the exposure of user data for over 31 million users, including usernames, email addresses, and hashed passwords.  The attack also involved DDoS attacks and website defacement, causing most services, including the Wayback Machine, which archives billions of web pages, to be temporarily suspended.

Brewster Kahle, founder of the Internet Archive, revealed on Friday that some services, such as the Wayback Machine and Archive-It, are now back online and other services will be available soon. He confirmed that the archived data remains safe and that system restoration will be done carefully to strengthen cybersecurity defenses.

However, over the weekend, it was found that some users received additional security incident notification emails related to the Zendesk system used for customer service.  It was stated that the Internet Archive has not yet changed the exposed API key despite being aware of the issue for two weeks. Currently, the Internet Archive does not know who is behind the attacks. The BlackMeta group has claimed responsibility for the DDoS attack, but the system hacking appears to be the work of another, as yet unidentified, group.

Researchers discovered serious security flaws in major E2EE cloud storage providers.  Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 372/67 (IT) Tuesday, October 22, 2024. Researchers from ETH Zurich discovered serious encryption problems in cloud storage platforms using end-to-end encryption (E2EE), which could lead to the leakage of sensitive user data.  This report indicates that 5 major providers, such as Sync, pCloud, Icedrive, Seafile, and Tresorit, all have vulnerabilities found in their cloud storage processes. Researchers Jonas Hofmann and Kien Tuong Truong explained that "malicious servers could be used to interfere with or modify file data, including accessing user data in plain text."  The vulnerabilities found involve various attack methods such as file insertion, metadata modification, and authentication bypass, impacting the confidentiality and security of user data. Furthermore, these attacks do not require advanced cryptographic skills, making them easy to execute even by attackers with limited resources.  Sync, pCloud, Seafile, and Tresorit have acknowledged the report and are working on fixes. Icedrive, however, has chosen not to take action, despite the disclosure in late April 2024.  This discovery highlights the importance of auditing and improving encryption systems in cloud platforms to prevent future cyberattacks from malicious actors.

Hackers exploit Roundcube Webmail XSS vulnerability to steal login credentials.

Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 370/67 (IT) Monday, October 21, 2024. Cybersecurity firm Positive Technologies has revealed phishing attacks attempting to exploit a vulnerability in the open-source webmail software Roundcube. Although Roundcube is not the most popular software, many government agencies still use it, making it a prime target for hackers. The attack begins with an email that appears to have no content, but contains hidden JavaScript code that allows hackers to access sensitive information. It exploits the vulnerability CVE-2024-37383, a Cross-site Scripting (XSS) security issue. Attackers can trick victims into opening a specially crafted email, causing JavaScript code to run that can access sensitive information such as usernames and passwords. This information is then sent to a server controlled by the hackers, hosted on Cloudflare. Currently, it is not clear who is behind the attacks, but Positive Technologies points out that hacker groups APT28, Winter Vivern, and TAG-70 have previously used similar vulnerabilities in Roundcube. This incident highlights the importance of keeping software up-to-date, as vulnerabilities discovered and patched as early as May 2024 can still easily lead to valuable data theft if not updated.

VMware fixes high-severity SQL injection vulnerability CVE-2024-38814 in HCX.  Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 369/67 (IT) Friday, October 18, 2024. VMware released an update to fix a high-severity vulnerability in HCX that allows non-administrative users to remotely execute code on HCX. The vulnerability, identified as CVE-2024-38814 (CVSS score 8.8), was found in the HCX platform for application and data migration. This SQL injection vulnerability allows an authenticated, but non-administrative, attacker to use specially crafted SQL commands to attack and execute unauthorized remote code on the HCX manager.  The vulnerability was reported to VMware by Sina Kheirkhah from the Summoning Team via the Trend Micro Zero Day Initiative (ZDI). VMware has issued a warning and recommends updating the product to address this vulnerability. VMware HCX, or Hybrid Cloud Extension, is a platform that facilitates seamless data migration, load balancing, and workload operations between data centers and clouds without system downtime.  The vulnerability affects several versions of HCX, including versions 4.8.x, 4.9.x, and 4.10.x. VMware has addressed the issue in versions 4.8.3, 4.9.2, and 4.10.1.

The Russian-linked APT29 group is targeting Zimbra and JetBrains TeamCity servers.

Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 363/67 (IT) Tuesday, October 15, 2024. US and UK cyber agencies have warned that the Russian-linked APT29 group is attacking vulnerable Zimbra and JetBrains TeamCity servers.  APT29, also known as SVR group, BlueBravo, Cozy Bear, Nobelium, Midnight Blizzard, and The Dukes, is a hacking group operated by the Russian Foreign Intelligence Service (SVR). US agencies, including the Federal Bureau of Investigation (FBI), the National Security Agency (NSA), the Cyber National Mission Force (CNMF), and the UK’s National Cyber Security Centre (NCSC-UK) issued a joint advisory to warn about techniques and procedures used by the Russian hacking group in recent cyberattacks. Since April 2021, they have exploited various vulnerabilities, including the Zimbra vulnerability CVE-2022-27924 for command injection to access credentials and emails, and the JetBrains TeamCity vulnerability CVE-2023-42793, an unauthenticated arbitrary code execution via authentication bypass.  These attacks target organizations worldwide to gain access to sensitive data and establish infrastructure for long-term data collection.  The agencies also warned that APT29 has the capability and intent to exploit newly disclosed vulnerabilities for data access, remote code execution, and privilege escalation. They recommend that organizations immediately patch publicly disclosed vulnerabilities to prevent future attacks.

Mozilla warns users to update Firefox after a serious security vulnerability is exploited.

Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 360/67 (IT) Friday, October 11, 2024. Mozilla revealed that Firefox and Firefox Extended Support Release (ESR) are facing attacks exploiting a critical security vulnerability, CVE-2024-9680. This flaw exists in the browser's timeline animation component.  This vulnerability allows attackers to execute malicious code within the browser's content process.  Damien Schaeffer, a security researcher at ESET, discovered and reported the vulnerability. The issue has been fixed in Firefox version 131.0.2, Firefox ESR 128.3.1, and Firefox ESR 115.16.1. Although there is currently no clear information on how malicious actors are exploiting this vulnerability, Mozilla warns that attackers could weaponize the flaw in various attack forms such as Watering Hole attacks or deceptive downloads.  Therefore, Mozilla recommends that users update Firefox to the latest version as soon as possible to prevent attacks exploiting this vulnerability.

Adobe releases patches to fix critical vulnerabilities in Commerce and Magento.

Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 359/67 (IT) Thursday, October 10, 2024.  Adobe has released urgent patches to address security vulnerabilities in several products and warns of the risk of code execution attacks on Windows and macOS platforms.  This Patch Tuesday update covers Adobe Commerce and Magento Open Source, products frequently targeted by hackers.  Adobe's report identifies 25 vulnerabilities in Adobe Commerce that could lead to code execution, privilege escalation, and security feature bypass. Two vulnerabilities have a severity rating of 9.8/10 according to the CVSS score, affecting Adobe Commerce versions 2.4.7-p2 and earlier, as well as Magento Open Source 2.4.7-p2 and earlier.  Adobe also found security issues in other products such as Adobe Lightroom, Adobe InCopy, Adobe InDesign, Adobe Substance 3D Stager, and Adobe FrameMaker, but there are no reports of these vulnerabilities being exploited in the wild.

American Water faces cyberattack, temporarily shuts down some systems. Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 358/67 (IT) Thursday, October 10, 2024. American Water, the largest water and wastewater utility company in the U.S., has decided to temporarily shut down some of its systems after discovering a cyberattack on October 2, 2024. Although this attack did not affect water and wastewater operations, the company temporarily shut down its MyWater portal service, and customer service centers will have limited functionality. American Water, which provides water and wastewater services to approximately 14 million customers in 14 U.S. states, confirmed in a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC) that it has followed security protocols by engaging external security experts and immediately notifying law enforcement officials to investigate and control the situation.  The company stated that the shutdown of the MyWater portal aims to protect customer data, promising that there will be no late fees or service shutdowns at this time. It also confirmed that drinking water remains safe for consumption. This incident occurs amid a wave of cyberattacks targeting companies in the U.S. national infrastructure sector, particularly water and wastewater systems, which are key targets for hackers.

Indiana man pleads guilty to stealing over $37 million in cryptocurrency.  Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 355/67 (IT) Tuesday, October 8, 2024. Evan Frederick Light, 21, of Lebanon, Indiana, pleaded guilty to conspiracy to commit wire fraud and conspiracy to commit money laundering. In February 2022, he participated in a cyberattack against an investment firm in Sioux Falls, South Dakota, stealing over $37 million in cryptocurrency from 571 victims. Light used customer credentials to access the company's servers and retrieve personally identifiable information (PII) of other customers, then stole cryptocurrency from their accounts.  He worked with other co-conspirators.  According to the U.S. Department of Justice (DoJ), Light transferred the stolen funds to various locations worldwide, including using mixing services and gambling websites to launder the money. The charges carry a maximum penalty of 20 years in prison, a fine, three years of supervised release, a $200 special assessment fee, and possible restitution.  In September 2024, the DOJ also arrested two other suspects, Malone Lam, 20, and Jeandiel Serrano, 21, who are accused of stealing over $230 million in crypto. The pair attempted to launder the funds through cryptocurrency exchanges and mixing services.

Chinese state-linked hacker group Salt Typhoon breached systems of major US broadband providers, including Verizon, AT&T, and Lumen Technologies, potentially gaining access to intercept communications and steal sensitive data, posing a threat to US national security.  This incident, reported by the Wall Street Journal, has not been publicly disclosed due to national security implications. Experts believe the group focuses on intelligence gathering.  This breach could allow access to court-authorized communications, a serious security risk. Salt Typhoon targeted US government surveillance systems used for monitoring crime and security threats, including activities by foreign states.  This breach is part of China's cyber espionage strategy, which US officials fear could lead to destructive attacks on critical infrastructure in the future.

Apple releases iOS 18.0.1 and iPadOS 18.0.1 updates to address Media Session and Passwords vulnerabilities.

Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 353/67 (IT) Monday, October 7, 2024. Apple has released iOS 18.0.1 and iPadOS 18.0.1 updates to address two vulnerabilities. The first vulnerability, CVE-2024-44207, could allow an attacker to record short audio messages in the Messages app before the microphone is activated. This vulnerability was reported by Michael Jimenez and an anonymous researcher. Apple addressed this issue with improved validation. The second vulnerability, CVE-2024-44204, is a logic issue that could allow the VoiceOver feature to read a user's saved passwords. Apple addressed this issue with improved input validation. This vulnerability was reported by researcher Bistrit Dahal, and Apple states that there are no known exploits in the wild for these vulnerabilities.

LiteSpeed Cache plugin vulnerability on WordPress could allow website takeover. Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 352/67 (IT) Monday, October 7, 2024.  A recent discovery reveals a high-severity vulnerability in the LiteSpeed Cache plugin on WordPress, which could allow attackers to execute arbitrary JavaScript code. This vulnerability is identified as CVE-2024-47374 and has a CVSS severity score of 7.2, affecting versions up to 6.5.0.2 of the plugin with over 6 million installations. The vulnerability stems from a Cross-site Scripting (XSS) issue that allows attackers to steal sensitive information or escalate privileges on WordPress websites by performing a single HTTP request. If certain settings are enabled, such as “CSS Combine” and “Generate UCSS,” this vulnerability could allow attackers to take control of the entire website.  LiteSpeed Cache is a popular plugin used in WordPress for website acceleration and is often used with popular plugins like WooCommerce and Yoast SEO, making it highly vulnerable to attacks. A fix for this vulnerability was released in version 6.5.1 on September 25, 2024. Website administrators should update immediately to prevent attacks from malicious actors. In addition, the developers also fixed another vulnerability identified as CVE-2024-44000, which allowed attackers to access cookie information and escalate privileges to administrator level.  This vulnerability was fixed in version 6.5.0.1 of the plugin.

CISA adds Ivanti Endpoint Manager (EPM) vulnerability to the Known Exploited Vulnerabilities (KEV) catalog. The Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 351/67 (IT) for Friday, October 4, 2024, reports that the U.S. Cybersecurity and Infrastructure Security Agency (CISA) has added a critical vulnerability in Ivanti Endpoint Manager (EPM) to the KEV catalog.  The vulnerability, CVE-2024-29824, has a CVSS score of 9.6 and is an authentication bypass vulnerability in the Ivanti Virtual Traffic Manager.  In May, Ivanti released security patches to address multiple critical vulnerabilities in Endpoint Manager (EPM), including CVE-2024-29824, which is a SQL injection vulnerability in the Core server of Ivanti EPM version 2022 SU5 and earlier.  An unauthenticated attacker within the same network can exploit this vulnerability to execute arbitrary code. To mitigate the risk from this vulnerability, agencies under the Federal Civilian Executive Branch (FCEB) must remediate the vulnerability within a specified timeframe. CISA requires government agencies to patch this vulnerability by October 23, 2024, to prevent exploitation.

Vulnerabilities found in DrayTek routers put over 700,000 devices at risk globally.  Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 350/67 (IT) Friday, October 4, 2024. Latest cybersecurity research by ForeScout has revealed 14 vulnerabilities in routers manufactured by Taiwan-based DrayTek. One of these vulnerabilities is considered critical, affecting over 700,000 routers connected to the public internet worldwide. Even though DrayTek has released patches, the commercial use of these routers remains at risk. ForeScout's report indicates that these devices are most prevalent in the European Union and the United Kingdom, with approximately 425,000 units, followed by Asia and other regions such as Australia, the Middle East, and North America. Researchers warn that these routers could be exploited for DoS attacks, data theft, and ransomware.  Meanwhile, devices with certain vulnerabilities have been used in botnet operations linked to the Chinese government, such as the previously disrupted Volt Typhoon. Although patches have been released, ForeScout advises security professionals to closely monitor devices to mitigate attack risks.

AFP news agency hit by cyberattack, impacting client services.

Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 349/67 (IT) Thursday, October 3, 2024. Last Friday, Agence France-Presse (AFP) reported a cyberattack impacting its IT systems and content delivery to partners.  Although AFP's global news reporting was not affected, some client services may have been impacted. AFP is investigating the incident with the French cybersecurity agency ANSSI.  AFP is an international news agency with a mission to provide fast, comprehensive, and fact-checked news. It has a network of over 2,600 employees, including 1,700 journalists, based in 260 cities across 150 countries. AFP offers news in various formats, including video, text, photos, and audio, and provides services in six languages: French, English, Spanish, Portuguese, German, and Arabic.  BleepingComputer further reported that AFP warned media companies that the attack might have compromised FTP credentials used to receive content from AFP. Partners are advised to change their passwords and secure their content reception systems to mitigate potential risks.

Zimbra RCE Vulnerability at High Risk of Attack, Users Must Update Immediately

Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 348/67 (IT) Thursday, October 3, 2024.  A Remote Code Execution (RCE) vulnerability on Zimbra servers has recently been disclosed. This vulnerability, CVE-2024-45519, allows attackers to execute arbitrary commands and immediately take control of vulnerable systems. Zimbra has released an update to address this issue but has not yet disclosed in-depth details about the flaw.

Researchers from Proofpoint have observed attacks targeting this vulnerability since September 28th. Attackers sent spoofed emails from Gmail with base64-encoded malicious code via the CC field to execute shell commands on vulnerable servers. This allowed attackers to install web shells, enabling remote access and control of the server. Researchers from HarfangLab indicated that the source of these malicious emails originated from a server in Bulgaria and urged administrators to apply the patch as soon as possible to prevent attacks.  Proofpoint reports that the volume of attacks has not decreased since they began and appears to be opportunistic, not specifically targeting any particular organization.

Researchers also warn that patching this vulnerability is critical, as Zimbra is widely used in both corporate and government sectors worldwide, making it a prime target for attackers seeking to steal sensitive data.

The Israeli army penetrated the communications network of the Beirut airport control tower to warn Iranian planes not to land.

Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 345/67 (IT) Tuesday, October 1, 2024.  Last Saturday, the Israeli army penetrated the communications network of the Rafic Hariri International Airport control tower in Beirut, Lebanon, and sent warnings to Iranian civilian aircraft attempting to land, forcing the aircraft to return to Tehran, according to a report from the MiddleEastMonitor website.  The Lebanese Ministry of Transport ordered airport officials to prevent Iranian aircraft from entering Lebanese airspace after the Israeli infiltration. This decision follows warnings from the Israeli army to prevent the transport of weapons to Hezbollah through Beirut Airport.  Daniel Hagari, an Israeli army spokesperson, said in a statement: "We will not allow the transfer of weapons to Hezbollah in any form. We are aware of arms shipments from Iran to Hezbollah, and we will act to thwart them."  He added: "This airport is a civilian airport for civilian use, and it must remain so."  Ali Hamieh, the Lebanese Minister of Transport, confirmed to the newspaper "An-Nahar" that the Israeli army had penetrated the airport's control tower communication system and threatened to attack the infrastructure if Iranian planes landed.  The Israeli army claims that Beirut airport is being used as a transit point for weapons to Hezbollah, but Lebanese authorities have denied this accusation, insisting that the airport is for civilian use only.

The U.S. and allies call for enhanced security of undersea cables to prevent attacks.

Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 344/67 (IT) Tuesday, October 1, 2024. The U.S. government, along with international allies such as the United Kingdom, Canada, France, and the European Union, issued a joint statement calling for measures to strengthen the security and resilience of undersea cable infrastructure to protect critical global communications and data from cyberattacks or sabotage. The statement emphasizes the importance of using cybersecurity best practices in the design of undersea cables, a critical technology used to transfer massive amounts of data across continents.  These cables encompass stations, software, and land-based components related to the cables, which require a global strategy for protection.  In addition, the U.S. government warned of the increasing reliance on undersea cables amid geopolitical conflicts between Russia and Ukraine, as well as tensions in other regions, such as between China and Taiwan, which could make undersea cables targets of attacks and cause global internet disruptions. The statement also calls on all countries to cooperate to create stronger security management and maintenance systems, including regular risk assessments. It also emphasizes secure infrastructure design, promoting the selection of secure service providers, and supporting cooperation between government and industry.

Kuwait's Ministry of Health faces cyberattack, impacting several hospitals in the country.

Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 343/67 (IT) Monday, September 30, 2024.  Kuwait's Ministry of Health is recovering its systems after a cyberattack that affected the operations of several hospitals, including the Sahel healthcare application. The Ministry of Health's website was also unavailable, causing inconvenience in accessing information and services. The Ministry later announced that some critical systems were restored, such as the Kuwait Cancer Control Center system, and management systems related to health insurance and health checks for foreigners.  The Ministry's technical team traced the problem to an attempted system breach that caused the disruption. The Ministry is collaborating with government security agencies to control the situation and implement additional measures to enhance the security of its infrastructure.  It acted swiftly to prevent the spread of the threat and protect access to the Ministry's critical databases. While details about the attack are still unclear, based on the measures taken, it is suspected that the Ministry might be facing a ransomware attack.  No ransomware group has claimed responsibility yet.

A cyberattack on MoneyGram has caused global service disruptions.

Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 339/67 (IT) Thursday, September 26, 2024.  MoneyGram, a US-based peer-to-peer and international money transfer service provider, has confirmed a cyberattack that temporarily disabled its service systems.  On September 22, the company informed customers that it had experienced network problems affecting connections to several internal systems.  The company shut down some systems since last Friday to contain the attack, and indicated that it may have been hit by ransomware. The attack impacted both offline and online money transfer services.  The company has launched an investigation into the incident and notified law enforcement.  MoneyGram says it is working diligently to restore systems online and return to normal business operations as soon as possible. Private equity firm Madison Dearborn Partners acquired MoneyGram International on June 1, 2023, for $11.00 per share, taking the company private. In early 2023, over 50% of the company's transactions were digital. The company operates in over 200 countries and serves up to 150 million customers worldwide, making it a significant player in the money transfer industry. Because MoneyGram holds a large amount of sensitive customer data, it makes an attractive target for cybercriminals.

ESET releases patches for Privilege Escalation vulnerabilities in Windows and macOS products.  Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 337/67 (IT) Wednesday, September 25, 2024. ESET has released patches to address Privilege Escalation vulnerabilities in its Windows and macOS products. This vulnerability is a Local Privilege Escalation that allows low-privileged attackers to delete specified files and elevate privileges. For Windows products, vulnerability CVE-2024-7400 is a high-severity vulnerability related to file handling during the deletion of detected files. The company has addressed the issue in Cleaner module 1251 through an automatic Detection Engine update, requiring no further action from customers. This vulnerability affects both consumer and business products, including Antivirus, Internet Security, and server security solutions. ESET also confirms that there are no reports of this vulnerability being exploited at this time.  In addition, ESET has released a patch for CVE-2024-6654, a medium-severity vulnerability affecting ESET Cyber Security versions 7.0 through 7.4.1600.0 and Endpoint Antivirus for macOS (now Endpoint Security for macOS) versions 7.0 through 7.5.50.0. This vulnerability allows low-privileged users to create symlinks to disrupt the operation of security tools. ESET has addressed the vulnerability in Cyber Security version 7.5.74.0 and Endpoint Security for macOS version 8.0.7200.0 and confirms that there are no reports of this vulnerability being exploited currently.

Hackers stole over $44 million from the Crypto platform BingX.

Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 335/67 (IT) Monday, September 23, 2024.  The Singapore-based Crypto platform BingX reported a cyberattack on September 20, 2024, where attackers stole over $44 million USD in Cryptocurrency. The company detected unauthorized transfers and network anomalies, leading to a temporary suspension of withdrawals and the announcement of a system closure for "wallet maintenance" to protect assets.  BingX immediately moved assets to cold wallets after the incident to prevent further damage. The company utilizes a tiered asset management system, storing most assets in cold wallets and using hot wallets only for necessary transactions, mitigating the impact of this attack.  The company investigated the incident with assistance from SlowMist and found that over $47 million USD in Crypto had been stolen. However, BingX confirmed that this incident did not affect operations, and the company used reserve funds to compensate for all losses.

In 2024, the amount of Crypto stolen has increased significantly. In the first half of the year, the value stolen more than doubled from 2023, prompting law enforcement agencies to accelerate efforts to protect Crypto users, including arresting suspects involved in several theft cases.

Ukraine bans government officials and military personnel from using the Telegram app on government devices for national security.

Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 334/67 (IT) Monday, September 23, 2024. The Ukrainian government has issued an order prohibiting government officials, military personnel, and employees working in security and critical infrastructure from installing the Telegram application on government devices, stating that this measure is necessary for national security during the war with Russia.

The National Cybersecurity Coordination Center of Ukraine has announced a ban on the use of Telegram on devices belonging to government officials, military personnel, security and defense officials, and employees in critical infrastructure.  This ban was announced on Friday by the Ukrainian National Security and Defense Council in a statement on Facebook.  In a meeting last Thursday, the Ukrainian National Security Agency and the Ukrainian Armed Forces Command stated that Telegram was being used by Russia for cyberattacks, phishing, malware distribution, locating users, and calculating targets for missile strikes.

However, there is an exception for individuals who need to use this app for official work.  The general public can still use Telegram on personal devices as usual.

The Telegram application is widely used in Ukraine, not only for messaging but also for following news, especially information about Russian air strikes. It is also the main way that Ukrainian officials, including President Volodymyr Zelenskyy, use to communicate with the public and update on the war. It is expected that Zelenskyy will continue to use Telegram.

GitLab releases fix for Critical vulnerability that can bypass SAML authentication.  Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 333/67 (IT) Friday, September 20, 2024. GitLab has released an update to address a Critical vulnerability affecting the Community Edition (CE) and Enterprise Edition (EE). This is a SAML authentication bypass, tracked as CVE-2024-45409, with a CVSS score of 10. The vulnerability stems from an issue in GitLab's OmniAuth-SAML and Ruby-SAML libraries, which are used to manage SAML (Security Assertion Markup Language) authentication.  This issue arises when the SAML response sent by the Identity Provider (IdP) to GitLab is misconfigured or modified. This allows attackers to craft malicious SAML responses to trick GitLab into recognizing the attacker as an authenticated user, bypassing SAML authentication and gaining access to the GitLab instance.  The vulnerability affects GitLab versions 17.3.3, 17.2.7, 17.1.8, 17.0.8, and 16.11.10. GitLab has updated OmniAuth SAML to version 2.2.1 and Ruby-SAML to version 1.17.0 and recommends users update to the latest versions as soon as possible. For those who cannot update immediately, GitLab recommends enabling two-factor authentication (2FA) for all accounts and setting SAML 2FA bypass to "Disallow".

North Korean hackers target energy and space industries with new malware MISTPEN. Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 332/67 (IT) Friday, September 20, 2024. Researchers found that a hacker group linked to the North Korean government used job scams to penetrate the energy and space industries. They spread new malware called MISTPEN, a previously undiscovered backdoor. Cybersecurity firm Mandiant stated that the group, known as UNC2970 or Lazarus Group, uses tactics impersonating recruiters from leading companies to trick managers or senior executives into opening files containing hidden malware, particularly in the energy and space industries in several countries, including the US, UK, and Singapore. This attack starts by sending emails or WhatsApp messages, tricking victims into opening ZIP files that appear to be job-related documents.  But when these PDF files are opened, they require the use of a modified Sumatra PDF program to inject malware into the victim's system. MISTPEN is malware designed to be installed on the system and controlled via a command-and-control server.  This hacker group also has a history of using modified open-source software to carry out attacks in this manner, and researchers also found that this malware has become more sophisticated over time and conceals traces of the attack seamlessly.

Remote attack via pagers from Hezbollah group in Lebanon
Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 331/67 (IT) Thursday, September 19, 2024. A remote attack occurred via pagers used by the Hezbollah group in Lebanon and Syria, resulting in at least 9 deaths and more than 2,800 injuries. This incident occurred simultaneously across Lebanon and is believed to be an attack targeting pagers used by Hezbollah for covert communication to avoid tracking by Israeli intelligence. One of the deceased is the child of a Hezbollah member of parliament, while the Iranian ambassador to Lebanon was slightly injured. The exploded pagers are the latest model recently adopted by Hezbollah. Experts believe this may be a Supply Chain Attack, where the pagers might have been modified before delivery to detonate when remotely controlled. CNN reported that the pagers may have been tampered with during manufacturing or transportation, leading to this attack. Although there is no official confirmation of the cause, many experts emphasize that devices using lithium-ion batteries do not have such an explosion risk.  It is therefore possible that these pagers were intentionally designed to explode. The situation is still under investigation.

Broadcom releases updates to fix critical vulnerabilities in VMware vCenter Server. Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 330/67 (IT) Thursday, September 19, 2024. Broadcom has released security updates to address critical vulnerabilities in VMware vCenter Server that could allow attackers to remotely execute code.  This vulnerability is tracked as CVE-2024-38812 and has a severity score of 9.8 out of 10, which could allow attackers with network access to compromise the system by sending specially crafted network packets. vCenter Server is a key component in managing VMware's virtualized data centers, which has a heap-overflow vulnerability affecting the DCERPC protocol implementation. In addition, Broadcom has also addressed a privilege escalation vulnerability (CVE-2024-38813) that could allow attackers to gain root privileges. Both vulnerabilities were discovered by the TZL team during the Matrix Cup 2024 competition. Broadcom has released updates to fix these issues in vCenter Server versions 8.0 U3b and 7.0 U3s, along with relevant versions of VMware Cloud Foundation. Although no exploits targeting these vulnerabilities have been observed yet, Broadcom recommends users update their systems immediately to mitigate the risks.

The Port of Seattle has confirmed that the Rhysida Ransomware group was behind the cyberattack.

Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 327/67 (IT) Tuesday, September 17, 2024. The Port of Seattle confirmed last Friday that the Rhysida Ransomware group was responsible for the cyberattack that occurred in August.  The incident affected the agency's website and phone systems, including Sea-Tac Airport, causing temporary disruptions to travel and various services. The port isolated critical systems to prevent further damage.  Media reports indicated that the cyberattack affected the port's email, website, and phone systems and impacted baggage handling and flights at Sea-Tac Airport. Alaska Airlines employees had to manually process over 7,000 bags due to check-in system failures. Lance Lyttle, Managing Director of Aviation at Sea-Tac Airport, believed the incident was a cyberattack.  The Port of Seattle confirmed Rhysida Ransomware as the perpetrator. This group has previously attacked organizations in various industries, including education, healthcare, manufacturing, information technology, and government.  The port revealed that hackers gained access to the system and encrypted parts of the computer system. The port refused to pay the ransom to the Rhysida Ransomware group and collaborated with external experts and government agencies to investigate the incident.  Furthermore, the port is implementing enhanced security measures for its IT infrastructure, including strengthening identity management and authentication systems to prevent future incidents.

"Hadooken," a new Linux malware, targets Oracle WebLogic servers.  Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 326/67 (IT) Tuesday, September 17, 2024. Researchers from Aqua Security discovered new malware called "Hadooken," which attacks WebLogic servers.  The malware's name comes from an attack move in the game Street Fighter.  Hadooken's capabilities include installing cryptocurrency mining software (cryptominer) and deploying Tsunami malware, which can be used for later system breaches.  This attack targets WebLogic servers, developed by Oracle and often used in large organizations. Attackers gain access to the servers through weak passwords. They then use shell scripts and Python to download and install the malware on the server, while also attempting to hide traces of the attack. Researchers found that the Hadooken malware was downloaded from two IP addresses: 89.185.85.102 (still active), registered in Germany, and 185.174.136.204 (no longer active), registered in Russia.  The still-active IP has been linked to the TeamTNT and Gang 8220 groups. However, researchers do not yet have enough evidence to confirm the source of this attack.  Searching for additional information through Shodan revealed more than 230,000 WebLogic servers connected to the internet. Although most are well-protected, some may be vulnerable to attack.  Researchers recommend that administrators monitor and update their software to prevent future attacks.

GitLab fixes Critical vulnerability in GitLab CE and GitLab EE

Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 325/67 (IT) Monday, September 16, 2024. GitLab released security patches to address 17 vulnerabilities in GitLab CE (Community Edition) and EE (Enterprise Edition). One vulnerability is rated Critical, CVE-2024-6678 (CVSS score 9.9), which allows attackers to execute Pipelines on behalf of other users.  This vulnerability affects multiple versions and has been fixed in the latest version. Another High severity vulnerability, CVE-2024-8640 (CVSS score 8.5), found in GitLab EE, allows attackers to inject commands into a connected Cube server.  GitLab also addressed several medium and low severity vulnerabilities, such as privilege escalation, unauthorized access to source code, and token theft. All of these have been fixed in the latest version of GitLab.

Ivanti warns of exploitation of vulnerability in Cloud Appliance. Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 324/67 (IT) Monday, September 16, 2024. Ivanti disclosed that a critical vulnerability in Cloud Service Appliance (CSA), designated CVE-2024-8190, is being actively exploited.  This vulnerability has a CVSS score of 7.2 and allows for remote code execution, but attackers require administrator privileges to exploit it.  CVE-2024-8190 affects Ivanti CSA versions 4.6 Patch 518 and earlier, which are now end-of-life.  It was addressed in Patch 519 and customers are advised to upgrade to CSA version 5.0 for continued support and security. Last Friday, Ivanti confirmed exploitation of this vulnerability in a limited number of customers. While details about the attackers remain undisclosed, the U.S. Cybersecurity and Infrastructure Security Agency (CISA) has added this flaw to its Known Exploited Vulnerabilities (KEV) catalog and mandated federal agencies to patch it by October 4, 2024.  Therefore, customers should upgrade immediately to prevent potential future attacks.

Command Injection vulnerability found in PAN-OS 11.2.2

Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 323/67 (IT) Friday, September 13, 2024. Palo Alto Networks has issued an alert regarding a Command Injection vulnerability, CVE-2024-8686, with a High severity rating and a CVSSv4 score of 8.6. This vulnerability affects PAN-OS version 11.2.2.  The vulnerability allows authenticated administrators with Admin level access to bypass system restrictions and run arbitrary commands with root privileges on firewall devices running PAN-OS version 11.2.2. Exploiting this vulnerability requires access to the device through the same channels as administrators and requires Admin level authentication.  Currently, Palo Alto states that no malicious exploitation of this vulnerability has been observed. The issue has been addressed in PAN-OS version 11.2.3 and all subsequent releases. Affected users are advised to update to the latest version immediately to mitigate the risk of attack.

Microsoft releases September 2024 Patch Tuesday updates.

Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 322/67 (IT) Friday, September 13, 2024. Microsoft released the September 2024 Patch Tuesday updates to address 79 vulnerabilities across multiple products, including Windows and its components, Office, Azure, Dynamics Business Central, SQL Server, Windows Hyper-V, Mark of the Web (MOTW), and Remote Desktop Licensing Service.  Among these, 4 vulnerabilities are actively exploited as Zero-Days and 1 has been publicly disclosed. These vulnerabilities are categorized by severity as follows: 7 Critical, 71 Important, and 1 Moderate.

The Zero-Day vulnerabilities currently being exploited are:
– CVE-2024-38014: Windows Installer Elevation of Privilege Vulnerability
– CVE-2024-38217: Windows Mark of the Web Security Feature Bypass Vulnerability
– CVE-2024-38226: Microsoft Publisher Security Feature Bypass Vulnerability
– CVE-2024-43491: Microsoft Windows Update Remote Code Execution Vulnerability

The complete list of vulnerabilities addressed in the September 2024 Patch Tuesday updates can be found at: https://www.zerodayinitiative.com/blog/2024/9/10/the-september-2024-security-update-review

Upgrade Adobe Acrobat Reader to fix remote code execution vulnerability CVE-2024-41869
Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 321/67 (IT) Friday, September 13, 2024. Cybersecurity researchers recommend users immediately upgrade Adobe Acrobat Reader and Adobe Acrobat after the discovery of a critical vulnerability (CVE-2024-41869) which could be exploited to execute remote code. This vulnerability was discovered through the EXPMON platform and a publicly released Proof-of-Concept (PoC) exploit.  By opening a specially crafted PDF file, attackers can leverage this vulnerability to access memory and execute malicious code.  The vulnerability is related to a "Use-After-Free" error, where the program attempts to access memory that has already been freed, leading to unexpected behavior such as crashes or freezes.  If attackers manage to inject malicious code into that memory location, they can easily execute it on the target device. Although a security update was released in August, it reportedly did not fully address the issue. Users who updated to the new version still experienced application crashes when clicking or closing a specific dialog box. However, Adobe has since released the latest update that fixes this flaw. Therefore, to ensure the security of data and devices, users should immediately upgrade their software to the latest version.

Payment gateway data breach affects 1.7 million credit card owners. Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 318/67 (IT) Wednesday, September 11, 2024. Slim CD disclosed a security breach involving credit card and personal data of nearly 1.7 million customers. Slim CD, a payment processing solutions provider, revealed a data breach affecting the credit card and personal information of over 1.7 million customers. Unauthorized access to the company's network occurred for almost a year, from August 2023 to June 2024.  In a notification sent to affected customers, the company stated that attackers had access to the system from August 17, 2023, to June 15, 2024. Credit card data access occurred between June 14 and 15, 2024.  The potentially accessed information includes: – Full name – Address – Credit card number – Credit card expiration date. Slim CD has increased security measures to prevent future incidents. However, the company did not offer free identity theft protection services to those affected. Slim CD provides payment solutions to businesses in various industries, including retail, service, and restaurants.  Those who received the breach notification may have never interacted with the company directly, as Slim CD acts as a backend provider for these businesses.

Critical RCE vulnerability found in Progress LoadMaster with maximum severity.

Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 316/67 (IT) Tuesday, September 10, 2024. Progress Software has released an emergency update to address a critical vulnerability (10/10) affecting LoadMaster and LoadMaster Multi-Tenant (MT) Hypervisor products. The vulnerability, CVE-2024-7591, is caused by improper input validation, allowing unauthenticated attackers to access LoadMaster by sending specially crafted HTTP requests to execute system commands. This vulnerability affects LoadMaster versions 7.2.60.0 and all earlier versions, including MT Hypervisor versions 7.1.35.11 and all earlier versions, covering both Long Term Support (LTS) and Long Term Support Feature (LTSF) versions. To address this vulnerability, Progress has released an add-on that can be installed on all vulnerable versions without requiring an upgrade to a new version. However, this add-on is not supported for the free version of LoadMaster, leaving the vulnerability an issue for users of the free version.  Although Progress Software confirms that there are currently no reports of attacks exploiting this vulnerability, even though no attacks have been found at present, Progress Software recommends that customers update their LoadMaster systems as soon as possible to prevent risks and enhance security.

WordPress users warned: Vulnerability in LiteSpeed Cache plugin could lead to attacks.

Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 315/67 (IT) Tuesday, September 10, 2024. Researchers from Patchstack have warned of a serious vulnerability in the LiteSpeed Cache plugin for WordPress, which is used by more than 5 million websites.  The vulnerability, tracked as CVE-2024-44000, has a CVSS score of 7.5 and could allow unauthenticated attackers to take control of user accounts and escalate privileges to administrator. The flaw is caused by a cookie leak in WordPress debug log files, which allows attackers to use this information to log into the website with a valid user session. However, this vulnerability only occurs when the debug feature is enabled, which is disabled by default in WordPress.  For mitigation, users should update the LiteSpeed Cache plugin to version 6.5.0.1, which addresses this issue.  Additionally, old log files that may contain leaked cookie information should be deleted. Direct access to log files should also be prevented.  Updating and patching vulnerabilities is crucial for ensuring secure WordPress usage.

VMware fixes Code Execution vulnerability in Fusion hypervisor.  Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 310/67 (IT) Thursday, September 5, 2024. VMware has fixed a high-severity Code Execution vulnerability, CVE-2024-38811 (CVSS score 8.8), in the Fusion hypervisor. The vulnerability is due to the unsafe use of environment variables, allowing a malicious actor with regular user privileges to exploit this vulnerability for Code Execution within the context of the Fusion application. This vulnerability affects VMware Fusion version 13.x. VMware has addressed this issue in version 13.6. VMware's advisory does not mention any workarounds, and it is unclear whether there are any exploits using this vulnerability.  VMware Fusion users should immediately update their software to version 13.6 to mitigate the potential risks from this vulnerability.

Pavel Durov, founder of Telegram, arrested in France for violating content controls
Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 301/67 (IT) Monday, August 26, 2024 Pavel Durov, founder and CEO of Telegram, a popular messaging application, was arrested in France last Saturday, according to French television network TF1. TF1 said the investigation focused on the lack of content moderation on the instant messaging service, which authorities have already taken action on, making the app a haven for various criminal activities, including drug trafficking, child pornography, money laundering, and various frauds. The hands-off approach to oversight on Telegram has become a contentious issue, as it may be fueling cybercrime and turning the platform into a hub for various threat actors, including malware distribution and the trade of stolen data, as well as other illegal goods.  Guardio Labs said in a report earlier this year that "the application has become a hub for both experienced and novice cybercriminals to exchange illegal tools and insights, creating a dark supply chain." Telegram, headquartered in Dubai, has more than 950 million monthly active users as of July 2024. It recently launched an in-app browser and Mini App Store, which has resulted in it becoming a super app similar to Tencent's WeChat.

Toyota confirms data breach impacting customers.  Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 300/67 (IT) Thursday, August 22, 2024. Toyota confirms its network was breached after a threat actor stole 240 GB of data and leaked it on a forum. The company reports the incident was contained and didn't impact all systems.  However, there is no information on when the breach was discovered, how the attackers accessed the data, or how many people were impacted.  The ZeroSevenGroup claimed to have breached Toyota's US branch, stealing files with employee and customer data, including contracts and financial information. The group also claims to have exfiltrated infrastructure data, using the open-source tool ADRecon to pull information from Active Directory. While Toyota has not disclosed the breach date, BleepingComputer found the stolen files were created on December 25, 2022. This date may indicate the threat actors accessed backup servers storing the data.  Earlier last year, Toyota Financial Services (TFS), a Toyota subsidiary, warned customers that personal and financial data had been exposed in a data breach from a Medusa ransomware attack that impacted branches in Europe and Africa.

Mad Liberator ransomware group targets AnyDesk users with fake Windows update screens.  Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 297/67 (IT) Wednesday, August 21, 2024. The new ransomware group Mad Liberator is a threat group to watch out for after Sophos X-Ops discovered that the group is using the remote access application AnyDesk to attack users. They create fake Microsoft Windows update screens to conceal data theft from users. Mad Liberator has been operating since July 2024, focusing more on data theft than encryption attacks, the typical pattern of common ransomware. The group uses social engineering techniques to trick victims into allowing AnyDesk connections by misleading them into thinking it is maintenance from the company's IT department. Once the attackers establish a connection, they transfer files disguised as Windows updates into the victim's system. This fake update screen helps conceal data theft from OneDrive and files on the central server. This attack takes about four hours. The attack underscores the importance of training employees on managing remote sessions and using Anydesk access controls to prevent future attacks.  However, the social engineering tactics used by this group in the case described above are interesting but not unique. Attackers will continue to develop and use various tactics to try to exploit both the human element and technical security layers.

Iran's banking sector is facing a major cyberattack.  Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 295/67 (IT) reported on Monday, August 19, 2024, that the Central Bank of Iran (CBI) was cyber-attacked last Wednesday, along with several other banks in the country, causing disruption to Iran's financial system.  Iran International reports that the scale and impact of this attack may be one of the largest cyberattacks ever faced by Iran's infrastructure.  In addition, it was reported that hackers were also able to steal account holder information.  There were also notes placed on ATMs that read, "Dear customers, you cannot withdraw money from the bank because all of Iran's national budget and resources have been invested in warfare for the benefit of the corrupt regime of the Islamic Republic."  This cyberattack comes at a time of heightened tension as Iran's Supreme Leader, Ayatollah Khamenei, threatened to retaliate for the death of Hamas leader Ismail Haniyeh.  There are also reports that Iranian hackers are involved in the upcoming US elections.

SolarWinds fixes Critical RCE vulnerability in all versions of Web Help Desk software.  Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 294/67 (IT) Friday, August 16, 2024. SolarWinds has released a security update for Web Help Desk (WHD) to address a Critical vulnerability that could be exploited for Remote Code Execution, tracked as CVE-2024-28986 with a CVSS score of 9.8. The vulnerability is a Java Deserialization issue that allows attackers to execute commands on vulnerable machines. SolarWinds states that Web Help Desk is software for Help Desk Ticketing and Asset Management used by large organizations and government agencies. SolarWinds Web Help Desk is vulnerable to a Java Deserialization Remote Code Execution vulnerability which, if exploited, allows attackers to execute commands on the host machine.  The vulnerability affects all versions of Web Help Desk. SolarWinds recommends that customers update to Web Help Desk (WHD) 12.8.3 and install a hotfix. The vulnerability was discovered by the company's security researchers, and users can find hotfix installation instructions at https://support.solarwinds.com/SuccessCenter/s/article/WHD-12-8-3-Hotfix-1.

Arrest of Belarusian and Ukrainian nationals linked to ransomware and cybercrime.

Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 293/67 (IT) Friday, August 16, 2024.  Law enforcement agencies from multiple countries have cooperated in the arrest and extradition of Belarusian and Ukrainian nationals believed to be involved with a Russian-speaking cybercrime group.  The operation was coordinated by the UK's National Crime Agency (NCA). One of those arrested is Maksim Silnikau, 38, who used the online alias “JP Morgan.” He was extradited from Poland to the United States in August 2024 to face charges related to international computer hacking and wire fraud.  The group was involved in the development and distribution of ransomware such as Reveton and the Angler Exploit Kit, which affected hundreds of thousands of victims worldwide.  Reveton, in particular, launched in 2011, is known as one of the first ransomware-as-a-service operations and reportedly earned the group as much as $400,000 per month.  Silnikau is also charged in connection with operating the Ransom Cartel ransomware, starting in May 2021, and using hidden websites to track and control ransomware attacks. If convicted on all counts, Silnikau could face more than 50 years in prison. This arrest is the result of international cooperation and represents a significant step in the fight against complex transnational cybercrime.

FBI shuts down dozens of Radar/Dispossessor ransomware servers.

Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 291/67 (IT) Thursday, August 15, 2024.  The FBI has shut down dozens of servers linked to the Radar/Dispossessor ransomware operation, a cybercriminal group that has become a significant threat recently. The group started by publishing data stolen by the LockBit ransomware group but has since evolved into an international ransomware gang targeting small to medium-sized businesses, including organizations across multiple sectors worldwide.  The FBI collaborated with law enforcement agencies from several countries to disrupt the group's infrastructure. Servers were shut down in the US, UK, and Germany, as well as criminal domains used in the attacks.  Radar/Dispossessor employs sophisticated attack methods, exploiting vulnerabilities and easily guessed passwords to access victims' systems. They then encrypt data and extort victims for ransom.  The criminals also contact victims' employees directly via email or phone to increase pressure to pay the ransom. The shutdown of Radar/Dispossessor is a law enforcement success, but experts warn that organizational self-defense remains crucial, as ransomware continues to be a widespread threat.

Evolution Mining, a major Australian gold producer, announced that it was hit by ransomware on August 8, 2024, impacting its IT systems.  Evolution Mining engaged external cybersecurity experts to assist with recovery, and the situation is reportedly under control.  The company stated the ransomware attack affected IT systems but is not expected to impact operations, which continue uninterrupted.  They indicated that the attackers may not have encrypted any systems or directly targeted production machines. The Australian Cyber Security Centre has been notified of the incident.  Currently, no ransomware group has claimed responsibility for the attack on Evolution Mining.  BleepingComputer contacted Evolution Mining for further information about the incident but has not received a response.  In June 2024, Northern Minerals, another major Australian mining company, admitted to a data breach after its data was published on the dark web. The attack was conducted by the BianLian ransomware group. The breach exposed operational details, R&D data, financial information, employee personal data, shareholder information, and senior executive emails.

Ukraine warns of new phishing campaign targeting government computers.  The Computer Emergency Response Team of Ukraine (CERT-UA) has issued a warning about a new phishing campaign impersonating Ukrainian security agencies to distribute remote desktop access malware. The agency is tracking the activity under the name UAC-0198.  It estimates that more than 100 machines have been infected since July 2024, including those belonging to government bodies in the country.  The attack chain involves sending mass emails distributing ZIP archives containing MSI installers. Opening the file activates malware dubbed ANONVNC, which leverages an open-source remote administration tool called MeshAgent, enabling stealthy and unauthorized access to the compromised hosts. The development comes after CERT-UA attributed phishing attacks spreading HTML attachments mimicking a UKR.NET login page to steal credentials to a hacking group tracked as UAC-0102.  CERT-UA said it has also observed a spike in campaigns distributing the PicassoLoader malware in recent weeks, with the end goal of deploying Cobalt Strike Beacon on the compromised systems. The attacks are linked to a threat actor tracked as UAC-0057.

ADT disclosed a data breach affecting over 30,000 customers.  Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 288/67 (IT) Tuesday, August 13, 2024. ADT, a security and burglar alarm system provider, disclosed a data breach affecting over 30,000 customers after a cyberattack. The attackers gained access to some databases containing ADT customer order information. The company immediately shut down unauthorized access and launched an investigation with external cybersecurity experts. ADT's investigation reported that customers' home security systems were not compromised and there is no evidence that customers' financial information, such as credit card or bank account information, was stolen. The company expects only a small number of customers to be affected and has notified those customers.  This incident is not expected to materially impact ADT's operations or financial position. The investigation is ongoing.  An attacker using the name “netnsher” claimed responsibility for the ADT hack, posting on a popular cybercrime forum, claiming the breach exposed over 30,812 records, including over 30,400 customer emails.  The stolen data includes customer emails, addresses, usernames, purchased products, and more.

FreeBSD releases urgent patch for high-severity OpenSSH vulnerability.  Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 287/67 (IT) Tuesday, August 13, 2024. FreeBSD has released a security update to address a critical vulnerability in OpenSSH, which could be exploited by attackers to remotely execute code with root privileges. The vulnerability is identified as CVE-2024-7589 and has a CVSS score of 7.4, indicating high severity. This vulnerability is related to signal handling in sshd (8) that may invoke unsafe logging functionality when a client fails to authenticate within the configured LoginGraceTime, which is typically 120 seconds. This process runs with root privileges, creating a risk that attackers could execute remote code. FreeBSD recommends users update OpenSSH to a supported version and restart sshd immediately to mitigate this threat. If updating is not feasible, users can reduce the risk by setting LoginGraceTime to 0 in the sshd_config file. While this increases the risk of denial-of-service (DoS) attacks, it will prevent remote code execution.

Ransomware group attacks French museum network. Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 284/67 (IT) Thursday, August 8, 2024. A ransomware group has attacked the network of the Réunion des Musées Nationaux (RMN), the French government organization that manages a network of museums and art centers across the country, including the Grand Palais in Paris and many other museums. The attack occurred last Sunday and affected more than 40 museums throughout France, some of which are being used for the Summer Olympics.  Grand Palais-RMN said in a statement that there is currently no evidence that data has been stolen.  Grand Palais-RMN technical teams are working hard to minimize the impact of the incident. The Grand Palais is hosting fencing and taekwondo competitions, while the Château de Versailles is hosting equestrian and modern pentathlon events. The Paris prosecutor's office has launched an investigation into the incident and assigned the Brigade for Combating Cybercrime to investigate the ransomware attack. French government experts are working to restore affected systems and ensure security.

Hackers breached Mobile Guardian's system, deleting data from thousands of devices. Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 283/67 (IT) Thursday, August 8, 2024. On August 4, 2024, hackers breached the systems of Mobile Guardian, a UK-based mobile device management (MDM) company, and remotely wiped data from thousands of iOS and ChromeOS devices.  The incident affected users worldwide, particularly in Singapore.  Singapore's Ministry of Education reported that approximately 13,000 students from 26 secondary schools were affected. Students using iPads and Chromebooks were unable to access applications and data on their devices. To prevent further attacks, Singapore's Ministry of Education removed the Mobile Guardian device management application from all iPads and Chromebooks. Mobile Guardian has shut down its servers and launched an investigation into the security breach, confirming that there is no evidence that attackers accessed user data. It remains unclear whether this incident was accidental or financially motivated, but it has affected users in several countries, including North America, Europe, and Singapore.

Agencies using Apache OFBiz are urged to patch vulnerabilities.

Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 282/67 (IT) on Wednesday, August 7, 2024, warns agencies using Apache OFBiz to immediately address the Critical vulnerability CVE-2024-38856.  Reports indicate increased exploitation of this vulnerability, which is an improper authentication issue that may allow unauthenticated users to invoke Screen rendering code. Affected versions are those prior to 18.12.15. Researchers from SonicWall discovered this vulnerability and described it as a critical issue that could allow malicious actors to perform Remote Code Execution without authentication. The cause of this vulnerability stems from a flaw in the authentication mechanism, allowing unauthorized users to access functions that normally require login. Additionally, the vulnerability discovered in May, CVE-2024-32113, is a path traversal vulnerability that could lead to Remote Code Execution.  The SANS Institute reports increased exploitation attempts of this vulnerability in late July, with attackers experimenting with the flaw and potentially incorporating it into various Mirai botnet versions in the future.

Hackers are attempting to sell the personal data of 3 billion people from a data breach in April.  Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 280/67 (IT) Tuesday, August 6, 2024. Jerico Pictures Inc., operating as National Public Data, has exposed the personal data of nearly 3 billion people from a data breach incident in April. On April 8th, a threat actor using the name USDoD announced the sale of the "National Public Data" database on the dark web, offering the personal data of 2.9 billion people for $3.5 million. A class-action lawsuit has been filed alleging that Jerico Pictures Inc. failed to secure and protect the personal information it collected and stored.  The database compiles information from non-public sources, including full names, current and former addresses, social security numbers, family information, and other personal details.  Researchers from VX-underground have verified the authenticity of the leaked data, finding that the database does not exclude individuals who have opted out of data sharing. Furthermore, the database includes information on deceased individuals. This data breach is considered one of the largest ever.

CISA warns of unpatched Avtech camera vulnerability being actively exploited.  Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 278/67 (IT) Monday, August 5, 2024. The U.S. Cybersecurity and Infrastructure Security Agency (CISA) has warned of a vulnerability, CVE-2024-7029 (CVSS score: 8.8), in Avtech cameras that is currently being exploited. Attackers can exploit this vulnerability to inject and execute commands with root privileges. This vulnerability affects Avtech AVM1203 IP cameras with firmware version FullImg-1023-1007-1011-1009 and earlier. Cybersecurity expert Larry Cashdollar from Akamai Technologies reported the vulnerability to CISA, which then reported it to the vendor but has not received a response.  CISA recommends users mitigate the risk of exploitation of CVE-2024-7029 by limiting network exposure of control devices to prevent internet access and placing control system networks and remote devices behind firewalls and isolating them from the business network.  For added security, users should employ secure remote access methods such as VPNs.  Multiple botnets have targeted Avtech devices, including Mirai, Death botnet, Hide ‘N Seek, and HNS.

Critical vulnerability in Acronis Cyber Infrastructure exploited in the wild.

Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 272/67 (IT) Wednesday, July 31, 2024. Cybersecurity company Acronis has warned of a critical vulnerability in its Cyber Infrastructure (ACI) product that has been patched, but was exploited in real-world attacks.
