Resecurity has observed a significant increase in fraud and scam activity during Ramadan in the Middle East. Organizations in the Middle East face increased fraud risks, especially in Saudi Arabia, where consumer spending ranks highest in the region, exceeding $16 billion. This surge is driven by rapidly increasing e-commerce activity, which has attracted cybercriminals seeking to exploit platforms for scams, resulting in significant financial impacts for both consumers and businesses.  The overall financial impact is estimated between $70 and $100 million. Resecurity has protected its clients by blocking over 320 fraud and scam attempts impersonating logistics providers and e-government services. Cybercriminals exploit platforms like Sadad, Musaned, Ajeer, Ejar, and well-known logistics services to trick internet users into various scams. Resecurity advises clients not to disclose personal and payment information on suspicious websites or to individuals impersonating bank or government employees. Report published by Resecurity: https://www.resecurity.com/blog/article/cybercriminals-accelerate-online-scams-during-ramadan-and-eid-fitr

Over 39,000 websites infected with new malware in ‘Sign1’ campaign

Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 117/67 (IT) Tuesday, March 26, 2024. Website security company Sucuri warns that more than 39,000 websites are infected with a new family of malware that redirects website visitors to fraudulent domains and unwanted advertisements. The name Sign1 comes from the discovery of JavaScript malware in WordPress custom HTML widgets or within the Simple Custom CSS and JS WordPress plugin that attackers added to compromised websites. Using this method, hackers spread malware to websites without placing malicious code in server files, allowing the malware to go unnoticed for long periods, as it is common for security providers to scan website files for malware rather than checking databases. The injected code is responsible for changing the URL to be executed in the victim's browser every 10 minutes, but only if the visitor comes from major websites such as Facebook, Google, Instagram, and Yahoo. In the past six months, Sucuri has identified more than 39,000 websites infected with various forms of this malware, and recently more than 2,500 websites have been infected in the past two months. Therefore, maintaining security, system administration, and website monitoring should be a top priority for website owners.

German police seized the Nemesis Market.  Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 116/67 (IT) Monday, March 25, 2024. The German Federal Criminal Police Office and the Cybercrime Unit in Frankfurt have seized the server infrastructure of the global illegal darknet market called Nemesis Market in Germany and Lithuania.  This operation was coordinated between German, American, and Lithuanian law enforcement agencies.  They also seized 94,000 euros in digital currency.  Nemesis Market has been operating since 2021, with over 150,000 users and more than 1,100 registered vendor accounts worldwide. Investigations revealed that almost 20 percent of the vendor accounts were from Germany. The marketplace offered illegal goods including drugs, stolen data, credit card information, and a wide range of cybercrime services such as ransomware, phishing, and DDoS attacks.  Currently, the Nemesis Market website displays a banner informing users that the site has been seized by law enforcement.

Ivanti releases urgent fix for critical RCE vulnerability in Sentry.  Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 114/67 (IT) Friday, March 22, 2024. Ivanti has disclosed details of a remote code execution vulnerability affecting Standalone Sentry, urging users to patch immediately to prevent potential cyber threats.  CVE-2023-41724 is rated critical with a CVSS score of 9.6. The vulnerability allows unauthenticated attackers to execute code on the underlying operating system of the appliance within the network.  This vulnerability affects versions 9.17.0, 9.18.0, and 9.19.0, as well as older versions. The company says it has released patches in versions 9.17.1, 9.18.1, and 9.19.1, which are available for download via its portal. Vincent Hutsebaut, Pierre Vivegnis, Jerome Nokin, Roberto Suggi Liverani, and Antonin B from the NATO Cyber Security Center are credited with discovering the flaw.  According to Mandiant, recently disclosed vulnerabilities in Ivanti software have been exploited by at least three Chinese-linked cyber espionage groups: UNC5221, UNC5325, and UNC3886.

Android users in India are being impacted by a Malware-as-a-Service threat.  Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 113/67 (IT) Friday, March 22, 2024.  Threat actors are using a Malware-as-a-Service (MaaS) campaign, selling or renting malware to hackers to steal sensitive personal information, including bank account details and SMS messages, on Android devices in India. According to Broadcom, the campaign distributes malicious Android Package Kit (APK) files and seeks banking information, SMS messages, and other sensitive data from victim devices. This campaign is deployed through masquerading as helpful applications, such as customer service apps, online booking apps, or various billing and delivery services.  Therefore, Android users in affected regions can protect themselves by downloading applications only from trusted sources, using security software, and staying informed about threats that may affect their devices.

Chrome 123 and Firefox 124 Release Patches for Serious Vulnerabilities

Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 112/67 (IT) Thursday, March 21, 2024. On Tuesday, Google and Mozilla released security updates for their web browsers Chrome and Firefox to address multiple vulnerabilities, including several critical and high-severity flaws.  Chrome 123 patched several issues, the most severe being CVE-2024-2625.  It also addressed five moderate-severity vulnerabilities in components such as Swiftshader, Canvas, Downloads, and iOS, and one low-severity vulnerability in iOS.  Chrome is releasing version 123.0.6312.58 for Linux and versions 123.0.6312.58/.59 for Windows and macOS.

Mozilla released Firefox 124 with patches for 12 vulnerabilities. The critical vulnerability, CVE-2024-2615, could be exploited to execute arbitrary code. Firefox 124 also fixed five high-severity vulnerabilities, five moderate-severity vulnerabilities, and one low-severity vulnerability. Mozilla also announced the release of Thunderbird 115.9 and Firefox ESR 115.9.

Fujitsu discovered malware in its IT systems that may have resulted in the theft of customer data.

Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 110/67 (IT) Wednesday, March 20, 2024.  Last Friday, Fujitsu, a Japanese technology company, announced that it suffered a malware attack, and attackers may have stolen personal and customer data. The company revealed that it found several computers infected with malware. In response to the compromise, security personnel disconnected the affected systems from the network. The company has launched an investigation into the incident. The company notified the Personal Information Protection Commission of the data breach, although it has not received any reports of misuse of personal or customer information.  The investigation is ongoing, and the company has not provided details about the attack, such as the type of malware involved. In May 2021, attackers gained access to several Japanese agencies after accessing Fujitsu's ProjectWEB. ProjectWEB is a software-as-a-service (SaaS) platform for enterprise collaboration and file sharing provided by Fujitsu. At that time, Fujitsu confirmed the security breach and revealed that the attackers stole some customer data belonging to several government agencies.

E-Root Marketplace administrator sentenced to 42 months for selling 350,000 stolen credentials.  Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 109/67 (IT) Wednesday, March 20, 2024.  31-year-old Sandu Boris Diaconu was sentenced to 42 months in prison in the U.S. for operating an illegal marketplace called E-Root Marketplace, which offered 350,000 stolen credentials for sale. He was charged with conspiracy to commit access device fraud and computer fraud, and possession of 15 or more unauthorized access devices. He pleaded guilty on December 1, 2023.  The E-Root Marketplace operated through a widely distributed network and was able to hide the identities of administrators, buyers, and sellers. Buyers could search for compromised computer credentials on E-Root, such as usernames and passwords, that would allow buyers to remotely access computers for the purpose of stealing personal information or manipulating computer content remotely. The marketplace also concealed transaction paths by using an online payment system called Perfect Money, which allowed Bitcoin to be converted to Perfect Money.  The infrastructure associated with E-Root and Perfect Money was seized by law enforcement in late 2020.  It is estimated that more than 350,000 credentials were advertised for sale in the illegal marketplace, with many victims falling under ransomware attacks and tax fraud schemes.

International Monetary Fund (IMF) Email Accounts Compromised

Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 108/67 (IT) Tuesday, March 19, 2024. The International Monetary Fund (IMF) has disclosed a security breach by a Threat Actor who compromised 11 email accounts earlier this year. The agency discovered the incident on February 16, 2024, and immediately launched an investigation with the assistance of cybersecurity experts.  The International Monetary Fund (IMF) is a major financial agency of the United Nations and an international financial institution funded by 190 member countries. Its mission is “working to foster global monetary cooperation, secure financial stability, facilitate international trade, promote high employment and sustainable economic growth, and reduce poverty around the world.”  The investigation into the 11 compromised IMF email accounts affected has so far not revealed any additional indicators or evidence, and the investigation is ongoing. This incident is not the first time the IMF has faced such problems; the IMF experienced a major security breach in 2011.

Scranton School District in Pennsylvania hit by Ransomware attack.  Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 106/67 (IT) Monday, March 18, 2024.  Schools in Scranton, Pennsylvania have experienced a Ransomware attack, resulting in IT system disruptions. The Scranton School District is working with forensic experts to investigate the security breach and restore affected systems. The Scranton School District is a large urban school district located in Scranton, Pennsylvania. The school district consists of 15 schools and serves more than 9,000 students. The Scranton School District reported "network-related issues" on Thursday, stating that the problems disrupted computer systems and services, causing the school district to postpone classes for two hours on Thursday. The school district has not yet released details about the Ransomware attack, and it is unclear which Ransomware group targeted the organization and whether the school experienced a data breach.

The US has seized $1.4 million in Tether (USDT) cryptocurrency from a tech support scam gang.  Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 103/67 (IT) Friday, March 15, 2024.  US law enforcement agencies seized the digital currency, believed to be proceeds from a tech support scam. After the FBI received a court order to seize the funds from the suspected fraud, the money will be returned to the victims. One of the scam's forms targeted elderly victims in the United States. Victims would receive pop-up alerts on their computer screens claiming their system had been compromised. The victims would then be directed to contact Microsoft or Apple and call a phone number belonging to the scammers posing as technical support staff. The scammers would then convince the victims to install remote access programs on their systems.  They would tell the victims that their social security numbers and bank accounts had also been compromised. They would then trick the victims into contacting another scammer impersonating an employee of the victim's bank. The victims would be persuaded to convert their money into cryptocurrency and transfer it to digital wallets belonging to the scammers and their accomplices.  According to the FBI’s 2023 Internet Crime Report, reported losses totaled more than $12.5 billion, a 22% increase compared to 2022.

Urgent Update! Critical vulnerability found in File Manager on WordPress!

Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) warning! A critical vulnerability has been found in the File Manager and File Manager Pro plugins on WordPress. Hackers can exploit this vulnerability to: 📌 Read sensitive information on your website 📌 Upload malicious files to take control of your website 📌 Cause various other damages. 🟢 Affected versions: File Manager versions 6.0 to 7.2.1, File Manager Pro versions 6.0 to 8.3.4. 🟢 Urgent fix!: UPDATE File Manager to version 7.2.2 or later. Update File Manager Pro to version 8.3.5 or later.

Microsoft Patch Tuesday for March 2024 addressed 59 vulnerabilities.

Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 102/67 (IT) Thursday, March 14, 2024, Microsoft released the March 2023 Patch Tuesday update that addressed 59 vulnerabilities in its products. Two vulnerabilities, CVE-2024-21407 and CVE-2024-21408, are rated Critical, and the remaining 57 are rated Important.

- CVE-2024-21407 is a Remote Code Execution vulnerability in Windows Hyper-V.
- CVE-2024-21408 is a Denial of Service vulnerability in Windows Hyper-V.

The most severe vulnerability addressed by Microsoft is an Open Management Infrastructure (OMI) Remote Code Execution vulnerability, CVE-2024-21334 (CVSS 9.8). An unauthenticated attacker could execute code on OMI instances accessible over the internet. Currently, none of the vulnerabilities addressed in the March 2023 Microsoft Patch Tuesday security update have been exploited in attacks.

The full list of vulnerabilities Microsoft patched in March 2024 can be found at https://www.zerodayinitiative.com/blog/2024/3/12/the-march-2024-security-update-review

Acer confirms that employee data in the Philippines has been leaked.

Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 101/67 (IT) for Thursday, March 14, 2024. Acer in the Philippines has confirmed that employee data has been stolen. A hacker known as 'ph1ns' has published a link for downloading the stolen database, which is available for free download on a data breach forum website.  The data belongs to Acer employees. Acer is a Taiwanese computer hardware and electronics manufacturer. The attacker stated that the attack did not involve ransomware or data encryption, but was purely a data theft.  They confirmed they did not attempt to extort the company, but presented evidence that they wiped data on the compromised server before losing access.

Acer confirmed the data is theirs, but was not stolen directly from the company’s systems.  A spokesperson stated, “We are aware that one of our external vendors in the Philippines experienced a data breach, and as a result, some employee data was compromised."  Later, Acer Philippines issued a public statement on the X platform, offering similar assurances about the safety of customer data, confirming that systems remain fully operational and have not been compromised by the threat actors. They have reported the incident to the National Privacy Commission (NPC) and the Cybercrime Investigation and Coordination Center (CICC) in the Philippines.  The incident is currently under investigation.

Major cyberattacks hit French government agencies.  Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 100/67 (IT) Wednesday, March 13, 2024. The French Ministry revealed several intense cyberattacks targeting multiple French government agencies on Sunday night.  The Ministry did not provide details about the attacks, but they appear to be distributed denial-of-service (DDoS) attacks.  Prime Minister Gabriel Attal stated on Monday, March 11th, that several French government agencies were affected by cyberattacks of unprecedented intensity, and confirmed the government was able to contain all the impacts.  The French government activated response measures, confirming that the impact of the attacks has been reduced for most services, and access to government websites has been restored. Although French authorities could not confirm if the attacks were by attackers linked to Russia, the Pro-Russia group NoName claimed several attacks in France.

CHAVECLOAK is a new banking Trojan targeting Brazilian users via phishing attacks.
Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 99/67 (IT) Wednesday, March 13, 2024:  Users in Brazil are being targeted by a new banking Trojan called CHAVECLOAK, which is spread through phishing emails containing PDF attachments.  These emails trick users into downloading a ZIP file and subsequently use DLL side-loading techniques to finally install the malware. The attack chain involves the use of DocuSign-themed lures (electronic signature transaction management system) to trick users into opening a PDF file with a button to read and sign a document. Clicking this button leads to the retrieval of an installer file from a shortened link using the Goo.su URL shortening service.  Inside the installer is an executable file named "Lightshot.exe," which utilizes DLL side-loading to load "Lightshot.dll," which is the CHAVECLOAK malware. This allows attackers to steal sensitive information, log keystrokes, and display deceptive pop-up windows to victims.

QNAP fixes 3 vulnerabilities in NAS devices, including an Authentication bypass vulnerability.  Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 96/67 (IT) Monday, March 11, 2024. QNAP has fixed 3 vulnerabilities in Network Attached Storage (NAS) devices that could be exploited to gain access to the device. The 3 vulnerabilities are as follows: – CVE-2024-21899 is an improper authentication vulnerability that could allow users to compromise the security of the system over the network. – CVE-2024-21900 is an injection vulnerability that could allow authenticated users to execute commands over the network. – CVE-2024-21901 is an SQL injection vulnerability that could allow authenticated administrators to inject malicious code over the network. QNAP recommends that users update QTS, QuTS hero, QuTScloud, and myQNAPcloud to the following versions: – QTS 5.1.3.2578 build 20231110 and later – QTS 4.5.4.2627 build 20231225 and later – QuTS hero h5.1.3.2578 build 20231110 and later – QuTS hero h4.5.4.2626 build 20231225 and later – QuTScloud c5.1.5.2651 and later – myQNAPcloud 1.0.52 (24/11/2023) and later.

A group of 40 state attorneys general sent a letter to Meta, the parent company of Instagram and Facebook, expressing "serious concerns" over a significant increase in consumer complaints regarding account takeovers by malicious actors who change passwords. They urged Meta to improve its preventative measures.  Once malicious actors gain control, they immediately change passwords, locking out legitimate owners. They then post content, access private messages, contact individuals for scams, and engage in other harmful or illegal behavior.  Besides demanding immediate action to improve mitigation strategies and response to affected users, the attorneys general also requested data from Meta on the number of account takeovers in the past five years, suspected causes for the increase, and existing safeguards.

CISA adds Android Pixel and Sunhillo SureLine vulnerabilities to the Known Exploited Vulnerabilities (KEV) catalog.  Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 94/67 (IT) Friday, March 8, 2024.  The US Cybersecurity and Infrastructure Security Agency (CISA) has added two vulnerabilities affecting Android Pixel and Sunhillo SureLine to the Known Exploited Vulnerabilities (KEV) catalog: – CVE-2023-21237:  An information disclosure vulnerability in Android Pixel. – CVE-2021-36380: An OS Command Injection vulnerability in Sunhillo SureLine. The Android Pixel vulnerability, CVE-2023-21237, allows for information disclosure without requiring privileges or user interaction.  Google addressed this issue in June 2023. The second vulnerability, CVE-2021-36380, is an OS Command Injection vulnerability in Sunhillo SureLine.  Exploiting this vulnerability allows execution of arbitrary commands with root privileges. According to Binding Operational Directive (BOD) 22-01: Reducing the Significant Risk of Known Exploited Vulnerabilities, FCEB agencies must remediate these vulnerabilities by the specified deadline to prevent attacks. Experts recommend that private organizations also review the catalog and address these vulnerabilities in their infrastructure.  CISA has ordered federal civilian agencies to remediate these vulnerabilities by March 26, 2024.

'Lotus Bane,' a new APT group, is behind attacks on Vietnamese financial organizations. Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 93/67 (IT) reported on Friday, March 8, 2024, that financial organizations in Vietnam have been targeted by a new cyber attacker group called Lotus Bane. This is part of a cyber attack first detected in March 2023. Group-IB said that this is an advanced persistent threat (APT) group, believed to have been active since 2022. The exact specifics of the attack patterns are still unknown. Group-IB explains that the techniques used by Lotus Bane overlap with OceanLotus, a Vietnamese threat group also known as APT32, Canvas Cyclone (formerly Bismuth), and Cobalt Kitty. This stems from the use of malware such as PIPEDANCE.  It is worth noting that PIPEDANCE was first documented by Elastic Security Labs in February 2023, linked to cyber attacks targeting an unnamed organization in Vietnam in late December 2022. The Lotus Bane group was involved in the attack, primarily targeting the banking sector in the APAC region. Although the attacks took place in Vietnam, their sophisticated methods indicate the potential for attacks on other countries within the APAC group.  Ongoing investigations may shed more light on their origins. The presence and activities of the Lotus Bane group in the APAC region highlight the need for continuous vigilance and strong cybersecurity measures.

Cybersecurity alert: Beware of hackers sending phishing messages to hack your Facebook page.

Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) prevention methods are as follows: 1. Do not use easily guessed passwords. Set complex passwords with special characters, uppercase and lowercase letters, and numbers. Use Multi-Factor Authentication (MFA) as a minimum. 2. Users with social media accounts that use the same password as their email or other platforms are at high risk of having another system using the same password easily accessed. 3. Enable login notifications for social media. If someone logs in from a device or browser not normally used, the platform will send a notification immediately. 4. Do not fall for emails prompting you to change your password without your initiation.  If you need to change your password, go directly to the platform's page and change it yourself.

Apple releases emergency updates to address two iOS zero-day vulnerabilities.

Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 92/67 (IT) Thursday, March 7, 2024. Apple has released emergency updates to address two iOS zero-day vulnerabilities, CVE-2024-23225 and CVE-2024-23296, which have been exploited in attacks. The first vulnerability, CVE-2024-23225, is a Kernel memory corruption vulnerability, and the second, CVE-2024-23225 (likely meant to be CVE-2024-23296), is an RTKit memory corruption vulnerability. Both vulnerabilities allow attackers arbitrary kernel read and write to bypass kernel memory protections. Apple has confirmed that both vulnerabilities have been exploited in attacks. Affected devices include iPhone XS and later, iPad Pro 12.9-inch 2nd generation and later, iPad Pro 10.5-inch, iPad Pro 11-inch 1st generation and later, iPad Air 3rd generation and later, iPad 6th generation and later, and iPad mini 5th generation and later. Apple has addressed both vulnerabilities with the release of iOS 17.4, iPadOS 17.4, iOS 16.7.6, and iPadOS 16.7.6.

Ransomware groups GhostSec and Stormous are targeting attacks in 15 countries. Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 91/67 (IT) for Thursday, March 7, 2024.  Cisco Talos researcher Hetan Raghuprasad reports that "ransomware groups GhostSec and Stormous are jointly carrying out double-extortion ransomware attacks against various businesses in several countries."  These attacks are targeting victims in countries such as Cuba, Argentina, Poland, China, Lebanon, Israel, Uzbekistan, India, South Africa, Brazil, Morocco, Qatar, Turkey, Egypt, Vietnam, Indonesia, and Thailand.  The businesses most affected include technology, education, manufacturing, government organizations, transportation, energy, medical, real estate, and telecommunications.  GhostSec is part of a coalition called The Five Families, which includes ThreatSec, Stormous, Blackforums, and SiegedSec, founded in August 2023. Late last year, the cybercrime group invested in ransomware-as-a-service (RaaS) with the GhostLocker malware, offering it for $269.99 per month. Shortly after, the Stormous ransomware group announced that it would use Python-based ransomware in attacks.  Talos' latest findings show that the two groups have joined forces and released an updated version of GhostLocker malware in November 2023, as well as starting a new RaaS program in 2024 called STMX_GhostLocker.

Hikvision Patches High-Severity Vulnerability in Security Management System

Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 90/67 (IT) Wednesday, March 6, 2024. Hikvision, a Chinese manufacturer of CCTV equipment, has released patches to address two vulnerabilities in its Security Management System. The most serious vulnerability, CVE-2024-25063, has a High-Severity rating and could lead to unauthorized access.  This vulnerability affects HikCentral Professional version 2.5.1 and lower. Hikvision says it's caused by insufficient server-side validation. If exploited, it could allow attackers to access certain URLs that they should not be able to access.  The second vulnerability, CVE-2024-25064, has a medium severity rating. This vulnerability affects HikCentral Professional versions 2.0.0 through 2.5.1. Hikvision says it's caused by insufficient server-side validation, allowing logged-in attackers to access resources they shouldn't be able to access by modifying parameter values. Hikvision recommends users patch as soon as possible, as vulnerabilities in Hikvision products can be exploited in malicious attacks.

Experts have disclosed two critical vulnerabilities in on-premises versions of JetBrains TeamCity software.  Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 89/67 (IT) Wednesday, March 6, 2024.  Researchers at Rapid7 have disclosed two new critical security vulnerabilities in JetBrains TeamCity On-Premises versions: CVE-2024-27198 (CVSS score: 9.8), an authentication bypass vulnerability in the TeamCity web component due to a path traversal issue, and CVE-2024-27199 (CVSS score: 7.3), an authorization bypass vulnerability in the TeamCity web component due to a path traversal issue.  These vulnerabilities could allow an unauthenticated attacker with HTTP(S) access to the TeamCity server to bypass authentication checks and gain administrative control of the server. These vulnerabilities affect all TeamCity On-Premises versions up to 2023.11.3 but have been addressed with the release of version 2023.11.4.  The company has also released a security patch plugin for customers who cannot patch their systems. Recently, JetBrains also addressed another critical vulnerability in the TeamCity server, tracked as CVE-2024-23917 (CVSS score: 9.8), which could be exploited by an unauthenticated attacker to gain administrative control of the server.

Threat actors hacked Chunghwa Telecom in Taiwan.  Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 88/67 (IT) Tuesday, March 5, 2024. Threat actors stole sensitive and confidential data from the telecommunications company Chunghwa Telecom, as disclosed by the Ministry of Defense. Chunghwa Telecom Company, Ltd. (Chinese Telecommunications Company) is the largest telecommunications provider in Taiwan and provides PSTN exchange, mobile, and local broadband services in the country. According to the Taiwanese Ministry of Defense, threat actors stole sensitive data from the company, including 1.7 terabytes of military and government documents. This includes contracts between the Navy and Chunghwa Telecom.  The data has been advertised for sale on the dark web. Taiwan has become a prime target for cyberattacks before the national elections. Cybersecurity experts say these attacks mostly originate from threat actors associated with China. Taiwan remains the target of numerous cyber espionage campaigns.

EKEN brand wireless video doorbells have a security vulnerability that could allow spying.  Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 87/67 (IT) Tuesday, March 5, 2024. Researchers from Consumer Reports (CR) have discovered serious vulnerabilities in wireless video doorbell products manufactured by Eken Group Ltd. from China under the brands EKEN and Tuck.  These are sold at major retailers such as Amazon, Walmart, Shein, and Sears.  The security flaws could allow malicious actors to view video from the devices or take complete control of them. Attackers can exploit the flaws to create accounts in the application and access the doorbell products by pairing them with other devices.  Malicious actors can then view images and lock out the device owners. Steve Blair, CR's privacy and security testing engineer, found at least 10 other similar-looking doorbell camera products sold under different brand names, all controlled through the same mobile app called Aiwit, owned by EKEN. Some major online retailers, such as Walmart, have removed the flawed products from their catalogs and offered refunds to customers who purchased the devices. However, EKEN smart wireless video doorbell devices are currently still being sold on Amazon.

CISA adds Microsoft Streaming Service vulnerability to the Known Exploited Vulnerabilities (KEV) catalog.  Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 86/67 (IT) Monday, March 4, 2024. The U.S. Cybersecurity and Infrastructure Security Agency (CISA) has added vulnerability CVE-2023-29360 (CVSS score 8.4) Microsoft Streaming Service to the Known Exploited Vulnerabilities (KEV) catalog. Attackers can exploit this vulnerability to gain system privileges.  The vulnerability was discovered by Thomas Imbert (@masthoon) from Synacktiv (@Synacktiv) through the Trend Micro Zero Day Initiative. According to Binding Operational Directive (BOD) 22-01: Reducing the Significant Risk of Known Exploited Vulnerabilities, FCEB agencies must patch the vulnerability by the deadline to prevent attacks and exploitation of vulnerabilities in the catalog. Experts recommend that private organizations also check the catalog and patch vulnerabilities in their infrastructure. CISA has ordered federal agencies to patch this vulnerability by March 21, 2024.

Rhysida ransomware demands $3.6 million for stolen children's hospital data.  Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 84/67 (IT) Friday, March 1, 2024. The Rhysida ransomware group claims to have carried out a cyberattack on Lurie Children's Hospital in Chicago in early February. Lurie is a leading children's hospital in the United States, providing care to more than 200,000 children annually. The attack caused health services to shut down and some treatments to be postponed. It affected email, telephone, internal internet, and doctors were forced to use paper for prescriptions.  The Rhysida ransomware group listed Lurie Children's on the dark web, claiming to have stolen 600 GB of data from the hospital and offering to sell the stolen data for 60 BTC ($3,700,000) to a single buyer. They set a deadline of seven days, after which the data will be sold to multiple buyers at a lower price or for free on Rhysida's platform.

LockBit ransomware group is back in action with a new encryptor and servers.

Last week, law enforcement agencies NCA, FBI, and Europol carried out a joint operation called 'Operation Cronos' to suppress the LockBit ransomware group. In this operation, law enforcement seized infrastructure, decryptor data, and shut down the LockBit website used for leaking stolen data.  However, the LockBit ransomware group is returning to attacks, using a newly updated encryptor and a new server infrastructure setup for publishing leaks and ransom negotiations.

According to BleepingComputer, the operation's negotiation server is back online but is only functional for victims of new attacks. While LockBit was being suppressed, approximately 180 affiliated cybercriminal groups continued ransomware operations. It is unclear how many are still working together in a Ransomware-as-a-Service model, as one publicly disclosed their operation on X. However, LockBit states that they are currently recruiting experienced pentesters to rejoin the operation, which may lead to increased attacks in the future.

Cencora, a pharmaceutical giant, has been hit by a cyberattack, with data stolen from its IT systems. Cencora, formerly known as AmerisourceBergen, provides pharmaceutical services, distributing medicines and solutions for medical offices, pharmacies, and animal health.  The company reported revenue of $262.2 billion in fiscal year 2023 and has approximately 46,000 employees. On February 21, 2024, Cencora discovered that its data had been stolen, some of which may include personal information.  The company filed an 8-K form with the SEC. Cencora says it has taken containment steps and launched an investigation with the help of law enforcement, external cybersecurity experts, and external consultants to examine the incident. The company has confirmed that the cyberattack is not related to the Optum Change Healthcare ransomware attack that led to disruptions in prescription billing.  Currently, there is no additional information on which attackers or ransomware are claiming responsibility for the attack.

LiteSpeed plugin vulnerability in WordPress puts over 5 million websites at risk.  Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 81/67 (IT) on Thursday, February 29, 2024, disclosed a security vulnerability in the LiteSpeed Cache plugin in WordPress that could allow unauthorized users to escalate their privileges. The vulnerability, identified as CVE-2023-40000, was patched in October 2023 in version 5.7.0.1. The LiteSpeed Cache plugin has been installed over 5 million times, with the latest version, 6.1, released on February 5, 2024. However, WordPress security authorities say CVE-2023-40000 resulted from a lack of user input sanitization and output escaping.  The vulnerability is rooted in a function called update_cdn_status() and is reproducible in default installations.  "Because the XSS payload is placed as an admin notice, and admin notices can be displayed on wp-admin endpoints, this vulnerability can easily be exploited by users with access to the wp-admin area." This allows authenticated attackers with contributor-level privileges and above to inject arbitrary web scripts into web pages that will execute whenever a user accesses the injected page.

ThyssenKrupp, a steel giant, confirms a cyberattack on its automotive division.

Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 80/67 (IT) Wednesday, February 28, 2024. ThyssenKrupp confirmed a systems breach attack on its automotive division last week, forcing IT systems to shut down to respond to the threat. ThyssenKrupp is one of the world's largest steel producers, with more than 100,000 employees and annual revenue of more than $44.4 billion (2022). A company spokesperson confirmed that the attack only affected the Thyssenkrupp Automotive Body Solutions business unit. The Automotive Body Solutions IT security team worked with the ThyssenKrupp Group IT security team to contain the threat. Therefore, various security measures were implemented, and some system applications were temporarily shut down. ThyssenKrupp further clarified that none of the other units were affected by the cyberattack. BleepingComputer contacted ThyssenKrupp to inquire about the reported outage. The company confirmed that production systems were shut down but clarified that customers were not affected. Currently, no ransomware group or threat actor has claimed responsibility for the attack on ThyssenKrupp. Thus the type of breach remains unknown.

Cyberattack against the Royal Canadian Mounted Police (RCMP)

Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 78/67 (IT) Tuesday, February 27, 2024. The Royal Canadian Mounted Police (RCMP), Canada's federal and national law enforcement agency, has confirmed being targeted by a cyberattack. The RCMP also reported the incident to the Office of the Privacy Commissioner (OPC).  Following the incident, the police are investigating the cyberattack. An RCMP spokesperson said in a statement to CBC News that there was no impact on RCMP operations, and no threat to the safety and security of Canadians. Canadian law enforcement did not provide details about the cyberattack.  In November 2023, the Canadian government disclosed a data breach after attackers hacked two government contractors. The Canadian government identified the two contractors as Brookfield Global Relocation Services (BGRS) and SIRVA Worldwide Relocation & Moving Services.  The hacks resulted in the exposure of sensitive information of an undisclosed number of government employees.  Data belonging to current and former Canadian government employees, members of the Canadian Armed Forces, and Canadian police officers was also exposed.

INTELBROKER hackers claim to have attacked Los Angeles International Airport systems.

Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 77/67 (IT) Tuesday, February 27, 2024.  IntelBroker hackers announced on the Hackread website that they had gained access to the CRM system, a service system of Los Angeles International Airport. They exploited a vulnerability in the target's system. The attack occurred this month.  IntelBroker is a notorious hacker group involved in attacks on well-known companies such as DC Health Link, Volvo, and Hewlett Packard Enterprise (HPE).  They were also behind the recent Facebook Marketplace database leak. The hackers claim to have accessed a database containing confidential information of private aircraft owners.  The database contains 2.5 million records, including the following information: – Full name – CPA number – Email (including 1.9 million emails – after removing duplicates, 15,800 emails remain) – Company name – Aircraft model number – Tail number (the identification number painted on the tail of the aircraft). This cyberattack did not affect passengers or travelers.

Critical vulnerability in VMware (EAP) requires immediate uninstallation.  Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 76/67 (IT) Friday, February 23, 2024. VMware recommends users uninstall the deprecated VMware Enhanced Authentication Plugin (EAP), which has an Arbitrary Authentication Relay vulnerability, CVE-2024-22245 (CVSS score: 9.6). The VMware Enhanced Authentication Plugin (EAP) was designed to simplify access to the vSphere management interface through Windows Authentication connections and smart card functionality with Windows Client. This plugin was deprecated in 2021 with the release of vCenter Server 7.0u2. There is also another vulnerability associated with the plugin: CVE-2024-22250 (CVSS score: 7.8). Remediation requires removing the EAP plugin both from the browser plugin (EAP 6.7.0) and the Windows Service (VMware Plug-in service). These vulnerabilities were reported by Ceri Coburn from Pen Test Partners.

ConnectWise fixes Critical vulnerabilities in ScreenConnect remote access tool.

Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 74/67 (IT) Thursday, February 22, 2024 ConnectWise has announced two Critical vulnerabilities in ScreenConnect remote desktop access: – CWE-288 Authentication bypass using an alternate path or channel (CVSS score 10) – CWE-22 Improper limitation of a pathname to a restricted directory (“path traversal”) (CVSS score 8.4)  Both vulnerabilities were reported on February 13, 2024, through the company's vulnerability disclosure channel via the ConnectWise Trust Center. Due to the high risk of these vulnerabilities being targeted, affecting ScreenConnect 23.9.7 and earlier, ConnectWise recommends updating to version 23.9.8 immediately.

XSS vulnerabilities in Joomla could expose millions of websites to remote code execution (RCE) attacks.  Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 73/67 (IT) Thursday, February 22, 2024. Joomla, an open-source content management system (CMS), has multiple cross-site scripting (XSS) vulnerabilities that could lead to remote code execution (RCE) attacks. The Sonar vulnerability research team discovered one of the underlying vulnerabilities, tracked as CVE-2024-21726, which is significant because it affects Joomla's core filtering component. Attackers can exploit this XSS vulnerability to inject malicious scripts into a victim's website. Attackers can steal visitor data, perform malicious redirects, or infect users with malware. In this case, attackers could cause problems by tricking an administrator into clicking a malicious link. Joomla powers approximately 2% of all websites, with most deployments publicly accessible, making these sites potential targets for cyber threat actors. The issue has been addressed in Joomla versions 5.0.3/4.4.3, which have been released. Therefore, users and administrators should update as soon as possible to avoid becoming victims of attackers.

LockBit ransomware gang's website seized in international law enforcement operation
Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 71/67 (IT) Wednesday, February 21, 2024 The LockBit ransomware gang's website has been seized by law enforcement agencies, who claim to have disrupted the group's operations and will release details of the operation against the group soon. The group's .onion website displays the message "This website is now under the control of law enforcement," specifically the UK's National Crime Agency (NCA). "We can confirm that LockBit's services have been disrupted as a result of international law enforcement action, an ongoing and evolving operation."  The page states that the NCA worked with the FBI and "international law enforcement agencies" under the operation name Cronos.  The page also features the logos of Europol and law enforcement agencies from Australia, Germany, the Netherlands, Japan, France, and Switzerland, along with the flags of those countries, as well as those of Canada, Sweden, and Finland. While the website itself is not the ransomware gang's primary tool, Europol has reportedly been credited with shutting down LockBit. So perhaps Operation Cronos has indeed disrupted LockBit's operations.

CISA warns of Cisco ASA/FTD vulnerability CVE-2020-3259 being exploited by Ransomware.  Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 68/67 (IT) Monday, February 19, 2024.  The U.S. Cybersecurity and Infrastructure Security Agency (CISA) warns that the Akira Ransomware group is exploiting the Cisco ASA/FTD vulnerability CVE-2020-3259 (CVSS score: 7.5) which is commonly exploited, and CISA has added the Cisco ASA/FTD vulnerability to the Known Exploited Vulnerabilities catalog. The vulnerability CVE-2020-3259 is an information disclosure vulnerability in the web services interface of Cisco ASA/FTD. CISA mentioned that the vulnerability is being used in Ransomware campaigns, but did not disclose which Ransomware groups are exploiting it. In January, researchers from cybersecurity firm Truesec reported forensic data showing the Akira Ransomware group exploiting the Cisco ASA (Adaptive Security Appliance) and FTD (Firepower Threat Defence) vulnerability. Attackers can use the vulnerability to extract sensitive information from the device's memory, including usernames and passwords. CISA has ordered government agencies to patch the CVE-2020-3259 vulnerability by March 7, 2024, and advised private sector organizations to inspect and patch the vulnerability in their infrastructure as well.

Microsoft released its February 2024 Patch Tuesday, addressing 72 security vulnerabilities, including 2 zero-days currently being exploited.  Five vulnerabilities are rated Critical, 65 are rated Important, and 2 are rated Moderate. The two vulnerabilities under active attack are: – CVE-2024-21412 (CVSS score 8.1) – Internet Shortcut Files Security Feature Bypass Vulnerability.  This allows unauthenticated attackers to send specially crafted files designed to bypass security checks.  Attackers must trick victims into clicking a link to the file. – CVE-2024-21351 (CVSS score 7.6) – Windows SmartScreen Security Feature Bypass Vulnerability. This allows authorized attackers to bypass SmartScreen. Attackers can exploit this by sending malicious files to users and enticing them to open them.  ZDI has published the full list of CVEs released by Microsoft: https://www.zerodayinitiative.com/blog/2024/2/13/the-february-2024-security-update-review

A ransomware attack shuts down over 100 hospitals in Romania.
Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 64/67 (IT) Thursday, February 15, 2024 Romania confirms that a ransomware attack on the Hipocrate Information System (HIS) has disrupted operations at over 100 hospitals.  The Hipocrate Information System (HIS) is software designed to manage medical activities and administration of hospitals and healthcare institutions. The Romanian Ministry of Health reported that on February 11, a major ransomware attack occurred on the HIS system, resulting in a system crash, encrypting files and databases.  Initially, 21 hospitals were affected, a number later confirmed to have risen to 25. Another 79 hospitals shut down their systems as a precautionary measure. The Romanian Ministry of Health further reported that cybersecurity experts, including those from the National Cyber Security Directorate, are monitoring the situation to prevent other hospitals from being affected. The DNSC reports that the attackers used Phobos Ransomware, also known as Backmydata Ransomware, and demanded 3.5 BTC (approximately 157,000 euros).  It is currently unknown whether the attackers stole sensitive data from the affected entities.

Two taxi drivers involved in the JFK Airport taxi dispatch system hack have been sentenced to prison.  Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 63/67 (IT) Thursday, February 15, 2024. Two taxi drivers accused of participating in a cyberattack scheme targeting the taxi dispatch system at John F. Kennedy International Airport were sentenced to prison by a US court on Monday.  The individuals, Daniel Abayev, was sentenced to 4 years and Peter Leyman to 2 years, a $160,000 fine, and nearly $3.5 million in restitution. Both are US citizens residing in New York. They pleaded guilty in October 2023 to conspiracy to commit computer intrusion, working with two Russians, Aleksandr Derebenetc and Kirill Shipulin, from at least September 2019 to September 2021.  They paid Russian hackers to breach the JFK Airport taxi dispatch system to manipulate the taxi queue, prioritizing drivers who paid Abayev and Leyman. At JFK, taxis wait in a holding lot before being dispatched to terminals based on arrival order, often waiting hours. The scheme allowed some drivers to skip the queue. Officials say up to 1,000 taxis per day used this method, paying $10 each time to jump the line.

Bank of America warns customers of a data breach from one of its service providers.
Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 62/67 (IT) Wednesday, February 14, 2024. Bank of America, one of the leading financial institutions in the country, warned customers of a data breach that may have exposed personal information after Infosys McCamish Systems (IMS), a vendor of Bank of America, was hacked last year.  The compromised personally identifiable information (PII) includes names, addresses, social security numbers, birth dates, and financial information, including account and credit card numbers.  The personal information of approximately 57,028 customers may have been exposed.  Infosys McCamish Systems (IMS) is a subsidiary of Infosys BPM Infosys McCamish, with more than 300,000 employees and customers in over 56 countries.  The incident occurred on November 3, 2023, when IMS systems were affected by a cybersecurity incident involving unauthorized access to IMS systems, resulting in some IMS applications becoming unavailable. On November 4, 2023, the LockBit ransomware group claimed responsibility for the attack on IMS and claimed to have encrypted more than 2,000 systems. A Bank of America spokesperson did not comment when contacted by BleepingComputer.

The U.S. federal government has arrested two men involved in The Warzone RAT operation.  Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 60/67 (IT) Tuesday, February 13, 2024.  The Department of Justice announced the seizure of domains used to sell the Warzone RAT Trojan for remote access.  The seizure is the result of an international law enforcement operation. Federal authorities in Boston seized www.warzone[.]ws and three related domains that sold Warzone RAT malware, a remote access trojan (RAT) that allows cybercriminals to connect to victims' computers for malicious purposes, such as browsing the victim's file system, taking screenshots, logging keystrokes, stealing usernames and passwords, and viewing the victim through their camera, all without the victim's knowledge or consent.  The U.S. investigation led to charges against two men: Daniel Meli (27) and Prince Onyeoziri Odinakachi (31).  Both were charged with selling and supporting Warzone RAT and other malware.  The two were arrested on February 7, 2024, on charges of conspiracy, accessing a protected computer to obtain information, and illegally selling and advertising interception devices.  Each faces a maximum sentence of five years in prison and a $250,000 fine.

The Ransomware group Black Basta claims to have stolen three terabytes of data from Hyundai Motor Europe.  Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 58/67 (IT) Monday, February 12, 2024. BleepingComputer reports that the car manufacturer Hyundai Motor Europe was breached by the Ransomware group Black Basta, which claims to have stolen three terabytes of data from the company. The incident occurred in January when the company experienced IT issues resulting in downtime caused by the ransomware attack. However, the company did not disclose the information. Later, Hyundai informed BleepingComputer that it had experienced a cyberattack without providing details about the incident. Hyundai initiated an investigation into the incident and received assistance from external cybersecurity and legal experts. They also notified relevant local authorities. Hyundai Motor Europe only reported unauthorized access to some parts of the network, allowing attackers to access email addresses, physical addresses, telephone numbers, and vehicle identification numbers of affected individuals, but no financial information has been disclosed.  Previously, in April 2023, Hyundai experienced a data breach affecting Italian and French car owners and customers who booked test drives.

Alert regarding a new Remote Code Execution (RCE) attack in Fortinet SSL VPN.

Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT), the National Computer Security Incident Response Team, has received an alert about a new Remote Code Execution (RCE) vulnerability in Fortinet SSL VPN, CVE-2024-21762, with a Critical severity level (CVSS 9.6).  This vulnerability allows unauthorized attackers to execute code remotely. Affected versions: FortiOS 7.4.0 to 7.4.2, FortiOS 7.2.0 to 7.2.6, FortiOS 7.0.0 to 7.0.13, FortiOS 6.4.0 to 6.4.14, FortiOS 6.2.0 to 6.2.15, all versions of FortiOS 6.0.  Solution: Update software to the patched version: Fortinet has released patches for the affected FortiOS versions. Users should update their software to the latest version as soon as possible. Temporarily disable SSL VPN: For users who cannot update the software immediately, it is recommended to temporarily disable SSL VPN to mitigate the risk from this vulnerability. Sources: https://www.bleepingcomputer.com/…/new-fortinet-rce… https://securityonline.info/cve-2024-21762-cvss-9-6…/... https://www.fortiguard.com/psirt/FG-IR-24-015 https://webboard-nsoc.ncsa.or.th

Critical JetBrains TeamCity On-Premise Vulnerability

Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 56/67 (IT) Friday, February 9, 2024.  JetBrains warns customers about a critical security vulnerability in its TeamCity On-Premises continuous integration and continuous deployment (CI/CD) software that can be exploited.  CVE-2024-23917 has a CVSS score of 9.8. The vulnerability could allow unauthenticated attackers with HTTP(S) access to the TeamCity server to bypass authentication checks and gain administrator privileges. The vulnerability affects all TeamCity On-Premises versions from 2017.1 to 2023.11.2.  The vulnerability was discovered by an unnamed security researcher who was credited with the discovery and reported the vulnerability on January 19, 2024.  The vulnerability has been patched in version 2023.11.3. Users who cannot update their server to version 2023.11.3 can download a security patch plugin to mitigate the vulnerability.  Currently, there is no evidence that this vulnerability has been exploited, but a similar vulnerability in the same product, CVE-2023-42793 (CVSS: 9.8), was exploited last year.

FORTINET Addresses Two Critical Vulnerabilities in FORTISIEM

Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 55/67 (IT) Friday, February 9, 2024.  Cybersecurity vendor Fortinet warns of two critical vulnerabilities in FortiSIEM, tracked as CVE-2024-23108 and CVE-2024-23109 (CVSS score 10), which could lead to remote code execution allowing unauthorized commands to be run via crafted API requests. Affected products are:

* FortiSIEM versions 7.1.0 to 7.1.1
* FortiSIEM versions 7.0.0 to 7.0.2
* FortiSIEM versions 6.7.0 to 6.7.8
* FortiSIEM versions 6.6.0 to 6.6.3
* FortiSIEM versions 6.5.0 to 6.5.2
* FortiSIEM versions 6.4.0 to 6.4.2

In February 2024, Fortinet updated two 2023 advisories on OS Command Injection vulnerabilities affecting FortiSIEM products.  If exploited, these vulnerabilities could allow a remote, unauthenticated attacker to execute commands on the system. Both issues are linked to vulnerability CVE-2023-34992 (CVSS score 9.8), which was addressed in October 2023.

Google fixes remote code execution vulnerability on Android.  Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 54/67 (IT) Thursday, February 8, 2024. Google released Android's February 2024 security patch to address 46 vulnerabilities, including a critical remote code execution vulnerability, CVE-2024-0031.  The vulnerability affects Android Open Source Project (AOSP) versions 11, 12, 12L, 13, and 14. Google has released Android's 2024-02-01 security patch level and Android's 2024-02-05 security patch level to address the issue. The company has released two security patch levels to address some of the vulnerabilities. Users should patch immediately when software updates are available.

Cyberattack Impacts Operations at LURIE Children's Hospital

Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 50/67 (IT) Tuesday, February 6, 2024. A cyberattack on Lurie Children's Hospital in Chicago has taken IT systems offline, seriously impacting operations and disrupting medical care. Lurie Children's Hospital is one of the leading children's hospitals in the United States, with a wide range of specialized medical services including pediatric surgery, oncology, cardiology, neurology, and neonatology. Lurie Children's is also the acute care children's hospital in Chicago with 360 beds and more than 1,665 physicians on the medical staff and 4,000 employees.  The hospital immediately announced its incident response and notified law enforcement. It is working with leading experts to investigate the incident.  Lurie confirmed that the attack disrupted access to the internet, email, phone service, and the hospital's MyChat platform. Currently, no ransomware group has claimed responsibility for the cyberattack on Lurie Children's Hospital. Cyberattacks on hospitals are highly impactful and dangerous.

AnyDesk Remote Desktop Software hacked, users should change passwords. Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 48/67 (IT) Monday, February 5, 2024. AnyDesk, the maker of remote desktop software, revealed on Friday that it was affected by a cyber attack that compromised its production systems. The German company said the incident was investigated and found not to be a ransomware attack, and it has notified relevant authorities. AnyDesk has revoked all passwords to the web portal, my.anydesk[.]com, and recommends that users change their passwords and download the latest version of the software. AnyDesk did not disclose when its systems were breached, and it is currently unknown whether any data was stolen after the attack. AnyDesk has more than 170,000 customers, including Amedes, AutoForm Engineering, LG Electronics, Samsung Electronics, Spidercam, and Thales. This disclosure comes one day after Cloudflare said it was breached by suspected attackers using stolen credentials to gain unauthorized access to Atlassian servers and ultimately access some documents and source code.

Vulnerabilities in WatchGuard and Panda Security products lead to code execution. Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 44/67 (IT) Wednesday, January 31, 2024. Vulnerabilities in WatchGuard and Panda Security products could cause denial of service (DoS) or arbitrary code execution. These vulnerabilities were found in the Panda Kernel Memory Access driver (pskmad_64.sys) installed with WatchGuard EPDR, Panda AD360, and Panda Dome for Windows. There are two vulnerabilities: CVE-2023-6330, a memory pool overflow vulnerability, and CVE-2023-6331, an out-of-bounds write vulnerability. Although both vulnerabilities could lead to code execution, the impact is mitigated because attackers need administrator privileges to exploit them successfully.  Both vulnerabilities have been addressed with the release of WatchGuard EPDR and Panda AD360 version 8.00.22.0023 and Panda Dome version 22.02.01.  More information about the patched vulnerabilities can be found on the WatchGuard security advisory page.

750 million Indian mobile phone user data found for sale on the dark web.  Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 43/67 (IT) Wednesday, January 31, 2024.  CloudSEK, an Indian data security company, claims that last week, data of 750 million mobile network users in India was found on the dark web, with two criminal gangs offering the data for sale for just $3,000. CloudSEK identifies CyboDevil and UNIT8200 as the sellers of the 1.8TB data, which includes mobile subscriber names, phone numbers, addresses, and identification numbers of those in India. CloudSEK's investigative report found that the leak was not caused by a data breach from an Indian telecommunications provider, but the means of obtaining the data are undisclosed. The company says its initial analysis found that the leak will affect all major telecommunications providers because the leak of personally identifiable information (PII) poses a significant risk to both individuals and organizations, which can lead to financial loss, identity theft, reputational damage, and the possibility of cyberattacks.

Kansas public transportation affected by Ransomware.  Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 40/67 (IT) Monday, January 29, 2024.  Kansas City Area Transportation Authority (KCATA) announced it was hit by ransomware on Tuesday, January 23rd.  KCATA is a public transportation agency that operates 78 bus routes with 300 buses.  The company reports 10.5 million riders annually.  The ransomware cyberattack affected the call center, rendering it unable to receive calls.  Although the call center was disrupted, KCATA routes continued to operate normally.  Therefore, passenger transport operations were not affected, and all services continued to operate, including buses and air transportation services.  Following the attack, KCATA contacted relevant agencies and the FBI.  Medusa ransomware claimed responsibility for the attack on KCATA and posted sample data allegedly belonging to KCATA on the dark web.  The attackers gave KCATA 10 days to negotiate a settlement and demanded $2,000,000.  Medusa also offered the option to extend the deadline for publicly releasing the stolen data for $100,000 per day.

Thousands of GitLab servers are vulnerable to Zero-click attacks. The Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 38/67 (IT) on Friday, January 26, 2024, reported that GitLab has released security patches affecting both Community and Enterprise Editions to address a Critical vulnerability, CVE-2023-7028 (CVSS score 10), impacting the following versions: – 16.1 before 16.1.5 – 16.2 before 16.2.8 – 16.3 before 16.3.6 – 16.4 before 16.4.4 – 16.5 before 16.5.6 – 16.6 before 16.6.4 – 16.7 before 16.7.2. CVE-2023-7028 is an authentication bypass vulnerability that allows attackers to send account password reset requests to unverified email addresses, potentially leading to account takeover without user interaction.  The vulnerability has been addressed in GitLab versions 16.7.2, 16.5.6, and 16.6.4, with fixes backported to 16.1.6, 16.2.9, and 16.3.7.  Researchers at ShadowServer reported 5,379 instances exposed online are vulnerable to this flaw, with the majority of vulnerable servers located in the United States (964), Germany (730), and Russia (721).

Critical vulnerability affects Fortra GoAnywhere MFT.  Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 36/67 (IT) Thursday, January 25, 2024. Fortra warns of an authentication bypass vulnerability, CVE-2024-0204 (CVSS score 9.8), affecting the Fortra GoAnywhere MFT (Managed File Transfer) product. Fortra GoAnywhere Managed File Transfer is a solution that provides secure and efficient file management and transfer. It is a centralized platform for managing automated file transfers between different systems and applications, enabling secure and controlled data movement across the enterprise network. Unauthorized users can exploit CVE-2024-0204 to create administrator users using the device's administrative portal.  The vulnerability affects Fortra GoAnywhere MFT 6.x from 6.0.1 and Fortra GoAnywhere MFT 7.4.0 and earlier versions. Fortra has addressed the vulnerability with the release of GoAnywhere MFT 7.4.1. The vulnerability was reported by Mohammed Eldeeb and Islam Elrfai of Spark Engineering Consultants on December 1, 2023. In February 2023, the Clop ransomware group claimed to have stolen sensitive data from more than 130 organizations by exploiting the zero-day vulnerability CVE-2023-0669 in Fortra's GoAnywhere Managed File Transfer secure file transfer tool.

LoanDepot, a US lending company, has had the personal data of approximately 16.6 million customers stolen.

Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 33/67 (IT) reported on Wednesday, January 24, 2024, that LoanDepot, one of the largest retail lenders in the United States, confirmed that the personal information of approximately 16.6 million customers was stolen. The company filed further details with the U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC) on January 22, 2024.  LoanDepot stated that the cyberattack occurred on January 8, 2024, and was a ransomware attack.  The company is still investigating the breach and has enlisted the help of external forensic and cybersecurity experts.  Preliminary investigation results show that "unauthorized third parties gained access to the sensitive personal information of approximately 16.6 million customers in their system." LoanDepot will notify affected customers of the data breach and offer free credit monitoring and identity protection services. The company also stated that it is making progress in restoring its lending and social media lending services. Experts have shown that LoanDepot's website was down briefly before being restored within a few hours.  However, customers unable to use some LoanDepot services have posted on social media expressing their dissatisfaction with the incident.

LockBit ransomware group claims attack on Subway franchise restaurants. Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 32/67 (IT) Tuesday, January 23, 2024. The LockBit ransomware group claims to have hacked Subway, an American franchise restaurant.  LockBit has added Subway to the victim list on the Tor data leak website and has threatened to release the stolen data on February 2, 2024, at 21:44:16 UTC. The group claims to have stolen hundreds of gigabytes of sensitive data, including employee salaries, franchise royalties, master franchise commission payments, restaurant sales figures, and more.  There is currently no information on how the Lockbit ransomware group demanded a ransom from the victim.

VMware Fixes Critical Vulnerability in Aria Automation

Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 28/67 (IT) Friday, January 19, 2024 VMware warned customers of a critical vulnerability affecting its Aria Automation multi-cloud infrastructure automation platform. VMware Aria Automation (formerly vRealize Automation) is a cloud automation platform that simplifies and streamlines the deployment and management of cloud infrastructure and applications. It's a comprehensive platform for automation across various environments, including VMware Cloud on AWS, VMware Cloud on Azure, and VMware Cloud Foundation. VMware has addressed the vulnerability, CVE-2023-34063 (CVSS score 9.9), which affects the Aria Automation platform. The vulnerability is a Missing Access Control issue that can be exploited by authenticated attackers to gain unauthorized remote access to organizations and workflows. The vulnerability was discovered by the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation (CSIRO) team.  CVE-2023-34063 affects versions prior to 8.16 and Cloud Foundation. VMware recommends users update their platform installations to version 8.16.

Atlassian fixes critical RCE vulnerability in older Confluence versions.  Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 26/67 (IT) Thursday, January 18, 2024. Atlassian warns of a Critical vulnerability, CVE-2023-22527 (CVSS score 10.0), in Confluence Data Center and Confluence Server affecting older versions.  This is a template injection vulnerability that could allow attackers to execute arbitrary code on vulnerable Confluence installations.  The vulnerability affects Confluence Data Center and Server versions 8.0.x, 8.1.x, 8.2.x, 8.3.x, 8.4.x, and versions 8.5.0 through 8.5.3.  Supported latest versions of Confluence Data Center and Server are not affected. Atlassian has addressed the vulnerability by releasing versions 8.5.4 (LTS), 8.6.0 (Data Center only), and 8.7.1 (Data Center only) and recommends users update to the latest version.

Experts warn of vulnerability affecting Bosch BCC100 Thermostat devices.  Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 24/67 (IT) Wednesday, January 17, 2024. Researchers from Bitdefender have warned of a high-severity vulnerability affecting Bosch BCC100 Thermostat devices, designated CVE-2023-49722 (CVSS score: 8.3).  The vulnerability was reported to the vendor in August 2023 and patched in November 2023. The thermostat includes two microcontrollers working together: a Hi-Flying HF-LPT230 chip, which handles Wi-Fi functions, and an STMicroelectronics STM32F103 chip, which acts as the central processing unit. Attackers could exploit the vulnerability to send malicious commands to the thermostat device. The vulnerability affects the following products: – Bosch BCC101 CVE-2023-49722 Versions: 4.13.20 – v4.13.33 – Bosch BCC102 CVE-2023-49722 Versions: 4.13.20 – v4.13.33 – Bosch BCC50 CVE-2023-49722 Versions: 4.13.20 – v4.13.33. The vendor addressed the vulnerability by releasing WiFi firmware 4.13.33 and closing port 8899.  Home users should check their IoT devices and consider isolating them from the network, which can be done by setting up a dedicated network for IoT devices.

Apple has patched a vulnerability in the Magic Keyboard that allowed monitoring of Bluetooth traffic.  Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 22/67 (IT) on Tuesday, January 16, 2024, reported that Apple released an update to Firmware 2.0.6 for the Magic Keyboard to address a Bluetooth keyboard injection vulnerability, CVE-2024-0230.  This session management vulnerability could be exploited by attackers to access accessories and spy on Bluetooth traffic. The vulnerability was discovered by Marc Newlin from SkySafe, who stated that an attacker near the victim could exploit unauthenticated Bluetooth to connect to the vulnerable device and inject keystrokes. This could allow actions such as installing apps, executing arbitrary commands, forwarding messages, and more.  The Firmware 2.0.6 update for the Magic Keyboard is available for the standard Magic Keyboard, Magic Keyboard with Numeric Keypad, Magic Keyboard with Touch ID, and Magic Keyboard with Touch ID and Numeric Keypad.

CISA warns that attackers are exploiting a Microsoft SharePoint vulnerability.  Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 19/67 (IT) Monday, January 15, 2024. CISA warns that attackers are currently exploiting a Microsoft SharePoint privilege escalation vulnerability, which can be linked to a critical remote code execution vulnerability, tracked as CVE-2023-29357.  This vulnerability allows remote attackers to gain administrator privileges on unpatched servers. Attackers gain access to a forged JWT authentication token and use it to attack the network, bypassing authentication and allowing them to gain the privileges of authenticated users. Remote attackers can also execute arbitrary code on compromised SharePoint servers through command injection when this flaw is chained with the CVE-2023-24955 SharePoint Server remote code execution vulnerability. Although further details about the exploitation according to CVE-2023-29357 have not been provided, CISA has added the vulnerability to the Known Exploited Vulnerabilities Catalog and now requires US federal agencies to patch the vulnerability by January 31, 2024.

The X account of the Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC) was hacked and used to spread fake news about Bitcoin ETF approval.  Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 18/67 (IT) on Friday, January 12, 2024. Hackers hacked the U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC)'s X account and used it to spread fake news about Bitcoin ETF approval. The post stated, "Today, the SEC granted approval for Bitcoin ETFs for listing," and was quickly deleted.  This fake news immediately impacted the Cryptocurrency industry, with Bitcoin's price temporarily increasing to $48,000 before dropping to around $45,000 after the SEC's denial.  SEC Chair Gensler posted a message from the account disclosing the hack, stating that the SEC has not approved the listing and trading of bitcoin exchange-traded products at this time. It is unclear how the hackers gained access to the SEC's social media account and whether 2FA was used. The SEC has notified law enforcement agencies and is investigating the security breach.

CISA adds Apache Superset vulnerability to Known Exploited Vulnerabilities catalog.  Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 16/67 (IT) Thursday, January 11, 2024. The U.S. Cybersecurity and Infrastructure Security Agency (CISA) has added a vulnerability in Apache Superset, CVE-2023-27524, to the Known Exploited Vulnerabilities (KEV) catalog. Apache Superset is an open-source Data Visualization and Exploration Platform based on the Python Flask Framework. According to Binding Operational Directive (BOD) 22-01: Reducing the Significant Risk of Known Exploited Vulnerabilities, FCEB agencies must remediate this vulnerability by the due date to prevent attacks and exploitation of vulnerabilities in the catalog.  Experts recommend that private organizations also review the catalog to address vulnerabilities in their infrastructure. CISA has ordered federal civilian agencies to fix this vulnerability by January 29, 2024. The agency has added the following vulnerabilities to the (KEV) catalog: – Adobe ColdFusion CVE-2023-38203 and CVE-2023-29300 – Multiple Apple products vulnerability CVE-2023-41990. This issue was exploited as part of Operation Triangulation to target Apple iOS devices – D-Link DSL-2750B Devices Command Injection vulnerability CVE-2016-20017 – Joomla Improper Access Control vulnerability CVE-2023-23752.

Toronto Zoo hit by ransomware attack.

Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 14/67 (IT) Wednesday, January 10, 2024. The Toronto Zoo, Canada's largest zoo, was hit by a ransomware attack on Friday morning, but the attack did not affect animal viewing, the zoo's website, or any operations.  The zoo does not store any credit card information and is investigating whether the incident affected member or donor data. The zoo's website was unaffected and tickets can still be purchased online at torontozoo.com. The incident has been reported to Toronto police. The zoo is working with cybersecurity experts and the City of Toronto's information security office to assess the damage from the attack. On October 27, 2023, the Toronto Public Library was hit by a ransomware attack that left various services, including its website, computers, and digital archives, unavailable.  The attackers stole files containing personal information on staff, customers, volunteers, and donors dating back to 1998.

An attack on ULTRA INTELLIGENCE & COMMUNICATIONS has led to the leak of Swiss Air Force documents.  Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 13/67 (IT) reported on Wednesday, January 10, 2024, that sensitive documents belonging to the Swiss Air Force were leaked on the dark web as a result of a cyberattack.  The BlackCat ransomware group targeted ULTRA INTELLIGENCE & COMMUNICATIONS, a US security provider, and the Swiss Federal Department of Defence confirmed that the Air Force was one of the affected organizations and has launched an investigation. The BlackCat ransomware group stole approximately 30 gigabytes of sensitive documents from the US company.  The leaked documents include a contract between the Swiss Ministry of Defence and the US company worth almost 5 million dollars, and other documents, such as those related to the Ministry of Defence’s purchase of encrypted communication technology for the Air Force.  Among the leaked documents are emails and receipts showing when transactions took place.  The Ministry of Defence confirmed that the operational systems of the armed forces were not affected by the incident.

US mortgage lender LoanDepot faces cyberattack.

Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 12/67 (IT) Tuesday, January 9, 2024. LoanDepot, one of the leading non-bank retail mortgage lenders in the United States, has been the victim of a cyberattack that caused the company to temporarily shut down its IT systems. The attack disrupted online payments.  In response to the attack, LoanDepot investigated and collaborated with law enforcement and forensic experts to confirm the full extent of the breach. Although specific details about the attack haven't been disclosed, it is suspected to be ransomware, where attackers steal sensitive organizational and customer data to pressure the targeted organization into paying a ransom. LoanDepot isn't the first lending victim to be attacked. In November 2023, Mr. Cooper, a lending company, was the victim of a cyberattack affecting the personal data of over 14.7 million customers. As LoanDepot stores sensitive customer information such as financial data and bank accounts, customers should be wary of phishing attacks and identity theft.

A cyberattack occurred at Beirut International Airport, the capital of Lebanon. The attackers compromised the Flight Information Display System (FIDS).

Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 11/67 (IT) reported on Tuesday, January 9, 2024, that hackers attacked Beirut-Rafic Al Hariri International Airport in Lebanon and breached the Flight Information Display System (FIDS). Rafic Hariri International Airport is the main international airport serving Beirut, the capital of Lebanon.  The airport is named after former Lebanese Prime Minister Rafic Hariri and is located approximately 9 kilometers from downtown Beirut. The airport is a major gateway for both domestic and international air travel.  The cyberattack involved hackers posting messages on screens in the airport. The messages claimed that Hezbollah and Iran are pushing the country towards war, disregarding the Lebanese people. The messages also mentioned the smuggling of weapons to be used for bombing the airport.  According to local television station LBCI, the cyberattack also disrupted the baggage screening system, known as the Baggage Handling System (BHS). Airport officials had to use police dogs to complete baggage checks. The cyberattack comes amid heightened tensions between Israel and Lebanon. However, no hacker group has claimed responsibility for the attack so far.

Law firm Orrick, Herrington & Sutcliffe discloses data breach that occurred in early 2023, impacting over 600,000 individuals.

Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 10/67 (IT) Monday, January 8, 2024. Law firm Orrick, Herrington & Sutcliffe has disclosed a data breach that occurred in 2023 impacting 638,000 individuals.  Attackers gained access to the firm's network between February 28, 2023 and March 13, 2023. The attackers were able to access a storage area containing files related to the law firm's clients.  Orrick, Herrington & Sutcliffe LLP is a global law firm serving clients in the technology, energy, and finance sectors on various legal practices including corporate, finance, litigation, intellectual property, and cybersecurity. The firm has offices in several countries. The law firm has notified affected clients.  The information disclosed varies from individual to individual.  Compromised information may include name, address, email address, date of birth, social security number, driver's license or government-issued identification number, passport number, financial account information, taxpayer identification number, medical information and/or diagnoses, claims information (date, cost of service and claim identifier), health insurance.

Ukraine's SBU says Russia hacked surveillance cameras to guide missile attacks on Kyiv
