Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 6/67 (IT) Thursday, January 4, 2024.  Ukraine's SBU revealed that attackers linked to Russia hacked surveillance cameras for espionage.  The SBU disabled two cameras used by Russian air forces to attack Kyiv on January 2nd.  The cameras were installed in a residential building and near a parking lot. Hackers compromised the cameras to spy on air defenses and infrastructure in the same area. They changed the cameras' viewing angles and connected them to the YouTube streaming platform. Since Russia's invasion of Ukraine, the SBU has disabled about 10,000 surveillance cameras that Russia could hack to adjust missile strikes. The SBU urged camera owners to stop online broadcasts from their devices. The agency also asked citizens to report footage detected from such cameras. Radio Free Europe reported that Russian spies accessed video feeds from thousands of surveillance cameras in Ukraine using Russian software known as Trassir.

New version of MEDUZA STEALER data theft tool launched on the DARK WEB. Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 5/67 (IT) Thursday, January 4, 2024.  Resecurity's HUNTER unit has detected the developers of MEDUZA STEALER, a tool used for stealing information, have launched a new version (2.2). This version has significant improvements, including support for more client software (including browser-based cryptocurrency wallets), an upgraded credit card (CC) grabber, and additional advanced operations for transferring password storage data on various platforms to extract credentials and tokens. Meduza is also a major competitor to Azorult, Redline, Racoon, and Vidar Stealer, which are used by cybercriminals for account takeover (ATO), online banking theft, and financial fraud. Those behind the development of Meduza have publicized this upgrade on various DARK WEB forums and Telegram groups. Currently, MEDUZA STEALER also supports Windows Server 2012/2016/2019/2022 and Windows 10/11.

Researchers report attacks on leading companies in Iran.  Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 4/67 (IT) on Wednesday, January 3, 2024, reported from researcher Hudson on December 20th that a hacker named 'irleaks' announced the sale of over 160,000,000 records, claiming to have stolen data from 23 leading insurance companies in Iran.  The stolen data includes first name, last name, date of birth, telephone number, mobile phone number, national ID number, company ID number, and other information.  They also shared sample data with a total price of $60,000. Hudson analyzed the sample data and confirmed that it may be genuine, but there is no clear confirmation of how the hacker targeted so many insurance companies at the same time. On December 30th, irleaks claimed to have hacked SnappFood, Iran's largest platform, stealing 3 terabytes of data, including: - 20,000,000 user records (email, password, phone number) - 51,000,000 user addresses - 600,000 credit card details - 180,000,000 device-related records.

The Black Basta Ransomware decryptor has been released. Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 3/67 (IT) Wednesday, January 3, 2024. Security researchers have released a new toolkit designed to help victims of Black Basta Ransomware. This toolkit can recover stolen files.  SR Labs Research revealed in a recent GitHub post that these tools exploit a weakness in Black Basta's encryption algorithm. Analysis indicates that files can be recovered, whether fully or partially, depending on the file size. Files smaller than 5,000 bytes cannot be recovered.  Files between 5,000 bytes and 1GB can be fully recovered. For files larger than 1GB, the first 5,000 bytes will be lost, but the rest can be recovered.  The tool works when Black Basta encrypts files with only zeros, which is why it only works with larger files. However, the decryption tool will only work with Black Basta Ransomware used in attacks around April 2023. Black Basta is one of the most successful ransomware-as-a-service operations, generating over US$100 million since April 2022.

The INC Ransomware group has claimed responsibility for a data breach at Xerox Corp.

Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 2/67 (IT) Tuesday, January 2, 2024. Xerox Corp is an American multinational company that provides document management solutions worldwide, including multifunction printers, copiers, digital presses, and production printing systems for the graphic communications market and large enterprises. The INC Ransom Ransomware group has claimed an attack on Xerox Corp and threatened to publish stolen data.  The INC Ransom Ransomware group added Xerox to its list of victims on its Tor leak site.  The ransomware group published images of 8 documents, including emails and invoices, as proof of access.  It's currently unclear how much data was stolen from the company. The INC RANSOM group emerged in 2023 and has claimed breaches at more than 40 organizations to date.

St Vincent’s Health Australia, Australia's largest healthcare provider, has experienced a data breach following a cyberattack.

Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 546/66 (IT) Thursday, December 28, 2023. St Vincent’s Health Australia, Australia's largest healthcare provider, was hit by a cyberattack affecting its healthcare system, resulting in a data breach. St Vincent’s Health Australia has reported the incident to authorities and is working with the Australian government to address the cybersecurity incident.  On Tuesday, December 19, 2023, St Vincent’s Health Australia responded to the incident, and on Thursday, December 21, St Vincent’s found evidence that the attackers had deleted some data from the network. They have hired security experts to investigate the attack. Currently, no attackers have claimed responsibility for the attack.

Ubisoft Video game company is investigating a Data Breach incident. Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 544/66 (IT) Tuesday, December 26, 2023. Ubisoft, the game company, is investigating reports of a Data Breach incident after evidence was revealed by researcher vx-underground, who reported on December 20, 2023, that attackers had accessed Ubisoft's infrastructure for approximately 48 hours, after which administrators blocked the attackers following detection of the attack. Ubisoft is a renowned video game company in the gaming industry, known for developing, publishing, and distributing a variety of video games on various platforms including PC, mobile devices, etc. Ubisoft has created popular games such as Assassin's Creed, Tom Clancy's Rainbow Six Siege, Far Cry, Watch Dogs, and many more. The attackers claimed to have access to the company's Microsoft Teams, Confluence, and SharePoint installations and planned to steal approximately 900GB of data from the game company. Ubisoft was previously attacked in March 2022, which severely impacted games, systems, and services by the Lapsus$ group, who claimed to have stolen the company's internal data. Another incident occurred in October 2020, when the Egregor ransomware group claimed to have attacked game developer Crytek and released files allegedly stolen from Ubisoft.

LockBit Ransomware group claims to have hacked accounting firm Xeinadin.  Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 542/66 (IT) Monday, December 25, 2023.  The LockBit Ransomware group has claimed responsibility for hacking the accounting firm Xeinadin and threatened to release stolen data. Xeinadin has over 60,000 clients across the UK and Ireland.  In 2021, it received a significant endorsement from Exponent, one of the leading private equity investors in the UK, which made the company one of the top 20 accounting firms in the country. The LockBit Ransomware group claims to have stolen 1.5 terabytes of Xeinadin customer data. The stolen data includes: – All internal databases – Customer financials – Passports – Account balances – Clients' personal accounts – Xeinadin's Companies House – Clients' legal information.  The group has threatened to publish the company's data if the company does not contact them by December 25, 2023. It will be published on the Tor leak site.

A data breach at healthcare software provider ESO Solutions has impacted 2.7 million individuals.  Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 540/66 (IT) Friday, December 22, 2023. ESO Solutions, a provider of software products for healthcare organizations, disclosed that patient data of 2.7 million individuals was accessed in a ransomware attack that occurred on September 28. During the investigation, ESO Solutions found that the attackers accessed a device containing sensitive personal information. On October 23, the company reported that the data compromised by the ransomware affected patients associated with its clients, including hospitals and clinics in the United States. The disclosed information includes: – Name – Date of Birth – Phone number – Patient account/medical record number – Type and date of injury – Diagnostic information – Treatment type and date – Procedural information – Social Security number (SSN). The company has notified the FBI and state authorities of the incident, and all affected customers were notified on December 12.  Fifteen healthcare providers have confirmed being impacted by the ransomware attack on ESO. Currently, no ransomware group has claimed responsibility for the attack on ESO.

Comcast's Xfinity customer data exposed after Citrix Bleed attack.  Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 538/66 (IT) Thursday, December 21, 2023. Comcast's Xfinity has disclosed a data breach following a cyberattack exploiting the Citrix Bleed vulnerability. The company has notified customers about the compromise resulting from the cyberattack. Citrix Bleed is a critical vulnerability, CVE-2023-4966, in Citrix NetScaler ADC (Application Delivery Controller) software that allows unauthorized attackers to exploit the vulnerability to access sensitive data and systems.  The vulnerability was discovered by security experts at Positive Technologies and disclosed to Citrix on October 10, 2023. Citrix released patches to address the vulnerability on November 15, 2023.  Xfinity is a brand of Comcast Cable Communications, LLC, a subsidiary of Comcast Corporation. Xfinity offers a variety of services such as cable TV, internet, telephone, and home security. It is a major high-speed internet and cable TV provider in the United States. On December 6, 2023, the company reported that the compromised data included usernames and passwords, as well as other information such as names, contact information, social security numbers, dates of birth, and secret questions and answers.  The company recommends that customers reset their passwords and enable multi-factor authentication.

Interpol arrests 3,500 cybercriminals and seizes $300 million.  Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 537/66 (IT) Thursday, December 21, 2023. An international law enforcement operation codenamed ‘Operation HAECHI IV’ has led to the arrest of 3,500 low-level cybercrime suspects and the seizure of $300 million in illicit proceeds. South Korean authorities led the HAECHI operation and worked with law enforcement agencies from 34 countries, including the United States, United Kingdom, Japan, Hong Kong, China, and India. The latest operation, which took place between July and December 2023, targeted threat groups involved in voice phishing attacks, romance scams, online sextortion, investment fraud, money laundering related to illegal online gambling, business email compromise, and e-commerce fraud.  Arrests made during this operation involved online gambling criminals in Manila, whom Korean police had been pursuing for over two years.  Operation HAECHI IV saw a 260% increase in arrests compared to HAECHI III, which took place between June and November 2022. Interpol and its partners arrested 975 suspects during that operation and seized $130,000,000.

Mr. Cooper Data Breach Affects 14.7 Million Customers

Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 536/66 (IT) Wednesday, December 20, 2023. Mr. Cooper (formerly Nationstar Mortgage LLC) is a Dallas-based residential mortgage company with 9,000 employees and millions of customers. It is one of the largest servicers in the United States, servicing over $937 billion in loans.  The company has issued a data breach notification warning of a cyberattack that exposed the information of 14.7 million customers who have mortgages with the company. In response to the incident, the company shut down its entire IT system, including the online payment portal used to pay mortgages, for over a week. Further disclosures about the incident revealed that the company found evidence that attackers accessed customer information. The company has reported to the Attorney General's office that the incident affected over 14.7 million customers. The exposed information includes:

* Full name
* Address
* Phone number
* Social Security number (SSN)
* Date of birth
* Bank account number

The exposed information may put affected individuals at risk of phishing, scams, and social engineering. Customers should be wary of scams.  At this time, no further details have been released about the type of cyberattack, and no ransomware group has claimed responsibility for the attack on Mr. Cooper.

MongoDB suffers security breach.  Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 534/66 (IT) Tuesday, December 19, 2023. MongoDB, a US-based company that develops open-source NoSQL database management systems, has disclosed a cyberattack on some of its corporate systems. The company is investigating the security incident, which involved unauthorized access to corporate systems, resulting in the disclosure of customer account metadata and contact information. The company detected the attack on December 13, 2023, and immediately began responding to the incident. It was also found that this unauthorized access attempt had been occurring for some time before it was discovered.  MongoDB further reported that there have been high-level login attempts which have caused problems for customers trying to log into Atlas.  It has warned customers to be wary of social engineering and phishing attacks, as well as to use multi-factor authentication (MFA) and change their MongoDB Atlas passwords.

Sophos backports RCE fix after attacks on unsupported firewalls. Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 532/66 (IT) Friday, December 15, 2023. Sophos has updated the CVE-2022-3236 vulnerability for end-of-life (EOL) firewall firmware versions after hackers were found to be exploiting the vulnerability.  This is a code injection vulnerability in the User Portal and Webadmin of Sophos Firewall that allows remote code execution. Although Sophos automatically patched devices configured to accept automatic security updates by January 2023, more than 4,000 devices remain vulnerable. These devices are older models running EOL firmware requiring manual patching. Hackers have exploited this vulnerability to scan for EOL devices and firmware from vendors. Therefore, it is highly recommended that organizations update EOL devices and firmware to the latest version. If using an older version of Sophos Firewall, it is recommended to update to one of the following Sophos Firewall versions: – v19.0 GA, MR1 and MR1-1 – v18.5 GA, MR1, MR1-1, MR2, MR3 and MR4 – v18.0 MR3, MR4, MR5 and MR6 – v17.5 MR12, MR13, MR14, MR15, MR16 and MR17 – v17.0 MR10.

A new hacker group, "GambleForce," is using SQL injection attacks to target organizations in the APAC region.  The Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 531/66 (IT), Friday, December 15, 2023, and Group-IB have discovered this previously unknown hacker group.  They have been linked to SQL injection attacks against companies in the Asia-Pacific (APAC) region, stealing sensitive data such as user credentials.  These operations have been ongoing since at least September 2023. They have also exploited CVE-2023-23752, a medium-severity vulnerability in the Joomla CMS.  The group has targeted 24 organizations across various sectors, including government, retail, and tourism, in countries such as Australia, Brazil, China, India, Indonesia, the Philippines, South Korea, and Thailand, with six successful attacks. GambleForce's modus operandi involves using specific open-source tools such as dirsearch, sqlmap, Tinyproxy, and redis-rogue-getshell in various stages of the attack, with the ultimate goal of exfiltrating sensitive data from compromised networks. The attackers also utilize a legitimate post-exploitation framework called Cobalt Strike.  Interestingly, versions of the tools found on the attack infrastructure use Chinese-language commands, although the origin of the group remains unclear.

December 2023 Microsoft Patch Tuesday releases fixes for 4 critical vulnerabilities.

Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 530/66 (IT) Thursday, December 14, 2023. The December 2023 Microsoft Patch Tuesday security update addressed 33 vulnerabilities across multiple products affecting Microsoft Windows and Windows Components. It also fixed several Chromium issues. Four of these vulnerabilities were rated Critical, and 29 were rated Important. Microsoft highlighted Critical vulnerabilities affecting MSHTML: – CVE-2023-35628 – Windows MSHTML Platform Remote Code Execution Vulnerability – CVE-2023-36019 – Microsoft Power Platform Connector Spoofing Vulnerability – CVE-2023-35636 – Microsoft Outlook Information Disclosure Vulnerability. Experts said none of the vulnerabilities fixed in the December 2023 Microsoft Patch Tuesday security update were exploited.

Apple releases iOS 17.2 with urgent security patches. Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 527/66 (IT) Wednesday, December 13, 2023.  On Monday, Apple released iOS and iPadOS with security patches to address several serious vulnerabilities that exposed mobile users to malicious attacks from malicious hackers.  The latest iOS 17.2 and iPadOS 17.2 fix at least 11 documented security vulnerabilities, the most serious of which is a memory corruption issue in ImageIO that could lead to arbitrary code execution when processing certain images. The iOS 17.2 release also addresses code execution vulnerabilities in the WebKit rendering engine and memory security issues that allowed applications to break out of the device's sandbox. The company also fixed a privacy issue in Accounts, an information disclosure issue in AVEVideoEncoder, an extension suite that allowed access to sensitive user data, and a Siri flaw that allowed attackers with physical access using voice bots to access sensitive user information.

Atlassian has found 4 new RCE vulnerabilities in its products.

Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 524/66 (IT) Friday, December 8, 2023. Atlassian, an Australian software company, has disclosed 4 vulnerabilities that allow Remote Code Execution (RCE). Security patches have been released to address these Remote Code Execution (RCE) vulnerabilities. The details of the vulnerabilities are as follows:

– CVE-2022-1471 (CVSS score: 9.8) is an RCE vulnerability in the SnakeYAML library that affects several products. Many Atlassian data center and server products use the SnakeYAML library for Java, which is vulnerable to deserialization that can lead to RCE (Remote Code Execution).
– CVE-2023-22522 (CVSS score: 9.0) is an RCE vulnerability in Confluence Data Center and Confluence Server.
– CVE-2023-22523 (CVSS score: 9.8) If exploited, this vulnerability allows attackers to perform RCE (Remote Code Execution) by gaining privileges on the machine where the Assets Discovery agent is installed.
– CVE-2023-22524 (CVSS score: 9.6) All versions of the Atlassian Companion app for MacOS, except version 2.0.0, are affected by the Remote Code Execution (RCE) vulnerability CVE-2023-22524. This allows attackers to use WebSockets to bypass the Atlassian Companion and MacOS Gatekeeper block lists to allow code execution.

It is not clear whether all of these vulnerabilities have been exploited in the wild.

Nissan is investigating a cyberattack on its systems in Australia and New Zealand that may have allowed hackers to access personal information.  The details of the attack have not been disclosed, but the company has notified customers of its Nissan Oceania branch of a potential data breach, warning them of the risk of scams in the coming days. Nissan Oceania is the regional unit responsible for distribution, marketing, and services in Australia and New Zealand.  Statements from the company were published on the main page of both the nissan.com.au and nissan.co.nz websites, announcing that Nissan Corporation systems and financial services in Australia and New Zealand were impacted by a cybersecurity incident. The notice states that the company has assembled an incident response team to determine the impact of the cyberattack, including whether any personal information was accessed. Due to the significant risk of customer data compromise, Nissan is warning about potential scams targeting account holders and the possibility of account takeovers.

Google fixes critical zero-click RCE vulnerability in Android security updates December 2023
Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 520/66 (IT) Wednesday, December 6, 2023 Google released Android security updates in December 2023. Google has fixed 85 vulnerabilities, including a critical zero-click remote code execution (RCE) vulnerability at CVE-2023-40088. This vulnerability is in the Android system, allowing attackers to exploit it to execute arbitrary code on vulnerable devices without user interaction. Google also mentioned the following important vulnerabilities: Vulnerabilities in Framework components – CVE-2023-40077 Severity Critical Updated AOSP versions 11, 12, 12L, 13, 14 – CVE-2023-40076 Severity Critical Updated AOSP versions 14 Vulnerabilities in System components – CVE-2023-45866 Severity Critical Updated AOSP versions 11, 12, 12L, 13, 14 Vulnerabilities in Qualcomm open source components – CVE-2022-40507 Critical Closed-source component Android users should update to fix the vulnerabilities as soon as patches are publicly released.

The UK government has strongly denied reports that the Sellafield nuclear plant has been targeted by malware for years.  A report published in the Guardian claimed the controversial complex was hacked by "cyber threat groups linked to Russia and China" and that malware was detected in 2015, possibly existing earlier. The report said dormant, embedded malware in an unspecified system could have exposed information related to nuclear material movements and security.  The UK government statement affirmed that "there is no record or evidence that Sellafield Limited's network has been subject to a successful attack from cyber threat groups, as has been reported by the Guardian." It added, "Our monitoring systems are robust and we have high confidence that no such malware exists on our systems. All of our systems and servers have multiple layers of protection. The critical networks that allow us to operate safely are isolated from our general IT network. This means that an attack on our IT systems would not be able to penetrate these networks.”

Rhysida ransomware group hacks King Edward VII's Hospital in London. Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 516/66 (IT) Friday, December 1, 2023. King Edward VII's Hospital is a private hospital located on Beaumont Street in the Marylebone district of London. It provides specialist medical treatment focusing on musculoskeletal health, the urinary system, women's health, and digestive health.  This hospital has a long history, dating back to when the Prince of Wales (later King Edward VII) founded it in 1899 to provide high-quality medical care to the working class. The Rhysida ransomware group claims to have hacked King Edward VII's Hospital in London and added it to the list on their Tor leak site. The ransomware group has published evidence in the form of images of stolen documents, including medical reports, registration forms, X-rays, prescriptions, medical reports, and others.  The ransomware group claims to have stolen a large amount of sensitive data, including the data of many patients and employees, including the medical records of members of the royal family, and is about to auction the data for 10 BTC.  Typically, the ransomware group plans to sell the stolen data to a single buyer and will publicly disclose the data within seven days of the announcement. Recently, the Rhysida ransomware group added the British Library and China Energy Engineering Corporation to the list of victims on their Tor leak site.

Exploitation of critical ownCloud vulnerability begins. Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 514/66 (IT) Thursday, November 30, 2023. Attackers have started exploiting an ownCloud vulnerability after its public disclosure.  The vulnerability, CVE-2023-49103, resides in the Graphapi app and allows attackers to retrieve sensitive information, including credentials, license keys, and other system data.  This affects Graphapi versions 0.2.0 through 0.3.0 and cannot be mitigated by disabling the Graphapi app.  Changing passwords for admin accounts, access keys, and credentials for email servers and databases is required. The vulnerability was disclosed on November 21, along with two other critical vulnerabilities in the software (CVE-2023-49104 and CVE-2023-49105). On Monday, the US cybersecurity agency CISA added the vulnerabilities to its weekly report, although a severity rating hasn't been assigned yet.  Shadowserver Foundation, a non-profit cybersecurity organization, warns that it has identified approximately 11,000 ownCloud instances exposed on the internet that are potentially at risk.  The largest number of instances are located in Germany (2,000), followed by the United States (1,400), and France (1,300). Russia, Poland, the Netherlands, Italy, the United Kingdom, Canada, and Spain also have exposed instances. Shadowserver warned that the vulnerability is very easy to exploit and advised administrators to follow the mitigation steps outlined by ownCloud.

GoTitan botnet spotted exploiting recent Apache ActiveMQ vulnerability. Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 513/66 (IT) Thursday, November 30, 2023. A recently disclosed security vulnerability affecting Apache ActiveMQ is being exploited by attackers to spread a new Go-based botnet called GoTitan, as well as a .NET program known as PrCtrl Rat, which can remotely control malware-infected hosts.  The attack involves exploiting a remote code execution vulnerability (CVE-2023-46604, CVSS score: 10.0) that has been used in attacks by various hacker groups, including the Lazarus group, in recent weeks. After a successful breach, the threat actors are found to drop further payloads from remote servers. One of these is GoTitan, a botnet designed to orchestrate distributed denial-of-service (DDoS) attacks via protocols such as HTTP, UDP, TCP, and TLS. Fortinet has also observed cases where vulnerable Apache ActiveMQ servers are being targeted to deploy another DDoS botnet called Ddostf, Kinsing malware for cryptojacking, and a command-and-control (C2) framework named Sliver. Another prominent malware delivered is a remote access trojan called PrCtrl Rat that establishes contact with a C2 server to receive further instructions for actions on the system, such as collecting data files and downloading and uploading files from the server.

Cyberattack on MSP CTS May Impact Hundreds of UK Law Firms

Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 510/66 (IT) Tuesday, November 28, 2023. A cyberattack targeting CTS, a managed service provider (MSP) for UK law firms, may have impacted hundreds of them.  CTS provides IT services to the UK legal sector. The company announced it is investigating a cyberattack that caused service disruption. The incident impacted a portion of its services and may affect hundreds of UK law firms. The company is receiving assistance from a cyber forensics firm. CTS plans to restore all services; however, it hasn’t provided a definite timeline for full recovery. Estate Agent Today reported that attackers may have exploited the CitrixBleed vulnerability (CVE-2023-4966).  This vulnerability allowed attackers to gain initial access to the organization’s infrastructure. On October 10th, Citrix published information about the critical CVE-2023-4966 vulnerability in Citrix NetScaler ADC/Gateway devices. MSPs are high-value targets for threat actors aiming to carry out supply chain attacks.

A worm released by Russian hackers is spreading globally.  Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 505/66 (IT) Friday, November 24, 2023. A Russian-backed hacker group targeting Ukrainian entities has been using malware for espionage. Whether accidentally or intentionally, the worm-type malware has spread to organizations in other countries. This group, known by various names such as Gamaredon, Primitive Bear, ACTINIUM, Armageddon, and Shuckworm, has been operating since at least 2014 and has been identified as a Russian state security service hacking group.  One of the tools used in the attacks against Ukraine is a worm called LitterDrifter.  This malware, written in Visual Basic Scripting, is designed to spread from one computer to another via USB drives and has two functions: to spread from USB drive to USB drive and to spread itself to devices connected to those drives.  The malware constantly communicates with command-and-control servers operated by the Gamaredon group.  The Gamaredon group focuses its attacks on various Ukrainian targets, but due to the nature of the worm, researchers have observed its spread to countries such as the United States, Vietnam, Chile, Poland, and Germany.  Researchers have also observed evidence of spread in Hong Kong. This may indicate that LitterDrifter is spreading beyond the intended targets of the Russian hackers.

The Canadian government has been impacted by data breaches from two contractors.

Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 502/66 (IT) Wednesday, November 22, 2023. The Canadian government announced that two contractors, Brookfield Global Relocation Services (BGRS) and SIRVA Worldwide Relocation & Moving Services, experienced security breaches in October, resulting in the disclosure of sensitive government employee data.  This data included information on current and former government employees, members of the Canadian Armed Forces, and Canadian police officers. The government has not yet disclosed the name of the ransomware groups that breached the two companies, but the LockBit Ransomware group has claimed responsibility for the attack on SIRVA, claiming to have stolen over 1.5 TB of data. In response to the security breaches, the Canadian government is offering credit monitoring services and issuing passports to those affected by the incidents. The government advises individuals who may be affected to: – Update login credentials used with BGRS or SIRVA Canada – Enable multi-factor authentication on accounts used for online transactions – Monitor financial and personal online accounts for unusual activity.

U.S. National Security Laboratory Employee Data Leaked
Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 501/66 (IT) Wednesday, November 22, 2023.  The hacker group SiegedSec has disclosed the personal information of thousands of employees at the Idaho National Laboratory (INL), a nuclear research laboratory and an agency of the U.S. Department of Energy.  In a post, SiegedSec claimed to have accessed the data of hundreds of thousands of users, employees, and members of the public, including names, social security numbers, bank account information, and addresses.  They posted samples of the leaked data, but it cannot be confirmed whether SiegedSec possesses the large dataset they claim to have stolen.  An INL spokesperson confirmed the breach and stated that the laboratory is still investigating the incident.  They indicated that the breach impacted a server supporting the Oracle HCM system, which supports INL's human resources applications, and that they took immediate action to protect employee data.  The hackers did not state their reason for targeting INL. However, the breach raises serious national security concerns, as INL employees and scientists work on some of the United States' most sensitive national security projects, including protecting critical infrastructure, such as the U.S. power grid, from cyber and physical attacks.  Personal information, such as detailed employee and banking information, is a treasure trove for foreign intelligence agencies seeking to penetrate the laboratory.

Yamaha Motor confirms Data Breach following Ransomware attack. Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 500/66 (IT) Tuesday, November 21, 2023. Personal information of employees of Yamaha Motor's affiliate in the Philippines was stolen due to a ransomware attack targeting the affiliate. The incident occurred on October 25th and affected a server managed by Yamaha Motor Philippines, the motorcycle manufacturing and sales affiliate in the country. On November 16th, it was revealed that some personal information stored by Yamaha Motor Philippines was stolen. Yamaha did not specify the ransomware group responsible for the attack, but the INC Ransom group claimed responsibility.  According to SentinelOne, the INC Ransom group exploited the CVE-2023-3519 vulnerability, a critical Citrix NetScaler ADC and Gateway vulnerability disclosed in July. Last week, the INC Ransom group published data allegedly stolen from Yamaha Motor Philippines, including identification documents, employee badges, and various internal documents. In recent months, the ransomware group has claimed responsibility for hacking into several organizations, including WellLife Network, Decatur Independent School District, Guardian Alarm, EFU Life Assurance, and Global Export Marketing.

Israeli man sentenced to 80 months in US for role in massive phishing campaign.  Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 499/66 (IT) Tuesday, November 21, 2023.  52-year-old Aviram Azari was sentenced to 80 months in prison for computer intrusion, internet fraud, and theft of sensitive data. He participated in a large-scale spearphishing campaign targeting companies and individuals in the United States and around the world. The man was arrested in September 2019 while entering the United States. From approximately November 2014 to September 2019, Mr. Azari participated in phishing campaigns targeting individuals and companies in the United States and globally. He paid various hacking groups, including some based in India, to send phishing emails to victims of various projects. Upon successfully accessing victims' accounts, they would send the victim's information to Mr. Azari, who then disseminated the information to the media.  Officials obtained evidence of over 100 successful attacks by Azari's targets but believe the number of those hacked may be as high as 100 times that amount.

Google warns hackers exploited Zimbra zero-day vulnerability in attacks on government organizations.

Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 498/66 (IT) Monday, November 20, 2023. Google's Threat Analysis Group (TAG) has discovered that attackers exploited a zero-day vulnerability in Zimbra Collaboration email servers to steal sensitive data from government systems in several countries. Hackers were found to have exploited this vulnerability, CVE-2023-37580 (moderate severity), since June 29th.  A fix was released on July 25th with version 8.8.15 Patch 41 of the software, leaving almost a month for the issue to be exploited.  The vulnerability is an XSS (cross-site scripting) issue in the Zimbra Classic Web Client.  According to Google's threat analysts, attackers exploited systems belonging to governments in Greece, Moldova, Tunisia, Vietnam, and Pakistan to steal email data, user credentials, and authentication tokens. Google's report did not reveal many details about the attackers, but warned about the importance of timely updates even for moderate severity vulnerabilities, as attackers can use them for further attacks.  The exploitation of CVE-2023-37580 is one of several examples of XXS vulnerabilities used to target mail servers, such as CVE-2022-24682 and CVE-2023-5631 affecting Zimbra and Roundcube.

Google reveals 'Reptar' vulnerability in Intel CPUs.  Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 497/66 (IT) on Monday, November 20, 2023.  Google's information security engineering team has discovered a new security vulnerability in Intel CPUs that could allow attackers to run code on vulnerable systems. Google has named this vulnerability "Reptar," and it affects a large number of Intel CPUs, including those used in cloud computing environments. Reptar, identified as CVE-2023-23583, allows attackers to leak information from the system vulnerability and use it to steal sensitive data such as credit card numbers, passwords, etc. Google has notified Intel and other industry players about this issue and has implemented mitigations and issued guidance to confirm the problem. They explained that the issue was found in certain Intel processors due to an error in the CPU's handling of redundant prefixes.  The company has released patches for this issue.  This CPU vulnerability affects several Intel desktop, mobile, and server CPUs, including the 10th Gen Intel® Core™ processor family, 3rd Gen Intel® Xeon® Scalable processors, Intel® Xeon® D processors, and 11th Gen Intel® Core™ processor family, and CPUs used in cloud computing environments, etc. The company is working on a long-term fix, but in the meantime, users are advised to patch their devices immediately.

Samsung Experiences Data Breach

Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 496/66 (IT) Friday, November 17, 2023 Samsung Electronics experienced a data breach that exposed customer personal information without authorization.  The data breach was discovered on November 13, 2023, and affects customers who purchased products from the Samsung UK online store between July 1, 2019, and June 30, 2020.  Attackers exploited a vulnerability in an application, the name of which the company did not specify. The company informed customers that affected information may include name, phone number, address, and email address, stating that financial information was not affected.  A Samsung spokesperson told BleepingComputer that the security breach is limited to the United Kingdom and affects only e-store customers. Customers in the United States were not affected by the breach.

CISA adds vulnerabilities in Juniper devices to the Known Exploited Vulnerabilities catalog.  Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 492/66 (IT) Wednesday, November 15, 2023. CISA has added 6 vulnerabilities to the Known Exploited Vulnerabilities catalog, including 5 affecting Juniper Junos OS and 1 affecting the support software SysAid SysAid IT. The vulnerabilities are as follows: – CVE-2023-47246 SysAid Server Path Traversal Vulnerability – CVE-2023-36844 Juniper Junos OS EX Series PHP External Variable Modification Vulnerability – CVE-2023-36845 Juniper Junos OS EX Series and SRX Series PHP External Variable Modification Vulnerability – CVE-2023-36846 Juniper Junos OS SRX Series Missing Authentication for Critical Function Vulnerability – CVE-2023-36847 Juniper Junos OS EX Series Missing Authentication for Critical Function Vulnerability – CVE-2023-36851 Juniper Junos OS SRX Series Missing Authentication for Critical Function Vulnerability. FCEB agencies must remediate the identified vulnerabilities by the due date to protect networks from exploitation of vulnerabilities in the catalog. Experts also recommend that private organizations review the catalog to address vulnerabilities in their infrastructure. CISA has ordered federal agencies to remediate the vulnerabilities by November 17, 2023, while the SysAid Server Path Traversal vulnerability must be remediated by December 4, 2023.

Australia's major ports disrupted by cyberattack.  Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 490/66 (IT) Tuesday, November 14, 2023 reported a cyberattack on DP World Australia, a major Australian transportation company.  This may be a ransomware attack. It has resulted in disruptions at major ports. In response to the attack, DP World disconnected systems from the internet and shut down ground operations at ports in Sydney, Melbourne, Fremantle, and Brisbane.  Darren Goldie, Australia's National Cyber Security Coordinator, said ships could still load and unload containers, but could not leave port. The Australian government is currently assisting the company in restoring normal operations. DP World has not disclosed any information about the attack.  Although the shutdown is in response to a ransomware attack, renowned researcher Kevin Beaumont has reported it as a ransomware attack and that attackers exploited a recently disclosed Citrix Netscaler vulnerability called CitrixBleed, which has been widely exploited in attacks.

The LOCKBIT ransomware group has published data stolen from Boeing.  The Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 489/66 (IT) reported on Tuesday, November 14, 2023, that at the end of October, the Lockbit ransomware group added Boeing to the list of victims on its data leak site. The group claimed to have stolen a large amount of sensitive data from the company and threatened to publish it if the company did not contact them by a deadline of November 2, 2023, later extended to November 10, 2023.  In early November 2023, Boeing confirmed that its services division had been affected by a cyberattack and said that the investigation was ongoing. The attack targeted elements of the parts and distribution business run by the global services division, and the company reported the incident to law enforcement and relevant regulatory bodies.  However, Boeing refused to pay the ransom demanded, and the LockBit group has now published over 40GB of data. Bleeping Computer analyzed the leaked data and reported that it mostly consists of backups for various systems. The most recent document in the leak is dated October 22, 2023.  It is currently unclear how the attackers breached the company, but some experts speculate that they may have exploited the CVE-2023-4966 vulnerability in Citrix NetScaler ADC/Gateway devices. Researchers at Mandiant have observed zero-day exploitation of this vulnerability since late August.

Police seize BulletProftLink phishing-as-a-service (PhaaS) platform. Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 488/66 (IT) Monday, November 13, 2023. The BulletProftLink phishing-as-a-service (PhaaS) platform with over 300 phishing templates has been seized, according to the Royal Malaysia Police.  In September 2021, Microsoft reported a large-scale phishing campaign which such a service could facilitate, offering numerous templates for buyers. The service also collected all credentials stolen by members (1,618 at the time) from phishing attacks. With assistance from the Australian Federal Police and the FBI, Malaysian police were able to operate and disrupt several domains used by the illicit storefront. Police arrested eight suspects on November 6. Officials also seized digital wallets worth approximately $213,000, servers, computers, jewelry, vehicles, and payment cards.  With the servers seized, law enforcement can examine them to identify users of the platform, some of whom paid a $2,000 monthly subscription fee to access the logs.  These phishing pages also proxied their pages through legitimate cloud services, such as Google Cloud and Microsoft Azure, to evade security tools.

Russia's state-owned Sberbank hit by 1 million RPS DDoS attack.

Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 486/66 (IT) Friday, November 10, 2023. Sberbank, a Russian financial institution, announced that it had faced the most intense Distributed Denial of Service (DDoS) attack two weeks ago.  Sberbank is a majority state-owned banking and financial services company and the largest institution in Russia, holding about one-third of all assets in the country.  Following the Russian invasion of Ukraine, the bank has faced international sanctions and has been the target of hacktivists several times.  Russian news agency Interfax reported that the attack reached one million requests per second (RPS). The latest damage caused Russia's financial system related to the National Payment Card System (NSPK), the provider of Mir cards, to become unavailable on October 30, 2023. They later deleted a post about a data breach affecting customers.  The NSPK told the media that the attackers were unable to steal sensitive customer data, as the website did not store such information, and assured that the cyberattack did not affect the payment system. TheRecord later reported that hacktivists from the 'DumpForums' group and the Ukrainian Alliance Cyber Alliance claimed responsibility for the attack, claiming to have stolen 31 GB of data.

MARINA BAY SANDS luxury hotel in Singapore experiences data breach.  Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 483/66 (IT) Thursday, November 9, 2023. The luxury hotel Marina Bay Sands (MBS) in Singapore experienced a data breach affecting 665,000 customers. The hotel discovered the security breach on October 20, 2023, where malicious actors accessed some customer loyalty program member data on October 19 and 20, 2023. The hotel's security team immediately investigated the incident.  Based on their investigation, there is currently no evidence that the unauthorized actors misused the information to harm customers. The hotel does not believe that member information from the Sands Rewards Club casino rewards program was affected. The disclosed information includes: name, email address, phone number, country of residence, and membership number. The hotel will notify affected customers about the issue and report the incident to relevant authorities in Singapore and other relevant countries.  Currently, the hotel has not disclosed technical details about the incident.

Experts warn ransomware groups are exploiting vulnerabilities in Atlassian and Apache.

Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 481/66 (IT) Wednesday, November 8, 2023. Rapid7, a cybersecurity firm, has observed multiple ransomware groups starting to exploit recently disclosed vulnerabilities in Atlassian Confluence and Apache ActiveMQ, vulnerability numbers CVE-2023-22518 and CVE-2023-22515. Both vulnerabilities are critical, allowing attackers to create unauthorized Confluence administrator accounts and cause data loss.  On November 6, Atlassian updated its advisory, noting multiple instances of the vulnerability being exploited and is adjusting the vulnerability's CVSS score from 9.8 to 10.0, indicating maximum severity.  The escalation is due to a change in the attack scope, with numerous threat actors and exploits targeting vulnerable internet-facing Atlassian Confluence servers to retrieve malicious payloads hosted on remote servers, which leads to the execution of ransomware payloads on compromised servers.  Data collected by GreyNoise indicates that exploitation attempts originate from IP addresses in three different countries: France, Hong Kong, and Russia.

Iranian hackers launch destructive cyberattacks against Israel's technology and education sectors.

Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 480/66 (IT) Tuesday, November 7, 2023.  Israel's education and technology sectors were targeted by destructive cyberattacks in October.  The attacks were carried out by Iranian hackers known as Agonizing Serpens, also known as Agrius, BlackShadow, and Pink Sandstorm (formerly Americium).  Their attacks are characterized by the theft of sensitive data, such as personally identifiable information (PII) and intellectual property.  According to Palo Alto Networks Unit 42, as told to The Hacker News, Agonizing Serpens APT used public and custom tools like Sqlextractor, WinSCP, and PuTTY, and released wiper malware:

– MultiLayer, a .NET malware that identifies files for deletion or corruption with random data to prevent recovery and render systems unusable.
– PartialWasher, a C++ malware that scans drives and wipes specified folders and subfolders.
– BFG Agonizer, malware that relies on open-source software called CRYLINE -v5.0.

Unit 42 researchers say the Agonizing Serpens APT group has significantly increased its capabilities and invested resources to evade EDR and other security measures.

Google warns that hackers can abuse GOOGLE CALENDAR.  Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 479/66 (IT) Tuesday, November 7, 2023. Google has issued a warning about several threat actors sharing proof-of-concept (PoC) regarding exploiting the GOOGLE Calendar service to host command-and-control (C2). This tool, called Google Calendar RAT (GCR), uses Google Calendar Events for C2 using a Gmail account.  It was first published on GitHub in June 2023.  Threat Horizons Report No. 8 states that the use of this tool has not yet been observed, but cyber threat intelligence has seen the PoC concept shared in underground forums and the Dark Web. Google says GCR works on compromised machines, periodically checking calendar event descriptions for new commands, and executes commands on the target device. It then updates the event description with the command output. This tool operates on legitimate infrastructure, making it more difficult for security personnel to detect suspicious activity.

FSB arrests Russian hackers working for Ukrainian cyber forces. Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 475/66 (IT) Friday, November 3, 2023. The Russian Federal Security Service (FSB) announced and released a statement on Tuesday stating that officers arrested two hackers believed to be assisting Ukrainian forces in carrying out cyberattacks against critical infrastructure targets in Russia.  The two suspects were detained on the same day but in different areas of Siberia. Both were charged with the serious crime of treason, which carries a maximum sentence of 20 years.  One suspect is a student at Tomsk State University of Control Systems and Radio Electronics. Russian media said the investigation found that he had helped a group of Ukrainian hackers in cyberattacks on Russian data infrastructure networks. He was put on a plane and sent to a pre-trial detention center in Lefortovo, Moscow, known as the infamous KGB prison and the former interrogation site for political prisoners. The second suspect is a 36-year-old man from the small town of Belovo, believed to be a member of Ukraine's cyber unit. He is believed to have been involved in cyber operations linked to Ukrainian forces, using malware and cyberattacks to disrupt critical infrastructure networks in Russia.

The British Library experienced a major outage affecting its website and various services following a cyberattack on October 28th.  The British Library, the UK's national library and one of the largest in the world, located in London, holds over 150 million items, including books, manuscripts, maps, newspapers, magazines, music recordings, and films.  This technical disruption resulted from a cyber incident, impacting the website, online catalog, and offsite services including public Wi-Fi.  The incident is currently under investigation with assistance from the National Cyber Security Centre (NCSC) and other experts.  The library has not released technical details regarding the attack, and it is currently unclear whether the attackers were able to access staff and user data.

Atlassian warns of critical Confluence vulnerability. Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 472/66 (IT) Wednesday, November 1, 2023. Atlassian warns of a critical vulnerability in Confluence Data Center and Server that could lead to data loss if exploited by an unauthenticated attacker. The vulnerability, CVE-2023-22518, has a CVSS score of 9.1 out of 10 and is described as an improper authorization vulnerability.  All versions of Confluence Data Center and Server are vulnerable and have been patched in the following versions: – 7.19.16 and later – 8.3.4 and later – 8.4.4 and later – 8.5.3 and later – 8.6.1 and later. Atlassian also advises customers to take immediate action to secure their instances by disconnecting publicly accessible instances until a patch can be applied. Users on other versions should update to a fixed version. Atlassian Cloud is not affected.

Lockbit Ransomware group claims to have stolen data from Boeing. Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 468/66 (IT) Monday, October 30, 2023.  The Lockbit Ransomware group claims to have hacked the aircraft engine and weapons manufacturer and threatens to expose the stolen data. Boeing is one of the world's largest aerospace manufacturers and defense contractors.  In 2022, it had sales of $66.61 billion.  The Lockbit Ransomware group has added Boeing to the list of victims on its Tor leak site.  It claims to have stolen a large amount of sensitive data from the company and threatens to publish it if Boeing does not contact them by the deadline (November 2, 2023, 13:25:39 UTC).  The group has not yet released any samples. In mid-October, the Lockbit Ransomware group claimed to have hacked technology services giant CDW, demanding an $80 million ransom. However, the group claims the company offered only $1 million.

Hacktivist activity related to the Gaza conflict is dwindling.

Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 467/66 (IT) Monday, October 30, 2023: Cyber activity by Hacktivist groups related to the conflict between Israel and Hamas has significantly slowed. Some groups no longer have plans for such attacks, and others have shifted their focus to targets outside of Israel. Research by Security Scorecard, published this month, found that several Hacktivist groups had planned attacks or identified targets, but many have gone silent or shifted to selling attack services. Dark Storm, a pro-Palestinian group, posted claims on a Dark Web forum in August 2023 that it would "attack Israeli infrastructure." In early October, it claimed to be preparing attacks on Israel's European allies.  Several Hacktivist groups threatened disruptive attacks against Israeli and Palestinian targets, while the SiegedSec group claimed responsibility for attacks on Israeli infrastructure and industrial control systems.  Furthermore, Solomon’s Ring, a Persian-speaking, pro-Palestinian hacktivist channel, has not claimed an attack since October 8, despite being active since October 2022 and claiming to have hacked and stolen data from Israeli data centers, though without evidence.  Meanwhile, KillNet Palestine (likely part of the Russian Hacktivist group KillNet) has not posted any new content since its founding announcement on October 13.

VMware Releases Patches for Critical vCenter Server RCE Vulnerability

Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 466/66 (IT) Friday, October 27, 2023. VMware has released updates to address a critical vulnerability in vCenter Server that allows remote code execution on the system.  The vulnerability, CVE-2023-34048 (CVSS score: 9.8), is an out-of-bounds write vulnerability in the DCE/RPC protocol implementation. If an attacker has network access to the vCenter Server, it could lead to an out-of-bounds write and allow remote code execution.  The vulnerability was discovered and reported by Grigory Dorodnov from the Trend Micro Zero Day Initiative. VMware states that there is no workaround for the vulnerability, only security updates in the following software versions: – VMware vCenter Server 8.0 (8.0U1d or 8.0U2) – VMware vCenter Server 7.0 (7.0U3o) – VMware Cloud Foundation 5.x and 4.x. The company is working on patches for vCenter Server 6.7U3, 6.5U3, and VCF 3.x.

A recent update also revealed vulnerability CVE-2023-34056 (CVSS score: 4.3), a partial information disclosure vulnerability impacting vCenter Server. Exploitation could allow a malicious actor with non-administrator privileges to access unauthorized information. VMware urges customers to act swiftly and apply the fixes as soon as possible to mitigate potential threats.

Former NSA employee pleads guilty to attempting to sell classified documents to Russia. Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 463/66 (IT) Thursday, October 26, 2023.  Jareh Sebastian Dalke, 31, a former employee of the U.S. National Security Agency (NSA), has pleaded guilty to six counts of attempting to transmit National Defense Information (NDI) to an agent of the Russian Federation.  Dalke admitted to attempting to transmit classified military and security information.  Dalke worked as an information systems security designer for the NSA from June 6, 2022, to July 1, 2022, and held a top-secret security clearance. Dalke admitted that between August and September 2022, he used an encrypted email account to send messages containing excerpts from three classified documents to a person he believed to be a Russian agent, requesting $85,000.  In reality, the person was an FBI agent. The three copied documents contained NDI, classified as top secret and Sensitive Compartmented Information (SCI).  Dalke was arrested by the FBI on September 28, shortly after sending the files. Sentencing is scheduled for April 26, 2024.  He faces a maximum sentence of life in prison.

University of Michigan student and employee data compromised in cyberattack
Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 462/66 (IT) Wednesday, October 25, 2023. The University of Michigan announced a data breach after hackers infiltrated its network in August, accessing data systems of students, applicants, alumni, donors, employees, patients, and research participants.  The unauthorized server access occurred between August 23-27, and exposed data includes personal, financial, and medical details.  The following details of students, applicants, alumni, donors, employees, and contractors were exposed: – Social Security numbers – Driver's license or other government-issued identification numbers – Financial account or payment card numbers – Health information. The data of research participants and patients of University Health Service and School of Dentistry may have been affected: – Demographic information (e.g., Social Security number, driver's license or government-issued identification number) – Financial information (e.g., financial account or payment card numbers, or health insurance information) – Clinical information from University Health Service and the School of Dentistry (e.g., medical record number, or diagnoses, treatments, or medication history) – Information related to participation in certain research studies.

The Philippines' Department of National Defense has ordered its personnel to stop using AI-powered image-generating applications.  Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 459/66 (IT) Tuesday, October 24, 2023.  The Philippines' Department of National Defense warned of the risks of using AI-powered applications to create images of individuals and ordered its personnel to immediately cease using such apps.  On October 14, Defense Secretary Gilberto Teodoro Jr. issued an order to stop using AI-powered image generation applications and to exercise caution in sharing information online.  This is due to the Philippine forces' ongoing efforts to quell decades-long communist and Muslim insurgencies, and to protect its interests in the disputed South China Sea.  It is currently unclear whether the order was issued in response to a specific incident or to address potential attacks aimed at exploiting data collected by these AI-powered applications. However, the memo warns about applications used to create digital avatar profile pictures after users submit at least 10 pictures of themselves. The avatars can then mimic how users actually speak and move.  The order states that these AI-powered applications pose significant privacy and security risks, as they can be misused to create fake profiles that can lead to identity theft, social engineering, phishing attacks, and other malicious activities.

A Critical Citrix NetScaler vulnerability is being exploited to target government and technology companies.  Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 458/66 (IT) Friday, October 20, 2023. Citrix warns of exploitation of a Critical vulnerability disclosed in NetScaler ADC and Gateway devices that could lead to the disclosure of sensitive information, assigned CVE-2023-4966 (CVSS score: 9.4). The vulnerability affects the following versions: – NetScaler ADC and NetScaler Gateway 14.1-8.50 and later – NetScaler ADC and NetScaler Gateway 13.1-49.15 and later of 13.1 – NetScaler ADC and NetScaler Gateway 13.0-92.19 and later of 13.0 – NetScaler ADC 13.1-FIPS 13.1-37.164 and later of 13.1-FIPS – NetScaler ADC 12.1-FIPS 12.1-55.300 and later of 12.1-FIPS – NetScaler ADC 12.1-NDcPP 12.1-55.300 and later of 12.1-NDcPP. Mandiant stated in an alert published Tuesday that it has observed exploitation of this zero-day vulnerability since late August 2023, potentially allowing hijacking of existing authentication sessions. Mandiant CTO Charles Carmakal said organizations need to do more than patch; they should also terminate all active sessions.

D-Link confirms Data Breach, employee falls victim to Phishing attack.  Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 456/66 (IT) Thursday, October 19, 2023. Taiwanese network equipment manufacturer D-Link confirms a data breach that exposed low-sensitivity and semi-public information. The company confirms that the data is not from the cloud system, but is expected to be from the old D-View system, which reached end-of-life in early 2015. The data was used for registration purposes. So far, there is no evidence that the old data contains user IDs or financial information. A post shared on BreachForums on October 1, 2023, revealed the theft of personal information of a large number of government officials in Taiwan, including source code for D-Link's D-View network management software. D-Link has contacted cybersecurity firm Trend Micro to investigate the incident. In addition, there was an incident where an employee fell victim to a Phishing attack, and the company has increased operational security.  The exact details of the attack have not yet been released, but the company emphasizes that current customers may not be affected by this incident.

Milesight industrial router vulnerability possibly exploited in attacks. Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 17/66 (OT) Wednesday, October 18, 2023. A vulnerability affecting some industrial routers from Chinese CCTV product manufacturer Milesight may be exploited in attacks. Several UR series industrial cellular routers from Milesight (Ursalink) are affected by CVE-2023-43261, a high-severity vulnerability that exposes system log files, such as ‘httpd.log’. The exposed logs contain passwords for the administrator and other users, which can be exploited by unauthenticated remote attackers to gain unauthorized access to the targeted devices. Passwords are not stored in plain text in the log files, but they can be easily decoded. Researcher Bipin Jitiya disclosed details of the vulnerability and publicly released a Proof-of-Concept (PoC) exploit, and notified Milesight of the findings. Milesight says UR series routers can be deployed in various sectors, including industrial automation, traffic signaling, medical devices, and retail.  Analysis of various firmware versions conducted by VulnCheck suggests that CVE-2023-43261 may have been present for several years. Shodan and Censys search engines show roughly 5,500 Milesight devices exposed on the internet, but only 6.5%, or less than 400 devices, appear to still be running a vulnerable firmware version.

CERT-UA reports 11 Ukrainian telecom providers were cyberattacked.  Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 454/66 (IT) Wednesday, October 18, 2023. The Computer Emergency Response Team of Ukraine (CERT-UA) revealed that at least 11 telecom providers in the country were attacked between May and September 2023. The agency is tracking the activity under the name UAC-0165, identified as an attack resulting in service disruption for customers.  The attacks used two special programs called POEMGATE and POSEIDON, which allow for credential theft and remote control of infected hosts. To erase forensic traces, the WHITECAT utility was used.  Moreover, unauthorized access to the providers' infrastructure was achieved using regular VPN accounts not protected by multi-factor authentication. CERT-UA stated that the attackers' intent was to compromise accountants' computers to steal authentication data (logins, passwords, keys/certificates) or alter details of financial documents in remote banking systems to send unauthorized payments.

Microsoft Defender Thwarts Akira Ransomware Group Attack

Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 452/66 (IT) Tuesday, October 17, 2023. Microsoft announced that Microsoft Defender for Endpoint helped block a large-scale hacking campaign carried out by Akira ransomware (tracked as Storm-1567). The attacks occurred in early June 2023, targeting industrial organizations.  Akira ransomware, launched in March 2023, claims to have attacked several organizations across various industries, including education, finance, and real estate. Like other ransomware groups, they have developed a Linux encryptor to target VMware ESXi servers, exploiting devices not equipped with Microsoft Defender for Endpoint to evade detection. Microsoft Defender's capabilities can prevent compromised accounts from accessing endpoints and other network resources. This protection limits the attackers' capabilities regardless of Active Directory status or account privilege levels.

The Lockbit ransomware group is demanding an $80 million ransom from CDW.  Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 450/66 (IT) on Monday, October 16, 2023 reported that the Lockbit ransomware group claims to have hacked CDW, a large technology solutions and services company for businesses, government, and education, known as CDW-G, which focuses services on US government agencies.  These include K-12 schools, universities, non-profit healthcare organizations, state and local, and federal governments. The Lockbit ransomware group has demanded an $80 million ransom. CDW disclosed that it detected suspicious activity related to its Sirius Federal server and quickly launched an investigation, assisted by external cybersecurity experts. The server is not related to customers and is separate from other CDW-G systems' CDW network. The company also said that systems remain operational. Brett Callow, a threat analyst at cybersecurity firm Emsisoft, described the ransom amount in this case as the third largest, at least.

ALPHV Ransomware group claims attack on circuit court
Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 448/66 (IT) Thursday, October 12, 2023. The ALPHV (BlackCat) ransomware group claims responsibility for the attack that affected the systems of the court across Northwest Florida last week. The group obtained personal details such as social security numbers and CVs of employees, including judges, and threatened to release the stolen data online to force the court back into negotiations. The Circuit Court revealed last week that it was investigating a cyberattack that disrupted operations on the morning of Monday, October 2nd. This incident will affect court operations in Escambia, Okaloosa, Santa Rosa, and Walton counties for an extended period.  Court officials also confirmed that all facilities remained open without interruption, and the court is not interested in the ransom demands from the ALPHV ransomware attack. The BlackCat/ALPHV ransomware group emerged in November 2021 as a rebranding of DarkSide/BlackMatter. Initially known as DarkSide, it rebranded as BlackMatter in July 2021 before operations ceased in November 2021.  As BleepingComputer reported last week, the ALPHV ransomware attack on MGM Resorts resulted in losses of approximately 100 million dollars.

Cisco releases urgent patch to fix critical vulnerability in Emergency Responder system. Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 444/66 (IT) Monday, October 9, 2023. Cisco has released an urgent update to address a critical vulnerability affecting the Emergency Responder system, which allows unauthenticated remote attackers to access the system using hard-coded credentials. Vulnerability number CVE-2023-20101 (CVSS score: 9.8). Attackers can exploit this vulnerability by using an account to log in to the affected system. If exploited successfully, attackers can log in to the affected system and execute arbitrary commands as root. The vulnerability affects Cisco Emergency Responder version 12.5(1)SU4 and has been fixed in version 12.5(1)SU5. Other product versions are not affected. This disclosure comes less than a week after Cisco warned of exploitation of a vulnerability in IOS and IOS XE software (CVE-2023-20109, CVSS score: 6.6), which could allow authenticated remote attackers to execute arbitrary commands on affected systems. Users should update to the latest version to prevent potential threats.

Cyberattack disrupts LYCA MOBILE services

Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 442/66 (IT) Friday, October 6, 2023 Lyca Mobile, an international mobile virtual network operator, has been the victim of a cyberattack that disrupted its network. Lyca Mobile is a Mobile Virtual Network Operator (MVNO) that provides prepaid mobile phone services to customers in many countries around the world. The company does not own the wireless network infrastructure, but leases network services from mobile operators instead, and Lycamobile serves more than 60 countries, reaching more than 15 million prepaid customers worldwide. The company issued a statement announcing that it had been the victim of a cyberattack that disrupted its network. The cyberattack occurred last week, preventing customers from accessing top-ups through the company's channels. The cyberattack did not affect services in the United States, Australia, Tunisia, and Ukraine. The company has investigated the security breach with the support of technical experts and has notified relevant regulatory and law enforcement agencies in each affected market. The company announced that it has restored affected services in all markets, but some operational services have not yet been resolved.  The company did not provide details about the attack, but it is likely that the company was hit by Ransomware.

WS_FTP Vulnerability CVE-2023-40044 Exploited in the Wild

Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 440/66 (IT) Thursday, October 5, 2023. Experts warn of vulnerability CVE-2023-40044, which attackers are exploiting in Progress Software's WS_FTP product.  Progress Software recently warned customers to patch the critical vulnerability CVE-2023-40044 (CVSS score 10) in WS_FTP Server software used by IT teams worldwide. The vulnerability was discovered by researchers at cybersecurity firm Assetnote.  A pre-authenticated remote attacker can exploit a .NET deserialization issue in the Ad Hoc Transfer module to execute arbitrary commands on the underlying WS_FTP server operating system.  This vulnerability affects WS_FTP Server versions prior to 8.7.4 and 8.8.2. Assetnote researchers discovered approximately 2,900 internet-exposed hosts running WS_FTP and also published a PoC exploit for this vulnerability. Cybersecurity firm Rapid7 reported that attackers began exploiting CVE-2023-40044 after Assetnote published the PoC.

BunnyLoader malware targeting browsers and digital wallets.  Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 439/66 (IT) Thursday, October 5, 2023.  Zscaler ThreatLabz has revealed a new Malware-as-a-Service (MaaS) threat called "BunnyLoader" being traded on underground websites.  The tool is priced at $250 and is under active development, with rapid development, feature updates, and bug fixes.  BunnyLoader is mostly written in C/C++ and is a fileless loader that performs malicious activities in memory, making it more difficult for cybersecurity operators to detect. BunnyLoader has a variety of capabilities such as a keylogger that records keystrokes and steals a large amount of information, including data from web browsers and digital wallets, and can perform remote command execution (RCE). Since its initial release on September 4, 2023, BunnyLoader has been continuously updated with bug fixes and new functionality.

Zanubis Android banking Trojan poses as a Peruvian government app to attack users.

Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 437/66 (IT) on Tuesday, October 3, 2023, detected a new Android banking Trojan malware called Zanubis, which disguises itself as a Peruvian government app to trick users into installing it. Kaspersky, in an analysis published last week, stated that "The primary distribution method for Zanubis involves impersonating legitimate Android applications in Peru.  It then tricks users into enabling accessibility permissions and takes complete control of the device." Zanubis, originally documented in August 2022, is the latest addition to a long list of Android banking Trojans targeting the Latin American (LATAM) region. Targets include more than 40 banks and financial institutions in Peru. It is primarily known for abusing accessibility permissions on infected devices to display fake overlay screens on top of target apps in an attempt to steal credentials. It can also collect contact information, installed app lists, and system metadata. Kaspersky said it observed the latest Zanubis samples in April 2023, masquerading as the Peruvian customs and tax authority application, Superintendencia Nacional de Aduanas y de Administración Tributaria (SUNAT).  Once installed, this allows Zanubis to perform keylogging or screen recording to steal sensitive information.

CISA adds JBoss RichFaces Framework vulnerability to Known Exploited Vulnerabilities Catalog.  Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 436/66 (IT) Monday, October 2, 2023.  The US Cybersecurity and Infrastructure Security Agency (CISA) has added a critical vulnerability, CVE-2018-14667 (CVSS score 9.8), affecting Red Hat JBoss RichFaces Framework to its Known Exploited Vulnerabilities Catalog. The vulnerability is an Expression Language (EL) injection via the UserResource resource, affecting RichFaces Framework versions 3.X through 3.3.4.  This allows unauthenticated, remote attackers to exploit this vulnerability to execute arbitrary code via org.ajax4jsf.resource.UserResource$UriData.  The vulnerability was discovered by security researcher Joao Filho Matos Figueiredo.  According to Binding Operational Directive (BOD) 22-01, to mitigate the risk of this vulnerability, FCEB agencies are required to remediate the identified vulnerabilities by the due date to prevent network compromise from exploitation of vulnerabilities in the Catalog. Experts also recommend that private organizations review the Catalog and remediate the vulnerability. CISA has ordered federal civilian agencies to remediate this vulnerability by October 19, 2023.

Unpatched ZERO-DAY RCE vulnerability affects over 3.5 million EXIM servers.

Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 435/66 (IT) Monday, October 2, 2023. Experts warn of a critical Zero-day vulnerability, CVE-2023-42115 (CVSS score 9.8), in all versions of the Exim Mail Transfer Agent (MTA) software.  This vulnerability allows unauthenticated remote attackers to exploit it and execute remote code (RCE) on exposed internet servers.  The vulnerability stems from an out-of-bounds write issue within the SMTP service, caused by a lack of validation of user-supplied data. This allows remote attackers to run arbitrary code on affected Exim installations. No authentication is required to exploit this vulnerability.  Researchers disclosed the vulnerability via ZDI on June 6, 2022, and ZDI reported it to the vendor on June 14, 2022. On September 25, 2023, ZDI requested an update and informed the vendor of their intention to publicly disclose the Zero-day on September 27, 2023. The development team has yet to fix this vulnerability, which has been present for over a year.

Hackers are exploiting a high-severity vulnerability in the Openfire messaging server to encrypt servers with ransomware and deploy cryptominers. Openfire is a widely used open-source Java-based chat (XMPP) server with over 9 million downloads, extensively used for cross-platform communication.  The vulnerability, designated CVE-2023-32315, is an authentication bypass affecting the Openfire administrative console, allowing unauthenticated attackers to create new admin accounts on vulnerable servers.  The flaw impacts all Openfire versions from 3.10.0 (2015) up to 4.6.7 and from 4.7.0 to 4.7.4. Although Openfire patched the vulnerability with versions 4.6.8, 4.7.5, and 4.8.0 released in May 2023, VulnCheck reported that in mid-August 2023, over 3,000 Openfire servers were still running vulnerable versions.  BleepingComputer found multiple reports from customers stating their Openfire servers were encrypted with ransomware.  It is unclear which ransomware group is behind these attacks, and it appears the attackers are not solely targeting Openfire servers but also web servers with other vulnerabilities. Therefore, it's crucial to keep all server security updates current.

RHYSIDA ransomware group attacks Kuwait's Ministry of Finance.

Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 431/66 (IT) Thursday, September 28, 2023. Last week, a ransomware attack targeted the Kuwaiti government. The attack occurred on September 18th, and government experts immediately initiated incident response procedures to mitigate the cyber threat.  Kuwait's Ministry of Finance officially announced the incident on Twitter.  Officials shut down affected systems to prevent the threat from spreading. The Ministry's message indicated that payment and payroll systems were impacted, as they were hosted on a separate network. “The Ministry of Finance announces that one of its systems was subjected to a hacking attempt and the system was shut down.  Currently, the ministry is still unable to fully restore the system.” According to a press release issued by the Kuwaiti government this week, local authorities, including the National Cyber Center, are investigating the incident with assistance from cybersecurity companies. This week, the Rhysida ransomware group claimed responsibility for the attack and added the ministry to the list of victims on its data leak site on the Tor network. The group also published a set of documents as proof of the hack. The Rhysida ransomware group has been operating since May 2023, according to the gang’s Tor leak site, and has listed at least 44 companies as victims of its attacks.

Warn to patch TeamCity Instance to avoid server hacking.
