Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 428/66 (IT) on Tuesday, September 26, 2023, experts warn of a critical vulnerability in TeamCity CI/CD servers that can be exploited to gain access to vulnerable servers. JetBrains TeamCity is a popular Continuous Integration and Continuous Delivery (CD) server developed by JetBrains, a software development company that provides tools for developers. TeamCity is designed to automate various software development processes, including building, testing, and deploying applications, and offers a wide range of features to support collaborative development. The vulnerability is an authentication bypass that affects on-premise versions of TeamCity, allowing attackers to exploit the vulnerability to steal source code, stored service secrets, and organizational private keys by injecting malicious code. TeamCity servers version 2023.05.3 and lower can bypass authentication, which allows unauthenticated attackers to remotely execute code (RCE) on the server. The vulnerability affects on-premise versions 2023.05.3 and lower. JetBrains has addressed the vulnerability with the release of version 2023.05.4, and this vulnerability does not affect TeamCity Cloud. Sonar says it cannot publish details of this vulnerability because it is exploitable.

Personal data of 25,000 Hong Kongers at risk after a cyberattack against the consumer watchdog, up from a previous estimate of 8,000.  The Hong Kong Consumer Council revealed that the personal data of more than 25,000 people may have been leaked.  Council CEO Gilly Wong Fung-han said Monday that externally provided computer systems, such as inquiry management and price-checking tools, had been restored, but there might be delays in handling complaints. The council has notified those affected by the data breach, including staff, former employees, 25,000 Choice magazine subscribers and 1,600 voters who participated in earlier activities.  Data potentially stolen includes the credit card details of about 8,000 Choice magazine subscribers, the identity documents, addresses and birth dates of current and former staff, as well as family member details, resumes of job applicants from the past two years, and contact information of business partners.

National Student Clearinghouse data breach affects approximately 900 schools in the U.S.

Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 425/66 (IT) Monday, September 25, 2023. The National Student Clearinghouse (NSC), a U.S.-based non-profit organization that provides educational verification and reporting services to educational institutions, employers, and other organizations, has disclosed a data breach affecting approximately 900 U.S. schools that use its services.  The security breach resulted from a cyberattack exploiting a vulnerability in managed file transfer (MFT) from the large-scale MOVEit hack campaign that targeted organizations worldwide in late May.  This attack occurred on May 30th, and malicious actors were able to access related files containing personal information such as names, birth dates, contact information, social security numbers, student identification numbers, and certain school-related records (e.g., enrollment records, degree records, and program level information). According to the data breach notification letter, the information affected by this incident varies by individual.

GitLab Releases Urgent Security Patches for Critical Vulnerability

Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 424/66 (IT) Friday, September 22, 2023. GitLab has released patches to address a critical vulnerability that allows attackers to execute other users' pipelines.  This vulnerability, identified as CVE-2023-5009 (CVSS score: 9.6), affects all versions of GitLab Enterprise Edition (EE) from 13.12 and prior to 16.2.7, as well as from 16.3 and prior to 16.3.4.  Successful exploitation of this vulnerability could allow attackers to access sensitive information or leverage the elevated permissions of the impersonated user to modify source code or execute arbitrary code on the system.  Security researcher Johan Carlsson (aka joaxcar) is credited with discovering and reporting the vulnerability CVE-2023-3932. GitLab addressed the vulnerability in early August 2023, with fixes included in GitLab versions 16.3.4 and 16.2.7. Users are urged to update their GitLab installations to the latest versions as soon as possible to mitigate potential risks.

Clop Ransomware group steals data from major hospitals in North Carolina
Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 420/66 (IT) Tuesday, September 19, 2023. Nuance, a Microsoft-owned technology company, has revealed that the Clop Ransomware group has stolen personal data from major hospitals in North Carolina as part of the Progress MOVEit Transfer campaign. MOVEit Transfer is used for secure file transfers using SFTP, SCP, and HTTP uploads. The Clop Ransomware group (also known as Lace Tempest) has been credited by Microsoft for the campaign that exploited the Zero-day vulnerability CVE-2023-34362 in the MOVEit Transfer platform. The company said the Clop group may have stolen personal data from several hospitals in North Carolina and other healthcare providers, including: – Atrium Health – Catawba Valley Medical Center – Charlotte Radiology – Duke University Health System – DLP Central Carolina Medical Center – ECU Health – FirstHealth of the Carolinas – Mission Health System – Novant Health – Novant Health New Hanover Regional Medical Center – UNC Health – Wake Radiology Diagnostic Imaging – WakeMed Health and Hospitals. Currently, many hospitals in the United States have been targeted by cyberattacks. The Rhysida Ransomware group has added three more U.S. hospitals to the list of victims on its Tor site after the PROSPECT MEDICAL attack on the systems of 3 hospitals and other healthcare facilities.

Mozilla fixes critical Zero-day vulnerability in Firefox and Thunderbird.  Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 418/66 (IT) Friday, September 15, 2023. Mozilla released a security update to fix a critical Zero-day vulnerability, CVE-2023-4863, in Firefox and Thunderbird that is being actively exploited.  The vulnerability is a heap buffer overflow in WebP, previously addressed in Google Chrome before version 116.0.5845.187. It allows remote attackers to write out-of-bounds memory via a crafted HTML page, potentially leading to arbitrary code execution.  The vulnerability was reported by Apple Security Engineering and Architecture (SEAR) and The Citizen Lab at the Munk School of the University of Toronto. Mozilla has not disclosed details about the attacks exploiting the flaw.  This vulnerability affects Firefox 117.0.1, Firefox ESR 115.2.1, Firefox ESR 102.15.1, Thunderbird 102.15.1 and Thunderbird. The CVE-2023-4863 vulnerability has been addressed with the release of Firefox 117.0.1, Firefox ESR 115.2.1, Firefox ESR 102.15.1, Thunderbird 102.15.1, and Thunderbird 115.2.2.  Google recently released an emergency security update to address the same vulnerability (CVE-2023-4863) in Chrome. This is the 4th Zero-day vulnerability patched by Google in 2023.

Microsoft has released patches to address two zero-day vulnerabilities.

Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 415/66 (IT) Thursday, September 14, 2023. Microsoft has released patches to fix 59 vulnerabilities, covering its product groups, including two zero-day vulnerabilities that have been exploited by cyber attackers. Of the 59 vulnerabilities, 5 are rated "Critical," 55 are rated "Important," and 1 is rated "Moderate." This update is in addition to the 35 vulnerabilities patched in the Chromium-based Edge browser since last month's Patch Tuesday, which included a fix for CVE-2023-4863, a critical buffer overflow vulnerability in the WebP image format.  The two Microsoft vulnerabilities that have been exploited in the wild are: – CVE-2023-36761 (CVSS score: 6.2) – Microsoft Word Information Disclosure Vulnerability – CVE-2023-36802 (CVSS score: 7.8) – Microsoft Streaming Service Proxy Elevation of Privilege Vulnerability.

Google fixes the fourth Chrome zero-day vulnerability of 2023.  Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 414/66 (IT) Wednesday, September 13, 2023. Google has released an emergency security update to fix a zero-day vulnerability that has been widely exploited since the beginning of the year.  The vulnerability, designated CVE-2023-4863, is the fourth zero-day vulnerability patched by Google in 2023.  CVE-2023-4863 is a heap buffer overflow in WebP.  The vulnerability was reported by Apple Security Engineering and Architecture (SEAR) and The Citizen Lab at the Munk School of the University of Toronto on Wednesday, September 6th. Chrome users should update their web browser to version 116.0.5845.187 for Mac and Linux, and 116.0.5845.187/.188 for Windows as soon as possible. This year, Google has fixed the following zero-day vulnerabilities exploited in Chrome: – CVE-2023-2033 (CVSS score: 8.8) – Type Confusion in V8 – CVE-2023-2136 (CVSS score: 9.6) – Integer overflow in the Skia graphics library – CVE-2023-3079 (CVSS score: 8.8) – Type Confusion in V8

CISA adds Critical Apache RocketMQ vulnerability to Known Exploited Vulnerabilities catalog.  Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 410/66 (IT) Monday, September 11, 2023. The US Cybersecurity and Infrastructure Security Agency (CISA) has added the critical vulnerability CVE-2023-33246 (CVSS score 9.8) affecting Apache RocketMQ to its Known Exploited Vulnerabilities Catalog. Various RocketMQ components, including NameServer, Broker, and Controller, have extranet leaks and lack authentication, allowing attackers to exploit this vulnerability by using the update configuration function to execute commands as the active RocketMQ system user.  Attackers can also forge RocketMQ protocol content.  This vulnerability affects Apache RocketMQ versions 5.1.0 and earlier. Users should update to version 5.1.1. Apache's advisory was released in May, but CISA added the issue to the Known Exploited Vulnerabilities Catalog after cybersecurity firm VulnCheck published technical details about the vulnerability.  CISA ordered federal agencies to patch this vulnerability by September 27, 2023. FCEB agencies must remediate identified vulnerabilities by the due date to protect against attacks exploiting vulnerabilities in the Catalog. Experts also recommend that private sector organizations review the Catalog and address vulnerabilities in their infrastructure.

More than a dozen vulnerabilities in security cameras made by the defunct company Zavio remain unpatched.

Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 408/66 (IT) Friday, September 8, 2023. BugProve, a provider of IoT firmware analysis platforms, has disclosed details of more than a dozen vulnerabilities found in security cameras made by Zavio, a Chinese company that has since shut down. However, the cameras are reportedly still in use in the United States and Europe.

Because Zavio is defunct, BugProve worked with CCTV Camera Pros, a major Zavio camera distributor in the US, to investigate the vulnerabilities and report them to the US Cybersecurity and Infrastructure Security Agency (CISA) for public disclosure and CVE assignment. According to the companies, seven of the vulnerabilities can be exploited for unauthenticated remote code execution with root privileges. These flaws allow attackers to completely take over the targeted devices. IP cameras are often targeted by botnet herders and used in DDoS and other attacks. CISA has assigned only two CVE identifiers, CVE-2023-4249 and CVE-2023-3959, as the vulnerabilities stem from the same root cause.

Since the affected Zavio cameras will not receive patches, users are advised to replace the devices in order to prevent becoming victims of malicious attacks. Security camera experts are reportedly informing customers that Zavio cameras are no longer available and suggesting alternatives.

Android's September 2023 security updates include patches for 32 vulnerabilities, including one that has been exploited in attacks. Google has been aware of several Android zero-day vulnerabilities in recent years, and many of them have been exploited by groups selling commercial spyware.  Five additional high-severity vulnerabilities were addressed in the Framework, with three leading to privilege escalation and two being information disclosure flaws. Google also announced that two other issues were fixed in Project Mainline components with updates delivered via Google Play. These updates target critical Android components without requiring devices to reboot. The second part of this month's Android security updates will arrive on devices as the 2023-09-05 security patch level, with fixes for 12 more vulnerabilities in Qualcomm components.  The annual security patch level addresses all vulnerabilities in this month's security updates, and issues addressed with prior patch levels. (

German financial authority website disrupted by DDoS attack.

Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 404/66 (IT) Wednesday, September 6, 2023. The German Federal Financial Supervisory Authority (BaFin) announced that it was hit by a distributed denial-of-service (DDoS) attack.  It is not yet clear who is behind the DDoS attack, but media speculate that it was launched by professional Russian hackers in response to Germany’s financial and military support for Ukraine. BaFin’s website was included in a list of attack targets published by the pro-Russian Killnet group on Telegram in January.  The German Federal Financial Supervisory Authority (BaFin) is the national financial regulatory authority in Germany. It is a federal agency under the Federal Ministry of Finance. BaFin is responsible for supervising banks, insurance companies, investment firms and other financial institutions. It also regulates the stock market and the financial services industry.  Security measures were implemented immediately after the attack began on Friday, September 1, 2023. BaFin stated that all other systems were not affected and the website is now back online.  BleepingComputer said that the website was attacked at the database host that contains information on listed companies and public tenders.

Freecycle website confirms data breach affecting 7 million users.  Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 403/66 (IT) Wednesday, September 6, 2023.  The Freecycle website, an online community created by people who want to reduce waste and recycle unnecessary items, is a place where members can exchange information about unwanted items and arrange for pick-up and delivery.  Freecycle, a non-profit organization, has confirmed a large-scale data breach affecting more than 7 million users. The data breach was discovered a few weeks after stolen data was offered for sale on a data trading website on May 30th.  The stolen data includes usernames, user IDs, email addresses, and MD5-hashed passwords. According to Freecycle's report, no other information was disclosed. After learning of the breach, Freecycle said it reported the incident to relevant authorities and warned affected users to immediately change their account passwords. They also advised users to be wary of phishing emails and to avoid clicking on links in emails from unknown sources.

The University of Sydney has suffered a data breach affecting applicants.  Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 402/66 (IT) Tuesday, September 5, 2023. The University of Sydney (USYD) announced a data breach by malicious actors who disclosed personal information of applicants who registered recently. The university, founded in 1850, has nearly 70,000 students and approximately 8,500 academic and administrative staff, and is one of Australia's most important educational institutions. The university's data breach announcement stated that the incident affected only a portion of applicants and that a preliminary investigation found no evidence that student, staff, or alumni data was affected.  The university said it is still in the process of reviewing the data accessed by the attackers and is asking all international applicants to follow the advice provided on the university's website. Earlier this week, the University of Michigan announced the shutdown of systems critical to its operations to address a serious cybersecurity incident. In June, the University of Manchester suffered a data breach in which hackers stole a quantity of data from its network.

LockBit Ransomware group claims to have breached the data of the Commission des services electriques de Montréal (CSEM).

Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 400/66 (IT) Monday, September 4, 2023. The LockBit Ransomware group claims to have hacked the Commission des services electriques de Montréal (CSEM), the agency responsible for underground electrical wiring in Montreal, Canada, established in 1910 through a public-private partnership. CSEM's mission is to provide a safe, reliable, and sustainable underground electrical network for the city.  Its main tasks are planning and coordinating underground electrical wiring, managing and maintaining the underground electrical network, and providing information and education about the underground electrical network. CSEM confirmed a data breach on August 3, 2023, and confirmed that it refused to pay the ransom. The agency immediately launched a security breach investigation with the assistance of law enforcement agencies, and CSEM has now recovered the affected systems. The LockBit Ransomware group published the stolen data on August 30, 2023. Since August 1, the LockBit group has accessed over 140 organizations worldwide.

A new scam disguised as the YouPorn website threatens to leak your sex tape.

Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 399/66 (IT) Monday, September 4, 2023. This week, a new form of extortion scam is being shared. It involves sending emails claiming to be from the adult website YouPorn, stating that a sexual video of the recipient will be published by uploading it to a network of adult websites. This email claims to be from info@youporn[.]com and has the subject line "Uploaded content: Feedback required". The message warns that your sex tape will be published on the website within the next 7 days unless you request its removal. The email includes links that claim to allow you to remove the video for free. However, these links are empty, causing your browser to open to the website's homepage. The email then lists paid options that can be used to remove the video from YouPorn and all websites in the adult network. These services are priced at $199, $699, or $1,399, with each tier claiming to offer additional protection.  However, as far as those involved have investigated, it has been found that the campaign has not been very successful. It is important to emphasize that these emails are a scam. If you receive this email, simply delete it. While it may sound scary, it is nothing more than a scam from malicious actors.

Chinese hackers target US and other governments with Barracuda device vulnerability.  Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 397/66 (IT) Friday, September 1, 2023. Mandiant, a cybersecurity firm, has revealed details of a sophisticated global espionage campaign, suspected to be the work of a Chinese state-sponsored threat group called UNC4841.  This group exploited a zero-day vulnerability (CVE-2023-2868) in Barracuda Email Security Gateway (ESG) appliances to infiltrate the systems of government agencies and organizations worldwide. Mandiant's investigation revealed that the campaign lasted eight months, from October 2022 to June 2023. The campaign involved the deployment of multiple advanced malware families, including Skipjack, DepthCharge, Foxglove, Foxtrot, and a new version of Seaspy. These malware families enabled the attackers to collect information, steal credentials, and evade detection. Affected sectors include national governments, technology companies, local governments, telecommunications providers, manufacturing entities, and universities. Although the campaign affected a limited number of ESG appliances globally (approximately 5%), the impact is significant due to the high-profile nature of the targeted organizations.

Critical vulnerability alert in VMware Aria Operations Networks, risk of remote attack. Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 396/66 (IT) Thursday, August 31, 2023. VMware has released software updates to address two security vulnerabilities in Aria Operations for Networks that could be exploited to bypass authentication and allow remote code execution. The most severe vulnerability, CVE-2023-34039 (CVSS score: 9.8), is an authentication bypass vulnerability that allows attackers with network access to Aria Operations for Networks to bypass SSH authentication to access the Aria Operations for Networks CLI. The vulnerability was reported by researchers Harsh Jaiswal and Rahul Maini, who are credited with its discovery.  The second vulnerability, CVE-2023-20890 (CVSS score: 7.2), is an arbitrary file write vulnerability affecting Aria Operations for Networks. It could be exploited by attackers with admin privileges to write files to arbitrary locations and achieve remote code execution. The vulnerability was reported by Sina Kheirkhah of the Summoning team.  These vulnerabilities affect VMware Aria Operations Networks versions 6.2, 6.3, 6.4, 6.5.1, 6.6, 6.7, 6.8, 6.9, and 6.10. They have been addressed in VMware version 6.11.0, which fixes both vulnerabilities.

Somalia orders internet providers to block Telegram and TikTok.
Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 395/66 (IT) Thursday, August 31, 2023.  Recently, the Somali government announced plans to shut down access to certain social media platforms, including TikTok and Telegram. Minister of Communications and Technology, Jama Hassan Khalif, announced via his Twitter account that the main purpose of blocking access to these social media platforms is to protect the morals and culture of the country's society. The order was issued on Sunday, August 20th. Internet service providers in the country have until Thursday, August 24th to comply with the order. Somalia has terrorist and extremist groups within the country that use Telegram for communication and to spread inappropriate content and misinformation to the public. The Minister stated that the ban was due to the platforms' harmful effects on youth and their misuse to harm many individuals. In recent years, statistics show that 8% of Telegram users are in the Middle East and North Africa, with 700 million users worldwide, which equates to more than half a million users. The TikTok platform has also been banned in several countries for moral reasons as well.

Attackers can obtain IP ADDRESSes by sending links via the mobile SKYPE application.
Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 393/66 (IT) Wednesday, August 30, 2023.  Security researcher Yossi found that it is possible to discover the IP ADDRESS of a target by sending a link through the mobile Skype application. The researcher pointed out that the attack method only requires the target to open the message. This attack method can only be performed on the mobile Skype app. Obtaining the target's IP ADDRESS allows malicious actors to locate their physical location or residence, posing a privacy risk.  This attack could pose a serious risk to activists, political dissidents, journalists, or those targeted by cybercriminals, and many others. According to a report by 404 Media, Yossi reported the issue to Microsoft earlier this month, but the company seemed to initially overlook the problem and did not indicate plans to fix the flaw. However, after 404 Media contacted Microsoft for information, the company announced plans to address the issue in the next application update. 404 Media only revealed that the issue can be exploited by manipulating certain parameters related to the link, but has not disclosed details of the attack since the vulnerability has not yet been patched.

Rhysida claims responsibility for the ransomware attack on Prospect Medical and threatens to sell data.

Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 392/66 (IT) Tuesday, August 29, 2023. The Rhysida ransomware group has claimed responsibility for the cyberattack on Prospect Medical Holdings, claiming to have stolen social security numbers, company documents, and records of 500,000 patients. The incident occurred on August 3rd when company employees found a ransom note on their screens stating that the network had been hacked and devices encrypted. Prospect Medical Holdings (PMH) is a US healthcare company with 16 hospitals in California, Connecticut, Pennsylvania, Rhode Island, and 166 clinics and outpatient centers. The cyberattack resulted in hospitals shutting down their IT networks to prevent the spread of the attack.  The Rhysida ransomware group claimed responsibility for the attack on Prospect Medical Holdings, threatening to sell the company's data for 50 Bitcoins (worth $1.3 million USD). The group claims to have stolen 1 TB of documents and a 1.3 TB SQL database containing 500,000 social security numbers, passports, driver's licenses, company documents, and patients' medical information. BleepingComputer has attempted to contact PMH for information about the attack but has not received a response at this time.

KmsdBot malware targets IoT devices with enhanced capabilities.  The Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 391/66 (IT) on Tuesday, August 29, 2023, reported that an updated version of the KmsdBot botnet malware is targeting Internet of Things (IoT) devices. KmsdBot was first documented by a security company in November 2022.  It was designed to target private servers and cloud hosting providers.  The malware is designed to scan random IP addresses for open SSH ports and brute-force the systems with a list of passwords downloaded from attacker-controlled servers.  This new update has the capability to scan Telnet and supports more architectures found in IoT devices.  The Telnet attacks are carried out by downloading a text file (telnet.txt) containing a list of weak, commonly used passwords and combinations for various applications. It exploits the fact that many IoT devices still have default credentials and have not been changed.

Leaseweb, a provider of critical cloud and hosting services, shuts down critical systems following a cyberattack.

Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 390/66 (IT) Monday, August 28, 2023. Leaseweb, a cloud and hosting provider, experienced a security breach affecting some of its "critical" systems. The company notified customers of recovery efforts.  The incident occurred on August 22nd when the company detected "unusual" activity on some of its systems and investigated customer portal outages. In response, the company took some affected systems offline to contain the threat and launched an investigation.  The company engaged a digital forensics cybersecurity firm to investigate the incident. Leaseweb's actions indicate that the company successfully contained the incident and improved security measures to prevent future occurrences.

Hackers attack Poland's rail network.  Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 389/66 (IT) Monday, August 28, 2023. Polish intelligence agencies are investigating a hacking attack on the country's railway system. Hackers infiltrated the railway network on Saturday, causing the emergency shutdown of approximately 20 trains near Szczecin. Service resumed within a few hours. During the attack, hackers broadcast the Russian national anthem interspersed with a speech by President Vladimir Putin.  Poland is a key transit hub for Western arms shipments to Ukraine. Several Western countries have called for increased cybersecurity measures as the conflict in Ukraine unfolds.  Some experts have said that Russia is conducting cyberattacks in Ukraine, apparently testing its cyberattack tools.

A hosting company says it lost all customer data after a ransomware attack.

Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 388/66 (IT) on Thursday, August 24, 2023, reported that two Danish hosting companies suffered a ransomware attack, resulting in the loss of most customer data.  This forced the hosting providers to shut down all systems, including customer websites and emails. Both Hosting CloudNordic and AzeroCloud brands belong to the same company. The attack occurred last Friday night, and the company stated it would not pay the ransom. The company is cooperating with security experts and has reported the incident to the police.  Due to the situation, both hosting providers recommend heavily impacted customers migrate to other providers, such as Powernet and Nordicway.  Danish media reported that the attack affected hundreds of Danish companies, which lost data stored in the cloud, including websites, email inboxes, and documents. Targeting hosting providers is a tactic used by ransomware groups in the past, as it causes significant damage and allows them to attack many victims in a single attack. This incident has resulted in numerous victims, putting immense pressure on the providers to pay the ransom to restore operations and avoid lawsuits from customers who lost data.

FBI finds 1,580 Bitcoin in crypto wallets linked to North Korean hackers. Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 387/66 (IT) Thursday, August 24, 2023. The Federal Bureau of Investigation has released information about digital wallets linked to North Korean hackers. The FBI said it is holding approximately 1,580 Bitcoin that may be related to the recent theft of hundreds of millions of dollars worth of digital assets. The FBI has been tracking the stolen digital currency by the TraderTraitor group (also known as Lazarus Group and APT38) of the Democratic People's Republic of Korea (DPRK), which is believed to be attempting to cash out the Bitcoin for more than $40 million. According to the information, the TraderTraitor-affiliated hacker group stole $60 million and $37 million from Alphapo and CoinsPaid in July, and $100 million from Atomic Wallet in June. In April 2023, the U.S. government warned that the North Korea-linked Lazarus Group had carried out numerous cyberattacks targeting entities and exchanges in the blockchain and cryptocurrency industries for money laundering.

CISA warns of exploitable Adobe ColdFusion vulnerability.  The Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 386/66 (IT) on Wednesday, August 23, 2023, reported that the US Cybersecurity and Infrastructure Security Agency (CISA) has warned organizations that a patched Adobe ColdFusion vulnerability from earlier this year, tracked as CVE-2023-26359, may be exploited in attacks. CISA added the vulnerability to its Known Exploited Vulnerabilities (KEV) catalog on Monday. Adobe addressed the vulnerability with its March 2023 Patch Tuesday updates, describing CVE-2023-26359 as a critical deserialization issue that can be exploited for arbitrary code execution. CISA has ordered federal civilian agencies to patch the vulnerability by September 11. Federal agencies are required to fix vulnerabilities added to the catalog under Binding Operational Directive (BOD) 22-01 to mitigate risks posed by the flaws. CISA's KEV catalog currently lists 12 ColdFusion vulnerabilities, including four flaws discovered this year. While there is no information available at this time regarding attacks exploiting CVE-2023-26359, Adobe ColdFusion vulnerabilities can be exploited by various threat actors in their operations.

The Snatch ransomware group claims to have hacked the South African Department of Defence.  Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 385/66 (IT) Wednesday, August 23, 2023.  The Snatch ransomware group claims to have hacked the South African Department of Defence and has added the South African Department of Defence to its data leak site. The group claims to have stolen military contracts, internal phone signals, and personal data, totaling 1.6 TB of information.  The disclosure of such classified military information poses serious risks to organizations related to these contracts. Snatch ransomware was first discovered in late 2019 by researchers at Sophos.  Snatch ransomware reboots infected computers in Safe Mode to bypass security solutions. In October 2022, the Snatch ransomware group also claimed to have successfully attacked HENSOLDT France. HENSOLDT specializes in military and defense electronics.

Seiko, a Japanese watch manufacturer, was hacked by the BlackCat ransomware group.

Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 384/66 (IT) on Tuesday, August 22, 2023 reported that the BlackCat/ALPHV ransomware group listed Seiko on their extortion website, claiming responsibility for the cyberattack that exposed the Japanese company's data earlier this month. Seiko, one of the largest and oldest watch manufacturers in the world, employs approximately 12,000 people and has annual revenues exceeding $1.6 billion. Seiko confirmed that on July 28th, the company experienced a data breach where unidentified individuals or groups gained unauthorized access to at least one server. On August 2nd, Seiko hired an external cybersecurity expert team to investigate and assess the situation. Seiko apologized to customers who may have been affected and urged them to be cautious of emails or other communication channels that may impersonate Seiko.

The BlackCat ransomware group claimed responsibility for the attack on Seiko and posted samples of data allegedly stolen during the attack.  The claimed leaked data includes production plans, employee passport scans, new release plans, and specialized laboratory test results.  Significantly, the attackers claim to have confidential technical blueprints and designs for Seiko watches, the disclosure of which would cause significant damage.

WinRAR Vulnerability Allows Arbitrary Remote Code Execution

Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 382/66 (IT) Monday, August 21, 2023. WinRAR, a file compression and archiving utility for Windows operating systems, was affected by a high-severity vulnerability, now patched, designated CVE-2023-40477 (CVSS score 7.8).  This vulnerability could allow remote code execution on a computer by opening a specially crafted RAR archive.  The vulnerability was reported to RARLAB by Zero Day Initiative researcher "goodbyeselene" on June 8, 2023, and could allow a remote attacker to execute arbitrary code on a RARLAB WinRAR installation. User interaction is required for exploitation. Targets may be tricked into visiting malicious websites or opening malicious files.  The vulnerability is due to a lack of validation of user-supplied data, which can result in out-of-bounds memory access.  This allows attackers to execute code by exploiting this vulnerability. WinRAR addressed the vulnerability with the release of version 6.23. Users are advised to update their WinRAR installations before attackers can exploit the vulnerability.

Clorox Company, a manufacturer of cleaning products, has partially shut down systems after a cyberattack.

Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 380/66 (IT) Friday, August 18, 2023, The Clorox Company has been the victim of a cyber incident and has partially shut down systems in response to the cyber attack.  Clorox Company is a multinational consumer goods company specializing in the manufacture and marketing of household cleaning products. In response to the attack, the company has taken some systems offline while increasing security precautions. Clorox has notified law enforcement and engaged leading cybersecurity experts to investigate and determine the scope of the incident.  It is not yet clear whether the attackers stole company data. In addition, the company announced it will implement temporary workarounds, including offline operations, to continue serving customers.  The company has not yet disclosed the details of the attack, but its response to the incident suggests it may have been the victim of a ransomware attack.

A large-scale phishing campaign using QR codes is targeting the energy sector.  The Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 379/66 (IT) reported on Friday, August 18, 2023, that cybersecurity firm Cofense has discovered a QR code phishing campaign targeting leading energy companies in the United States to steal users' Microsoft credentials across multiple industries.  Most links included in the phishing messages contain Bing redirect URLs. Other prominent domains include krxd[.]com (linked to Salesforce applications) and cf-ipfs[.]com (Cloudflare's Web3 service).  Using QR codes offers advantages over embedding phishing links directly in emails, most importantly the ability to bypass anti-phishing solutions, as the phishing link is hidden within the QR code image. Researchers observed a monthly growth percentage for this campaign exceeding 270%. The overall campaign has grown by more than 2,400% since May 2023. Researchers say this is the largest campaign ever using QR codes observed by Cofense, a situation suggesting that attackers are testing the effectiveness of QR codes. The phishing messages used in this campaign contain a PNG image file or a PDF file with a QR code. The message content attempts to trick recipients into scanning the code to verify their account.  The email message urges recipients to complete the process within 2-3 days. Experts warn that the energy sector is the main focus of this campaign, followed by the manufacturing and insurance sectors.

Vulnerabilities in Iagona Scrutis website could allow ATMs to be hacked remotely.

Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 374/66 (IT) on Tuesday, August 15, 2023, reported that multiple vulnerabilities found in the ScrutisWeb ATM monitoring software, produced by the French company Iagona, could be exploited to remotely compromise ATM systems.  These vulnerabilities were discovered by Synack Red Team researchers. ScrutisWeb allows organizations to monitor bank or retail ATMs from a web browser, enabling quick responses to issues. Synack researchers identified four vulnerabilities: CVE-2023-33871, CVE-2023-38257, CVE-2023-35763, and CVE-2023-35189.  The vulnerabilities include authorization bypass, hardcoded cryptographic key, and arbitrary file upload, which could be exploited by remote, unauthenticated attackers. Attackers can exploit the vulnerabilities to obtain information from the server (configuration, logs, and databases) and execute arbitrary commands.  Researchers said attackers could leverage these vulnerabilities to log into the ScrutisWeb management console as an administrator, monitor the activity of connected ATMs, enable management mode on the devices, upload files, and reboot or shut down the machines.  The U.S. Cybersecurity and Infrastructure Security Agency (CISA) has published an advisory to inform organizations about the vulnerabilities. According to CISA, affected products are used worldwide.  (

Cumbria Constabulary accidentally leaked officer data online.

Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 373/66 (IT) Tuesday, August 15, 2023: Cumbria Constabulary, a territorial police force in England, unintentionally published the names and salaries of all its officers and staff online.  This is the second UK agency in two weeks to admit to a data breach involving employee personal information. In this incident, Cumbria Police admitted that the names, salaries, and allowances of officers were indeed published on its website due to an unintentional human error.  The information was removed immediately after the accidental publication, but the police did not specify how long the data was online before the error was discovered. Cumbria Constabulary stated it had immediately contacted all affected officers to inform them of the minor impact and outline the measures being taken to manage the leak and prevent recurrence.  The incident was reported to the Information Commissioner’s Office (ICO – the UK's data regulator), which reportedly stated that no further action was needed beyond advice and guidance. The ICO was reportedly satisfied with the Constabulary's actions and the stringent steps taken to prevent further data breaches. However, it is reported that Chief Constable Simon Byrne will be investigated by the watchdog and may face penalties.

Multiple vulnerabilities in CODESYS V3 SDK can be exploited for RCE or DoS.  Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 16/66 (OT) Tuesday, August 15, 2023. Microsoft Threat Intelligence researchers have discovered 16 high-severity vulnerabilities, dubbed CoDe16, in the CODESYS V3 Software Development Kit (SDK).  These vulnerabilities allow attackers to perform remote code execution and denial-of-service attacks, compromising operational technology (OT). Vulnerability CVE-2022-47391 has a severity score of 7.5. Successful exploitation affects all CODESYS V3 versions prior to 3.5.19.0 and could expose operational technology (OT) infrastructure to attacks such as remote code execution (RCE) and denial of service (DoS).  Recommendations from Microsoft: – Patch affected devices and update device firmware to version 3.5.19.0 or higher. –  Check all critical devices such as PLCs, routers, PCs, etc., and disconnect them from the internet, regardless of whether they are running CODESYS. – Restrict access to CODESYS devices to authorized components only.

CISA adds vulnerability affecting .NET, Visual Studio to Known Exploited Vulnerabilities Catalog.  Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 372/66 (IT) Friday, August 11, 2023. The US Cybersecurity and Infrastructure Security Agency (CISA) has added zero-day vulnerability CVE-2023-38180 (CVSS score 7.5) affecting Microsoft's .NET and Visual Studio to its Known Exploited Vulnerabilities Catalog. This vulnerability can be exploited for denial-of-service (DoS) attacks. Microsoft addressed it with the August 2023 Patch Tuesday update. Microsoft confirmed that vulnerable systems can be attacked without user interaction.  Microsoft did not disclose details about attacks exploiting this vulnerability, but it affects Visual Studio 2022 versions 17.2, 17.4, and 17.6, as well as .NET 6.0 and 7.0 and ASP.NET Core 2.1.  According to Binding Operational Directive 22-01, FCEB agencies must patch the vulnerability by the deadline to prevent network exploitation. CISA ordered federal agencies to fix this vulnerability by August 30, 2023.

Adobe released security updates to address vulnerabilities in Acrobat Reader. Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 371/66 (IT) Friday, August 11, 2023. On Tuesday, Adobe released a large set of security patches for Acrobat Reader software, fixing at least 30 vulnerabilities affecting Windows and macOS installations. These are critical vulnerabilities, and Adobe warned that successful exploitation could lead to arbitrary code execution, memory leaks, security bypasses, and application denial-of-service attacks. Affected software includes Acrobat DC, Acrobat Reader DC, Acrobat 2020, and Acrobat Reader 2020.  Most of the bugs are memory safety issues. The Adobe PSIRT team also updated Adobe Dimension software to address three vulnerabilities that could allow arbitrary code execution and memory leaks on Windows and macOS operating systems.

Ransomware attacks in Finland have quadrupled since joining NATO.  Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 370/66 (IT) on Wednesday, August 9, 2023, reports that Recorded Future News interviewed Sauli Pahlman, Deputy Director General of the National Cyber Security Center (NCSC) of Finland.  They found that targeted ransomware attacks in Finland have quadrupled since Finland joined NATO in 2023. This increase is believed to be politically motivated, as Vladimir Putin has repeatedly warned that Russia would retaliate if NATO established military infrastructure in Finland after joining the alliance. In October 2022, the Finnish Security Intelligence Service (Suojelupoliisi or SUPO) warned of increased cyberattacks from attackers linked to Russia. At that time, SUPO pointed out to NATO that membership would make the country a special target for Russia. Intelligence indicated that cyber threats to Finland's critical infrastructure had increased as a result of Russia's invasion of Ukraine. The agency also warned that these operations primarily targeted organizations and individuals from Western countries residing in Finland. (

Russian hackers launch DDoS attacks against Spanish websites. Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 369/66 (IT) Wednesday, August 9, 2023. Leading research institutions in Spain have become the latest organizations in the country to be targeted by Russian cyberattacks. These are weeks-long DDoS attacks, which appear to be politically motivated. Local reports claim that the hacker group NoName057 has claimed responsibility for the DDoS attacks, which affected at least 72 websites between July 19 and 30. It is believed that the financial, banking, telecommunications, media, and tourism sectors, as well as various agencies, were affected by the attacks. This followed Prime Minister Pedro Sánchez's arrival in Kyiv, demonstrating his support for the Ukrainian government.

Cyberattacks have disrupted services at multiple hospitals across several US states.

Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 368/66 (IT) Monday, August 7, 2023: Cyberattacks in the United States have disabled the computer systems of several hospitals, forcing the closure of emergency rooms, the suspension of ambulance services, and the transfer of patients to other facilities. This has severely impacted the operations of various hospitals. The cyberattacks targeted medical institutions under Prospect Medical Holdings, which operates hospitals in California, Texas, Connecticut, Rhode Island, and Pennsylvania.  The attacks shut down services at several hospitals on Friday, and some hospitals suspended elective surgeries, outpatient appointments, blood draws, and other services on Thursday.  The company has not disclosed details about the cyberattacks. However, the impact on operations suggests that the affected entities were hit by ransomware.  In June, Idaho Falls Community Hospital suffered a cyberattack that impacted operations, and hospital officials confirmed that some clinics were closed due to the attack.  Another hospital, Mountain View Hospital, experienced a similar incident, with officials confirming that malware infected parts of the hospital's IT infrastructure.

Researchers discovered a new high-severity vulnerability in PaperCut software. Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 367/66 (IT) Monday, August 7, 2023. Cybersecurity researchers have discovered a new high-severity security flaw in PaperCut printing management software for Windows, which could lead to remote code execution to perform certain configurations. The vulnerability number is CVE-2023-39143 (CVSS score: 8.4) affecting PaperCut NG/MF prior to version 22.1.3. Earlier in April, another remote code execution vulnerability was also disclosed in PaperCut products, numbered CVE-2023-27350 (CVSS score: 9.8), and an information disclosure vulnerability (CVE-2023-27351) was widely exploited to spread Cobalt Strike and ransomware. However, CVE-2023-39143 is more complex to exploit, involving multiple issues that must be chained together to take over the server. It's not a one-shot RCE vulnerability.

Canon Inkjet Printers at Risk for Third-Party Compromise via Wi-Fi

Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 363/66 (IT) Thursday, August 3, 2023. Canon issued a security advisory this week detailing concerns about risks to inkjet printers and sensitive information regarding Wi-Fi settings stored in the printer's memory. If exploited, this vulnerability could lead to information leaks, putting users at risk and compromising data security.  If any printer is in the hands of a third party, there is a risk of unauthorized access, which could lead to information falling into the wrong hands. Canon has compiled a list of affected printers, with 196 affected models. The company has provided mitigation measures. What to do when a user's printer is used by a third party: reset all settings, enable wireless LAN, and finally, reset the settings again. Canon also offers additional steps for models without the "reset all settings" function. The vendor also advises customers to consult the manual for specific reset instructions.  More details can be found at hxxps://psirt.canon/advisory-information/cp2023-003/

A critical vulnerability in MikroTik RouterOS exposes over half a million devices to potential hacking.  Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 361/66 (IT) on Thursday, July 27, 2023, reported a severe privilege escalation issue affecting MikroTik RouterOS.  Attackers can remotely exploit this vulnerability to execute arbitrary code and take complete control of vulnerable devices.  A report released Tuesday revealed the vulnerability, CVE-2023-30799 (CVSS score: 9.1), affects approximately 500,000 RouterOS systems, making them susceptible to attacks via the web or Winbox interface.  VulnCheck notes that CVE-2023-30799 was initially disclosed by Margin Research as an exploit called FOISted (without a CVE identifier).  This vulnerability in Mikrotik routers was exploited to incorporate devices into denial-of-service (DDoS) botnets. Users are strongly advised to patch the vulnerability by updating to the latest version (6.49.8 or 7.x) as soon as possible.  Mitigation recommendations include removing the MikroTik administrative interface from the internet, blocking administrator login IP addresses, disabling Winbox and the web interface, and configuring SSH to use public/private keys and disable passwords.

12 Norwegian ministries were hit by a cyberattack exploiting a zero-day vulnerability.

Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 359/66 (IT) on Wednesday, July 26, 2023, reported that malicious actors exploited a zero-day vulnerability in supplier software to attack the ICT platforms of 12 Norwegian ministries. Local authorities launched an investigation into the attack, which was reported by the Norwegian National Security and Service Organization (DSS) to the National Security Authority (NSM). The DSS established a crisis response team to investigate the incident in conjunction with the NSM and other security agencies.  The Prime Minister's Office, the Ministry of Defence, the Ministry of Justice, and the Ministry of Foreign Affairs were not affected by the attack as they do not use the targeted platform. The DSS also notified the Norwegian Data Protection Authority of indications that the attackers may have stolen data from the affected government ICT platforms. In response to the incident, the DSS implemented security measures that prevented employees in the affected ministries from accessing DSS mobile services. However, they were still able to work normally using office or home computers. The zero-day vulnerability has been patched, but the Norwegian government has not yet released details about the attack.

Multiple DDoS Botnets Targeting Zyxel Devices

Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 358/66 (IT) Monday, July 24, 2023.  Fortinet FortiGuard Labs researchers warn that several DDoS Botnets are exploiting vulnerabilities affecting several Zyxel firewalls. The vulnerability, CVE-2023-28771 (CVSS score: 9.8), is a command injection issue allowing unauthorized execution of arbitrary code on vulnerable devices.  Zyxel patched this vulnerability in late April and advised customers to apply the patch.  The U.S. CISA has also added the vulnerability to its Known Exploited Vulnerability Catalog. In June, Rapid7 researchers confirmed they were tracking exploitation of CVE-2023-28771 by Mirai-like botnets.  Now, Fortinet experts have observed attacks occurring across multiple regions, noting that attackers specifically target the command injection vulnerability in Internet Key Exchange (IKE) packets sent over UDP on Zyxel devices. This campaign uses multiple servers to launch attacks, and reports indicate the malware updates itself every two to three days to maintain compromise on Zyxel devices.

Adobe releases new patches for exploited ColdFusion vulnerabilities.

Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 356/66 (IT) Friday, July 21, 2023. Adobe has released new updates to address recently disclosed ColdFusion vulnerabilities that have been actively exploited. A critical vulnerability, designated CVE-2023-38205 (CVSS score: 7.5), is described as improper access control that could lead to security bypass.  It affects the following versions: – ColdFusion 2023 (Update 2 and earlier versions) – ColdFusion 2021 (Update 8 and earlier versions) – ColdFusion 2018 (Update 18 and earlier versions). Adobe states that CVE-2023-38205 is being actively exploited in limited attacks targeting Adobe ColdFusion.  Two other important deserialization vulnerabilities were also addressed: CVE-2023-38204 (CVSS score: 9.8), which could lead to remote code execution, and CVE-2023-38206 (CVSS score: 5.3), an improper access control vulnerability that could lead to security bypass. The disclosure comes as Rapid7 warned that the fix for CVE-2023-29298, an access control bypass vulnerability, was incomplete and could be bypassed by attackers.  The company continues to recommend that Adobe ColdFusion users update their installations to the latest versions to mitigate potential threats.

Ukrainian cyber police have dismantled a large bot farm operated by a gang of over 100 people.  The gang created fake social media accounts to spread propaganda, distort information, and conduct psychological operations related to the invasion of Ukraine, in support of the Russian government. The gang used the large bot farm to spread illegal content, Ukrainian citizens’ personal data, and conduct various types of fraud.  Cyber police discovered that the group used special equipment and software to register over a thousand bot accounts on various social media networks.  Police seized more than 250 computers, mobile phones, and GSM gateways, along with approximately 150,000 SIM cards from various mobile operators.

Virustotal data leak exposes data of some registered users, including intelligence agency members.  Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 353/66 (IT) Thursday, July 20, 2023. German newspapers Der Spiegel and Der Standard report that the online malware scanning website VirusTotal suffered a data leak that exposed data of some registered customers. The leaked file is 313 kilobytes in size and contains a list of 5,600 names, including data related to employees of the NSA, U.S. Secret Service, U.S. cyber agencies, and German intelligence services who have registered with the Google-owned VirusTotal website.  Der Spiegel points out that the leaked data reveals who is involved in IT and malware security in affected companies and government organizations.  Malicious actors could use this information to target these officials with spear-phishing attacks. The exposed records include customer names and email addresses. The data was exposed after an employee accidentally uploaded it to VirusTotal.  Once Google became aware of the leak, the data was removed within an hour of the upload.

Adobe warns customers of critical RCE vulnerability in ColdFusion.

Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 352/66 (IT) Wednesday, July 19, 2023. Adobe issued a warning to customers about a critical remote code execution vulnerability in ColdFusion, tracked as CVE-2023-29300 (CVSS score: 9.8), which is being actively exploited.  Unauthenticated attackers can exploit this vulnerability to remotely execute commands on vulnerable Coldfusion 2018, 2021, and 2023 servers. Adobe has not disclosed technical details of the vulnerability but has addressed three vulnerabilities in ColdFusion:

1. CVE-2023-29298 (CVSS score: 7.5) Improper Access Control
2. CVE-2023-29300 (CVSS score: 9.8) Deserialization of Untrusted Data
3. CVE-2023-29301 (CVSS score: 5.9) Improper Restriction of Excessive Authentication Attempts

In March 2023, the US Cybersecurity and Infrastructure Security Agency (CISA) added a critical Adobe ColdFusion vulnerability, tracked as CVE-2023-26360 (CVSS score: 8.6), to its Known Exploited Vulnerabilities Catalog.  This Improper Access Control vulnerability could allow remote attackers to execute arbitrary code.

BreachForums website owner pleads guilty.

Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 350/66 (IT) Tuesday, July 18, 2023:  The owner of the notorious website BreachForums has pleaded guilty in a US court to conspiracy to commit access device fraud, access device fraud, and possession of child pornography.  The man, Conor Brian Fitzpatrick, 21, of Peekskill, New York, was arrested on March 15, 2023. Fitzpatrick, known online as ‘Pompompurin,’ admitted to authorities that he was the owner and administrator of BreachForums, which launched in 2022 as an alternative to RaidForums, a cybercrime marketplace. BreachForums, located on the Surface Web, was easily accessible to anyone. With over 340,000 members, it was shut down following Fitzpatrick's arrest. BreachForums had become a top hacker marketplace at the time, facilitating the trade of hacked or stolen data, including bank account details, social security numbers, personal information, online account credentials, and hacking services for hire.

Fitzpatrick's guilty plea carries a maximum penalty of 10 years in prison for conspiracy to commit access device fraud, a 10-year prison sentence for access device fraud, and a maximum of 20 years for possession of child pornography.  The maximum penalties for each count, as well as a $250,000 fine and supervised release, are applicable.

New PyLoose Linux malware mines crypto directly from memory. Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 345/66 (IT) Friday, July 14, 2023.  A new fileless malware called PyLoose is targeting cloud workloads to hijack computing resources to mine Monero cryptocurrency. PyLoose is a relatively simple Python script with a compiled, base64-encoded XMRig miner, an open-source tool that leverages CPU power to solve complex algorithms necessary for the cryptocurrency.  Researchers from Wiz stated that PyLoose’s direct execution from memory makes detection by security tools difficult. Fileless malware doesn’t leave traces on the system’s drive, making it hard to detect. It typically leverages legitimate system tools to inject malicious code into legitimate processes. Wiz security researchers first detected the PyLoose attacks on June 22, 2023, and have since confirmed over 200 instances. Researchers haven't been able to attribute the PyLoose attacks to a specific threat actor, as the attackers didn't leave any clues behind.  They recommend that cloud instance administrators avoid publicly exposing services vulnerable to code execution, utilize strong passwords and multi-factor authentication to protect access to these services, and implement system command execution restrictions.

HCA Healthcare data breach affects 11 million patients. Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 344/66 (IT) Thursday, July 13, 2023. HCA Healthcare has been attacked. The data breach exposed the personal information of approximately 11 million patients. The agency discovered the breach on July 5th after the attacker posted information on an underground forum claiming to have stolen data from HCA Healthcare. The attacker posted details of sample patient data such as name, address, date of birth, gender, phone number, email address, service dates, and appointment dates. HCA Healthcare stated that the following information was not stolen in the attack: – Clinical information such as treatments, diagnoses, or conditions – Payment information such as credit card or account numbers – Sensitive information such as passwords, driver's licenses, or social security numbers.  HCA Healthcare has conducted an investigation into the security breach with the assistance of forensic and threat consultants. HCA Healthcare has also notified law enforcement of the incident and plans to contact affected individuals. In response to the incident, HCA Healthcare has disabled user access to the impacted data storage location.

Revolut was hit by a cyberattack exploiting a vulnerability in its payment system, resulting in a loss of US$20 million.  Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 342/66 (IT) Wednesday, July 12, 2023. In early 2022, attackers exploited a zero-day vulnerability in Revolut's payment system to steal over $20 million, according to the Financial Times, citing multiple sources.  The breach was not publicly disclosed.  The issue stemmed from a flaw in Revolut's system in America and Europe, causing some transactions to be declined. The company would then refund the accounts using its own funds. The problem was first discovered in late 2022, with reports indicating that attackers exploited the vulnerability by attempting to purchase expensive items that would be declined. The refunded amounts were then withdrawn from ATMs.  Technical details of the vulnerability remain unclear.  Approximately $23 million was stolen, with a portion recovered by tracking down those who withdrew the cash. The massive fraud resulted in the neobank and fintech company incurring a net loss of around $20 million.  The disclosure comes less than a week after Interpol announced the arrest of suspected members of a French hacker group dubbed OPERA1ER, linked to attacks targeting financial institutions and mobile banking services with malware, large-scale phishing campaigns, and business email compromise (BEC) scams.

VMware warns customers of exploitation of vulnerability CVE-2023-20864 affecting vRealize products.

Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 341/66 (IT) Wednesday, July 12, 2023. VMware notified customers about the availability of exploit code for a critical RCE vulnerability, CVE-2023-20864, in VMware Aria Operations for Logs (formerly vRealize Log Insight). VMware Aria Operations for Networks (formerly vRealize Network Insight) is a network monitoring tool that helps organizations build optimized, highly available, and secure network infrastructure.  In April, the virtualization giant released security updates to address two critical vulnerabilities, CVE-2023-20864 and CVE-2023-20865, affecting Aria Operations for Logs (formerly vRealize Log Insight).  The company has now updated its original security advisory to confirm the availability of exploit code for the aforementioned issue. The company is urging customers to patch the vulnerability immediately. In June, the company warned customers that another critical remote code execution vulnerability in Aria Operations for Networks, CVE-2023-20887, was being actively exploited.

Japan's Nagoya Port suspends cargo operations after Ransomware attack.
Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 336/66 (IT) Friday, July 7, 2023. Nagoya Port is the largest trading port in Japan, accounting for approximately 10% of Japan's total trade value. In particular, this port is the largest exporter of automobiles in Japan and is the port where Toyota Motor Corporation exports most of its vehicles, including goods such as food and household appliances. On Wednesday morning, the Nagoya Harbour Transportation Authority announced that cargo operations had been suspended following a cyberattack that affected the Nagoya United Terminal System (NUTS), the computer system used in the operation of the port's 5 cargo terminals.  All cargo operations have been suspended since July 4th.  The attack resulted in temporary traffic jams of transport vehicles at the port.  Nagoya Port predicted that the system would be back online and cargo operations would resume on the morning of July 6th. The group claiming responsibility for the attack is the LockBit 3.0 ransomware group.

Aon's MOVEit attack has exposed the data of Dublin Airport employees.  Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 334/66 (IT) Thursday, July 6, 2023. The data of approximately 3,000 Dublin Airport employees was compromised after service provider Aon fell victim to the MOVEit Transfer attack. Dublin Airport reported the incident to local authorities and the Irish Data Protection Commission. Aon is the latest victim of an attack exploiting the CVE-2023-34362 vulnerability affecting Progress Software's MOVEit file transfer platform. MOVEit Transfer is a managed file transfer used by organizations for secure file transfers using SFTP, SCP, and HTTP uploads. This vulnerability is an SQL injection vulnerability that unauthenticated attackers can exploit to gain unauthorized access to the MOVEit Transfer database. The Clop ransomware group claims to have breached hundreds of companies worldwide by exploiting the MOVEit Transfer vulnerability. The list of victims of the ransomware attack exploiting the MOVEit Transfer Zero-day includes the US Department of Energy, British Airways, Boots, BBC, Aer Lingus, Ofcom, Shell, University of Rochester, Schneider Electric, Siemens Energy, and Gen Digital. The US State Department is offering a $10 million reward for information linking members of the Clop ransomware group.

Interpol Dismantles Phone Scam Network

Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 330/66 (IT) Tuesday, July 4, 2023.  An international police operation has arrested dozens of suspects, including the ringleader of a criminal group that targeted elderly victims with phone scams.  The National Crime Agency (NCA) arrested the suspected ringleader near London, while Polish and German officers searched several locations in Europe.  Seized items include mobile phones and other electronic devices, gold bars and coins, jewelry, and €160,000 ($174,000) in cash.  Around 70 criminals have been arrested for investigation.  The scam's first step involved calling elderly victims, impersonating police officers or government officials, and informing them that their relatives were responsible for accidents resulting in fatalities. The call would then be transferred to a second individual who would cry and plead for help, shocking the recipient into complying with the scammers' demands to send money to avoid the relative's detainment.  The second step involved sending someone to collect the money directly from the victim's home. Europol estimates that hundreds of elderly victims were affected by this gang, losing up to €5 million ($5.4 million). Police claim the arrests have potentially prevented further losses of up to €1.4 million ($1.5 million).

WordPress websites using the Ultimate Member plugin are under attack.

Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 329/66 (IT) Tuesday, July 4, 2023.  Hackers are exploiting a critical, unpatched vulnerability in the WordPress plugin, tracked as CVE-2023-3460 (CVSS score: 9.8), to create rogue administrator accounts.  Ultimate Member is a popular WordPress membership plugin that allows administrators to create advanced online communities and membership sites. It allows the creation of almost any type of website where users can join and become members easily.  The plugin is currently installed on over 200,000 sites.

Researchers at WordPress security firm WPScan noticed new administrator accounts kept appearing on targeted websites. Attackers can exploit this vulnerability to create new user accounts with administrator privileges, which can be used to completely take over the website. Researchers explain that the root cause of the issue is the use of a pre-defined list of user meta data keys that users should not be able to manipulate. The plugin uses this list to check if users are trying to register these keys when creating a new account. This security mechanism is considered unsafe.

WPScan didn't provide details about the exploit but shared Indicators of Compromise (IoCs) for these attacks. Researchers at WordFence also observed attacks exploiting this issue. They explain that the flaw is not adequately addressed in the latest available version.

The LockBit group demanded a $70 million ransom from semiconductor manufacturing giant TSMC.  Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 328/66 (IT) for Monday, July 3, 2023, reported that the LockBit ransomware group claimed to have penetrated the systems of Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Company (TSMC) and demanded a ransom of $70 million. TSMC is the world's largest chip manufacturer for the technology sector, including Apple and Qualcomm Inc.  On Wednesday, BleepingComputer reported that a Lockbit affiliate called Bassterlord announced the attack on TSMC via Twitter and published images containing company-related data as proof of the attack. The group claimed to have stolen a large amount of sensitive data from the company and threatened to publish it if payment was refused.  The group initially gave TSMC seven days to pay the ransom but later extended the deadline to August 6. TSMC denied being breached by Lockbit but confirmed that the group had breached Kinmax Technology, one of its IT hardware suppliers. The investigation into the incident revealed no impact on TSMC's core operations and no compromise of TSMC customer data. TSMC stated it would not work with the compromised supplier until the situation was resolved. Taiwan's Kinmax Technology also provides services to other prominent companies such as Cisco, Citrix, HPE, Microsoft, and Nvidia. The security breach was discovered on June 29.

Avast Releases Free Decryptor for Akira Ransomware Windows Version

Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 327/66 (IT) Monday, July 3, 2023.  Avast, a cybersecurity company, has released a free decryptor for the Akira ransomware, allowing victims to recover their data without paying ransoms to hackers.  The Akira ransomware is Windows ransomware with a 64-bit Windows binary, written in C++ and using the Boost library for asynchronous cryptographic operations. The authors used Microsoft Linker version 14.35. Attacks began in March 2023, with hackers behind the malware claiming to have breached several organizations across multiple industries, including education, finance, and real estate.

Decryption method: The first step is to download the Avast decryptor binary, which is a 64-bit decryptor as the ransomware itself is 64-bit and won't run on 32-bit Windows. If you have no choice but to use 32-bit applications, you can download a 32-bit decryptor. Avast released both a 64-bit and a 32-bit Windows decryptor. Victims need to prepare two files: one encrypted by Akira ransomware and the original file. Avast is working on creating a decryptor for the Linux version and has released IOCs for both the Windows and Linux versions.

Suncor Energy's cyberattack has impacted Petro-Canada gas stations.  Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 322/66 (IT) Wednesday, June 28, 2023. Petro-Canada gas stations across Canada have been affected, preventing customers from paying with credit cards or loyalty points. This is because the parent company, Suncor Energy, disclosed that it experienced a cyberattack. Suncor Energy is the 48th largest public company in the world and one of Canada's largest producers of synthetic crude oil, with annual revenues of $31 billion.  The company said it has implemented mitigation measures against the attack and notified relevant authorities of the situation. Transactions with customers and suppliers will be impacted until the incident is resolved. The company did not provide any details about the type of cyber threat. Petro-Canada, a subsidiary of Suncor Energy, with over 1,500 gas stations across Canada, announced it was experiencing problems due to the incident via Twitter.  The company stated that customers cannot currently log into their accounts through the app or website and apologized for the inconvenience. The Petro-Canada incident has led "Carwash Season Pass" holders to seek refunds for their subscriptions.

CISA says Critical Zyxel NAS vulnerability exploited in attacks.  Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 320/66 (IT) Tuesday, June 27, 2023. The US Cybersecurity and Infrastructure Security Agency (CISA) warns of a recently patched critical vulnerability affecting network-attached storage (NAS) products manufactured by Zyxel, which has issued an advisory for the NAS326, NAS540, and NAS542 devices. Specifically, devices running firmware version 5.21 and earlier are affected by the critical flaw. Tracked as CVE-2023-27992, the vulnerability can be exploited for unauthenticated arbitrary command injection. The flaw resides in the pre-authentication command injection of the devices. Some Zyxel NAS devices may allow unauthenticated attackers to execute some operating system (OS) commands remotely by sending crafted HTTP requests. Zyxel has released patches for affected products and urged customers to install them as soon as possible. CISA added the vulnerability to its Known Exploited Vulnerabilities Catalog on Friday, June 23, informing users that CVE-2023-27992 is actively exploited in attacks. CISA has ordered federal agencies to take action by July 14.

Twitter hacker sentenced to 5 years for cybercrimes.  Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 319/66 (IT) Tuesday, June 27, 2023. Joseph James O’Connor, also known as PlugwalkJoe, a hacker involved in the 2020 Twitter attack, was sentenced to 5 years in prison for cybercrimes. In November 2021, the US Department of Justice indicted Joseph James O’Connor for stealing $784,000 in digital currency using SIM swapping attacks to take control of victims' phone numbers by tricking mobile carrier employees into transferring data to SIMs under the control of the criminals. Once the SIM is stolen, attackers can steal money, digital currency, and personal information, including contacts synced with online accounts.  Criminals can hijack social media accounts and bypass 2FA services that rely on SMS used by online services, including financial services, to gain access to cryptocurrency company accounts. Using this access, the alleged hacking group stole $784,000 worth of Bitcoin, Litecoin, Ethereum, and Bitcoin from wallets.

Fortinet Fixes Critical RCE Vulnerability in FortiNAC, Update Urged.

Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 317/66 (IT) Monday, June 26, 2023. Fortinet has fixed a remote command execution vulnerability, CVE-2023-33299, affecting its FortiNAC solution.  FortiNAC is a Network Access Control (NAC) solution designed by Fortinet, used in various companies and organizations to secure and control network access by enforcing security policies, monitoring devices, and managing access rights. FortiNAC helps organizations protect their network infrastructure by providing visibility and control over devices connected to the network, such as laptops, smartphones, IoT devices, and other endpoints.  It allows network administrators to define and enforce security policies, authenticate and authorize devices, and monitor network activity. Fortinet has released security updates to address the critical vulnerability, CVE-2023-33299 (CVSS score 9.6/10), which could allow unauthenticated attackers to execute arbitrary code and commands on vulnerable devices. The company urges customers to update immediately. Affected products include: FortiNAC versions 9.4.0 through 9.4.2, FortiNAC versions 9.2.0 through 9.2.7, FortiNAC versions 9.1.0 through 9.1.9, FortiNAC versions 7.2.0 through 7.2.1, all versions of FortiNAC 8.8, all versions of FortiNAC 8.7, all versions of FortiNAC 8.6, all versions of FortiNAC 8.5, and all versions of FortiNAC 8.3.

Researchers have disclosed new severe vulnerabilities in OT products from Wago and Schneider Electric.  Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 15/66 (OT) on Friday, June 23, 2023, reported the disclosure of three security vulnerabilities in Operational Technology (OT) products.  The vulnerabilities, dubbed OT: ICEFALL by Forescout, comprise 61 flaws. The most severe vulnerability, CVE-2022-46680 (CVSS score: 8.8), involves plaintext transmission of credentials in the ION/TCP protocol used by power meters from Schneider Electric. Successful exploitation could allow an attacker to take control of vulnerable devices.  Two other security vulnerabilities (CVE-2023-1619 and CVE-2023-1620, CVSS score: 4.9) involve denial-of-service (DoS) affecting WAGO 750 controllers that can be triggered by authenticated attackers by sending specifically malformed packets or specific requests after logging out.  Summarizing the OT: ICEFALL research, Forescout observed that vendors still lack a basic understanding of security best practices and issue incomplete patches while failing to employ proper security testing procedures.

Avast and Norton Parent Are the Latest Victims of the MOVEit Data Breach

Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 315/66 (IT) Friday, June 23, 2023. Gen Digital, the parent company of cybersecurity products such as Avast and Norton, confirmed on June 20th that the personal information of company employees was compromised in the MOVEit attack by the Cl0p ransomware group.  They confirmed that personal information such as names, addresses, employee IDs, and email addresses of employees were disclosed. According to Gen Digital's statement, they further confirmed that they have notified all affected parties and reported the incident to data protection regulators. "We use MOVEit for file transfers and have patched all vulnerabilities in the system.  When we learned of this, we took immediate action to protect our environment and investigate the potential impact. We confirm that there is no impact on our core systems, IT systems, and services, and no customer or partner data has been exposed." This vulnerability, CVE-2023-34362, is a critical SQL injection vulnerability that started as a zero-day vulnerability and was part of the Cl0p ransomware group's vulnerability exploitation campaign. The attacks continued even after patches were released, and so far, more than 100 companies and organizations have been targeted.

Alert! Hackers exploiting critical vulnerability in VMware's Aria Operations Networks.

Thailand Computer Emergency Response Team (ThaiCERT) 313/66 (IT) Thursday, June 22, 2023. Vulnerability CVE-2023-20887 in VMware Aria Operations for Networks may allow a malicious actor with network access to the product to perform command injection attacks, resulting in remote code execution.  This affects VMware Aria Operations Networks version 6.x.  Fixes are available in versions 6.2, 6.3, 6.4, 6.5.1, 6.6, 6.7, 6.8, 6.9, and 6.10, released on June 7, 2023. VMware confirms that hackers are actively exploiting CVE-2023-20887.  Data collected by GreyNoise, a threat intelligence company, shows exploitation attempts from two distinct IP addresses located in the Netherlands.  Therefore, users of Aria Operations for Networks are advised to update to the latest version as soon as possible to mitigate potential risks.
